2.1 Introduction
Surface modification is a prominent field of engineering of utmost importance for biomedical
applications. When having in mind the contact of a medical device with the human body – resulting
from surgical or topical implantation – the reaction to this “foreign body” must be considered. The
surface of a medical device is the first contact with the biological environment. Upon contact, a series of
bio-recognition processes (such as protein/cell adhesion and inflammatory response) occur between
the surface of biomaterials and the biological environment [1-5]. It is evident that such interface defines
whether the device will be accepted or rejected by the body, and therefore the surface properties play
an extremely important role in its success.
Surface engineering has been commonly achieved through techniques such as plasma [6], polymer
grafting [7], micro/nanofabrication [8] and Langmuir-Blodgett [9]. Each one of them, different as they
may seem, often aim for the same goal: to modify the characteristics of a selected surface while
retaining the properties of the bulk materials. Using the example of artificial prosthesis, the surface
could be improved for better biointegration through the enhancement of its antimicrobial properties,
biocompatibility, degradation resistance and drug loading capability [10-12], while preserving the native
mechanical properties.
It is notable how surface modification in biomedical applications has motivated so much interest in the
scientific community. Nowadays, modifying a surface is no longer limited to the improvement of an
implant’s integration. Technological ramifications have allowed producing surfaces that respond to
stimuli, tune cell adhesion, mineralize and adjust the permeability of active agents’ carriers [13-16]. In
particular, surfaces containing nano- or micro-scale features in a well-controlled manner have been
shown to influence cellular adhesion and metabolism [17]. In this sense, surface modification has also
become a synonym of “control”.
Taking Nature as the greatest of inspirations, scientists and engineers have developed many biomimetic
concepts based on the constant evolutionary improvement of designs and functionalities of natural
occurring materials [18]. One example is the layered organization found in natural materials, such as
the case of nacre found in the shells of sea animals. Nacre consists in a hierarchical and layered
structure of calcium minerals capable of dissipating high amounts of mechanical energy [19-21]. In an
attempt to mimic natural layered structures, a strategy consisting in the alternate adsorption of
polyelectrolytes onto solid surfaces – polyanions and polycations – was introduced. In this process, two
or more constituents can be added on top of a substrate sequentially with nanometric precision as
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
40
many times as desired, until stacks of numerous layers give rise to multilayered thin films. This concept
was first introduced by Iller [22] in 1966, who assembled alternate layers of positively and negatively
charged colloidal particles (such as silica and alumina) onto solid smooth surfaces. Later, Decher and
Hong [23] expanded this concept using anionic and cationic bipolar amphiphiles containing rigid
biphenyl cores, and adsorbed them alternately onto a positively charged planar surface. They
demonstrated the construction of a film with 35 amphiphile layers accounting for a total thickness of
170 nm. After completion of their follow-up work [24,25] this strategy became known as layer-by-layer
(LbL). Since its introduction, it has become one of the most prominent surface engineering strategies in
materials science, capable of providing a reliable, easy, versatile and cost-effective way of tuning
interfaces. Furthermore, a wide variety of constituents can be selected. The only requirement is that
multipoint interactions – such as electrostatic contacts, van der Walls forces, and hydrogen bonding –
exist between each of them to enable their sequential adsorption [1,26-30]. It is a simple and versatile
technique that allows producing robust coatings, even in substrates with convoluted and three
dimensional geometries. Harmful solvents (e.g., crosslinkers, organic solvents) and harsh processing
conditions (e.g., high temperatures, extreme pH values) are seldom required, making LbL an attractive
technique for biological-based applications. Specialized biomaterials and ligands, such as cell adhesion
enhancers, may be used in order to mimic biological structures and functions, rendering a substrate
more instructive for cell behavior [27,31]. Multilayered films can also act as drug reservoirs: active
agents may be embedded in the multilayer constitution while preserving their bioactivity, especially
when the protection of drugs until their delivery is desired [32,33].
Due to the broad scope and fast development of LbL, dozens of review articles have contributed to this
topic in the last decade. In 2006, Kotov and coworkers [30] focused on a comprehensive review about
the bioactivity of multilayer films for biomedical applications, such as superhydrophobic surfaces,
biosensors, drug delivery, protein/cell adhesion, mediation of cellular functions and implantable
materials. These authors estimated that LbL could be extrapolated to the third dimension in the
following years in order to conceive scaffolds with specific embedded growth factors, receptors, or
ligands. Their expectations have been met as several works have showed the production of complex
geometrical structures using this technology. Another review by Picart and coworkers [1] in 2010
reminded us of the fundamentals of LbL and how the experimental conditions affect the final properties
of a multilayer films. Namely, the mechanism of exponential growth, which describes an alternative non-
linear model of thickness growth per layer, was reflected upon. In 2012, Tong, Song and Gao [34]
reviewed the construction of spherical containers (namely capsules) for drug delivery, biosensing and
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
41
confining chemical reactions, showing how LbL has surpassed the simple idea of improving interfaces
and creating functional surfaces.
In this review, we intend to discuss the state-of-the-art developments of LbL-based strategies, especially
those with applicability in the biomedical field. Through selected recent examples from the literature, we
will discuss how LbL has been established as a conventional surface modification technique in little
more than 20 years thanks to this technique’s capability to address a wide range of biomedical
applications. Simultaneously, it is our intention to open the question of whether LbL, as it stands now,
surpasses other existent technologies and what potential is still reserved for the future development of
multilayered biomedical devices with value for biomedical applications.
2.2 Fundamentals of the layer-by-layer technique
2.2.1 Layer-by-Layer as a tool for surface modification
LbL adsorption relies in the interaction between two or more distinct materials that possess
complementary interactions, i.e. that the properties of both materials result in their mutual attraction.
The most exploited buildup mechanism of multilayer films is the assembly driven by electrostatic
interactions of oppositely charged components, as depicted in Figure 2.1.
Figure 2.1. Schematics of layer-by-layer adsorption of polyelectrolytes based on an electrostatic
mechanism deposition. The procedure is based on the contact of the substrate with a solution with an
oppositely charged polymer. In the depicted example, negatively charged round substrates are
submerged in an aqueous solution of a polycation, followed by a solution containing a polyanion. Each
adsorption stage is separated by a rinsing step, to remove loosely adsorbed molecules.
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
42
Besides electrostatic assembly, constructing multilayer films may rely on short-range interactions, such
as van der Walls forces and hydrogen bonding [35-37]. Nowadays it is acknowledged that the gain in
entropy due to the release of counterions plays a key role in the LbL adsorption process. Its outcome is
often the organization of the layers in a more coiled and interdigitated conformation, leading the
polyelectrolyte molecules to lose degrees of freedom [38-40].
Many types of charged molecules and nano-objects are suitable for deposition by electrostatic
interactions, from nanoparticles [41-43], carbon nanotubes [44,45], clay platelets [46],
dendrimers [47,48], polysaccharides [49-51], polypeptides [52-54], nucleic acids [55,56] and viral
components [57,58]. Special emphasis has been given to synthetic polyelectrolytes, such as the widely
investigated poly(styrene sulfonate)/poly(allylamine hydrochloride) (PSS/PAH) system – considered so
far as a model of multilayered thin films [1]. Synthetic materials are usually highly versatile materials
with well-defined structures with tailored properties, such as molecular weight and charge density [59].
Thanks to their tailored properties these systems have been used as a means to determine the
influence of several construction conditions involved in the LbL buildup. For example, it is known that
varying the pH of weak polyelectrolytes also varies the protonation state of their ionizable groups, this
way influencing the availability of charged groups; additionally, a moderate ionic strength can help
reducing electrostatic repulsion between charged groups and favor electrostatic assembly [60-62].
Another parameter is temperature, which increases the mobility of the adsorbed molecules and the
chances of finding more energetically optimal binding sites at the deposition site [63].
Synthetic materials have served their purpose, but for biomedical applications materials that exhibit
biological features should be more appropriate. Natural materials are intricate structures which have
risen from hundreds of millions of years of evolution. Comparing to our current technology, Nature was
able to conceive structures more multifaceted than man-made materials, forming complex arrays,
hierarchical structures and multifunctionality [11,64,65]. Natural materials often avoid triggering
chronic or immunological reactions and toxicity, and are therefore appropriate multifunctional
ingredients for constructing multilayer films and coatings with improved interface with the biological
environment [66].
2.2.2 Moving LbL toward faster production
The number of parameters that may influence the buildup of multilayer films is broad: LbL requires
complementarity between the multilayer constituents, but the strength of the forces driving the
assembly may be influenced by other parameters. Intrinsic properties – such as the molecular weight of
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
43
polymers or size of inorganic particles, charge density and polarity – and external properties – such as
temperature, pH of the solvent and ionic strength – may facilitate or hinder a constituent’s adsorption.
The result depends on the original properties of the materials. For instance, varying the pH of a weak
polyelectrolyte above or below its acidic constant (pKa) will greatly impact on its overall charge density
and ultimately electrostatic interactions [67,68]. Therefore, the construction of multilayer films based on
new and not much used constituents may require a thorough preliminary screening process.
Nonetheless, as soon as this temporal hardship is overcome, the optimal conditions will be determined
and they can be applied in the mass-production robust nanostructured coatings.
Despite all the presented advantages of LbL, this technique has one fundamental drawback: it is
generally a time-consuming process. To construct a multilayer film, the adsorption time to assemble a
single layer may vary with the nature of the constituents. A standard time of 10 minutes is usually
acceptable, plus a rinsing step that may take an equivalent time scale. Surprisingly, the effect of
reducing the processing times (sacrificing some mass deposition) was never properly addressed as a
way to accelerate the fabrication of the films. In a scale-up perspective, and when large numbers of
layers are required, automated devices have been proposed for the production of multilayer films. The
most common devices are dipping machines, which allow parallel construction of several films at once.
They function similarly to manual dipping in every aspect but its automated nature permits not only the
repetition of multiple adsorption cycles over long construction times but also the parallel assembly of
multiple films. This way, thicker multilayer films with several micrometers can be obtained in high
quantities [69-71].
One could argue that, although many films can be fabricated in parallel, the fabrication time is still too
long. An alternative procedure is a sputtering-based strategy which, rather than dipping, sprays the
surface. The fabrication time of the latter has been reported to be greatly shortened due to enhanced
adsorption by the spray pressure. Schlenoff, Dubas and Farhat [72] showed the construction of
poly(diallyldimethylammonium) chloride/poly(styrenesulfonate) (PDADMAC/PSS) multilayer films by
spraying the respective solutions onto silicon wafers. For that purpose, they used a sprayer as simple as
a hand-operated “plant mister”, making it possible for each layer to be adsorbed in a matter of seconds.
Their morphology, uniformity, and chemical composition were similar to coatings made by dipping.
Izquierdo et al. [70] followed a similar spraying strategy for the assembly of PSS/poly(allylamine)
hydrochloride (PAH) multilayers, where they reiterated the findings of the previous authors.
Although the process of LbL started as being an inherently slow processing method that requires a
lengthy preliminary screening stage, these drawbacks have been addressed and reduced to a minimum
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
44
in the last decade [73]. Furthermore, the use of automated devices, including unconventional
sputtering-based approaches, have made it possible to construct multilayers a lot faster (about a factor
of 250 in the latter example) and are appropriate for future industrial mass-production with low risk of
stock shortage.
2.3 Surfaces with specialized properties
2.3.1 Surfaces containing adhesive constituents
Multilayer films and coatings can exhibit higher forms of specialized properties by selecting functional
materials as their components. One such example is the use of polymers that are known to exhibit
adhesive properties in nature. Without much effort, a great source of adhesive natural materials can be
found in the sea, such as the polysaccharides chitosan (CHI) and alginate (ALG). CHI is derived from
chitin, found in the exoskeleton of shellfish or crustaceans, like shrimp and crabs, and ALG is a
structural component found in brown algae. These two polysaccharides share a marine origin and
exhibit important properties for biomedical applications – biocompatible, adhesive, nontoxic,
bacteriostatic, fungistatic, antimicrobial and hemostatic [66,74] – which proved to be useful in drug
delivery, implants and wound dressings [75-77]. Another strategy to obtain adhesive materials is to
produce synthetic analogues based on natural systems, such as the adhesive proteins rich in 3,4-
dihydroxy-phenylalanine (DOPA). DOPA, also a precursor of dopamine, can be found in the threads
expressed by mussels, which have been shown to attach to many types of inorganic and organic
surfaces thanks to the exhibition of catechol hydroxyl groups [78,79]. Catechol-modified biomimetic
polymers can be used to aid in the construction of the multilayer film itself. As demonstrated by
Lee et al. [80] catechol-functionalized poly(ethylenimine) (PEI) and hyaluronic acid (HA) adsorbed could
be adsorbed onto any sort of substrate, namely poly(tetrafluoroethylene) (PTFE), silicon and gold.
Karabulut et al. [81] exploited the iron(III) (Fe3+) crosslinking mechanism of catechol groups to tune the
mechanical properties of films made of carboxymethylated cellulose nanofibrils modified with dopamine.
The adhesive forces were measured using a silica probe demonstrating that, in the presence of Fe 3+
,
dopamine-functionalized films are more resistant to deformation than films prepared from unmodified
nanofibrils. Wu et al. [82] prepared multilayers of PAH and poly(acrylic acid) (PAA), the latter modified
with dopamine, and crosslinked the films by an oxidation reaction mediated by sodium periodate for
better stability. These coatings could be peeled by a sodium hydroxide solvent, providing undamaged
free-standing membranes. Curiously, DOPA and its analogues have been used as a mechanism to
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
45
improve the construction of LbL films, rather than increasing adhesiveness to surrounding tissues. It is
however expectable that the adhesiveness of such films is indeed augmented, judging by how catechol-
modified gels and membranes behave.[83-85]
Adhesive materials can be found in places other than the sea. For instance, Costa et al. [86] assembled
multilayer films made of CHI and phosphonate-modified levan, a fructan exopolysaccharide produced by
the halophilic bacterium Halomonas smyrnensis sp. nov. AAD6T. The adhesiveness of this polymer
comes from their hydroxyl groups that form strong adhesive bonds with various substrates [87,88]. The
adhesiveness of these films was verified by lap shear bonding stress between two overlapped films with
100 bilayers assembled onto glass slides, meaning that no peeling was attempted. In comparison to
CHI/ALG films used as controls – two polysaccharides often regarded as good natural adhesives – the
detachment force of the levan-functionalized surfaces was about 3 times higher than the control
(2.5±0.3 MPa and 0.9±0.1 MPa, respectively). The cell adhesion for 24 h conducted using a fibroblast
cell line also showed that cells were sensitive to the incorporation of levan and adhered mostly to these
coatings (110 cells?mm -2
in comparison to 20 cells?mm -2
in the control).
The technology of LbL films using adhesive materials has the potential to address issues related to
wound healing, namely in the performance of medical adhesives. Many synthetic adhesives currently
approved present limitations, which include poor adhesion in the presence of biological fluids, allergic
response and inflammation [89]. Therefore, the use of natural adhesive constituents may help in the
development of wound healing dressings and surgical biomaterials with improved adhesiveness to
organs and tissues.
2.3.2 Mineralization control
Bone regeneration and integration is probably one of the most researched areas in biomedical
engineering and a variety of systems have been proposed for this purpose [90-92]. Using the recurrent
example of orthopedic bone implants, coatings that exhibit biomineralization capability may provide a
favorable environment for osteogenesis and a bone-friendly interface between the implant and host’s
bone [93,94].
Biomineralization can be achieved following two strategies: (i) addition of inorganic components (e.g.
silicate-based particles), or (ii) incorporation of osteoinductive molecules (e.g. polymers and proteins).
An example of (i) are bioactive glasses. These materials have been subject of much research in the last
decades because when in contact with physiological or simulated body fluids they form a surface
apatite layer. Such apatite layer permits an adjusted bonding of the implant to bone in vivo, preventing
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
46
the formation of a fibrous capsule and promoting a stronger osseo-integration. Ultimately, this layer can
bind to the collagen of connective tissue cells, like osteoblasts [95]. In the case of (ii), bone
morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) are well-known growth factors which have been widely used for bone
repair and are known to stimulate the proliferation, migration and differentiation of stem cells [96].
One would not expect LbL devices to be used as systems aimed to integrate or regenerate a hard tissue
such as bone, since most polymeric multilayer films do not exhibit mechanical properties equivalent to
the bone. However, it may be used to engineer an appropriate interface between an implantable device
and bone, since LbL allows incorporating distinct classes of materials in their structure. Thus, strategies
can be devised to convert a “soft” multilayer to the purpose of triggering biomineralization.
Couto, Alves and Mano [41] constructed multilayer films that contained bioglass nanoparticles as an
inorganic ingredient that provided biomineralization capability in vitro. The synthesized nanoparticles
had a charge of -25 mV, which enabled them to interact with the polycationic CHI via electrostatic
interactions. Using a quartz-crystal microbalance (QCM), they demonstrated that films up to 10 bilayers
could be successfully assembled. Using a simulated body fluid (SBF), they showed that it was possible
to induce the formation of apatite crystalline layers, similar to the ones found in the inorganic
component of bone. The mineralization was also more pronounced with increasing number of layers.
Fukui and Fujimoto [97] described the conception of a nanocapsule templated in phospholipids that
encapsulated phosphate ions. The phospholipids were coated using CHI, dextran sulfate or DNA and
then incubated in a solution containing calcium ions. They demonstrated that changes in the surface
chemistry could influence the counterion diffusion and therefore the biomineralization rate (Figure 2.2).
Despite the efforts made so far, biomineralization-inducing multilayers still remain a largely unexplored
approach. Most likely the reason lies within the fact that immobilizing particles inside a multilayer
structure is not an easy task. While a polymeric film may have only a few nanometers but an
interpenetrated structure, a nanoparticle can be very large in comparison. Thus, it is likely that the
production of biomineralizing surfaces will be limited to the loading of osteoconductive agents.

2.3.3 Stimuli-responsive surfaces
Higher degrees of functionalization can be achieved by introducing stimuli-responsive constituents.
Usually, a surface – modified or not – is perceived as a static interface, that is, no structural changes
occur upon switching environmental parameters. However, stimuli-responsive surfaces are dynamic and
undergo conformational changes upon variations of specific external factors. An elegant example found
in Nature exhibiting such mechanism is skin. Skin is the largest organ of the human body and it can be
perceived as the ideal multifunctional membrane that responds to every variation in its environment –
heat/cold, humidity, chemical/mechanical stress and even light [99]. Exploiting external stimuli has
been extensively researched for several devices, such as grafted surfaces and hydrogels [100], but not
as much in multilayer systems for controlling biological events, like cell attachment/detachment
mechanisms. Some works described films made of CHI and elastin-like recombinamers (ELRs), a
recombinant class of elastin-like polymers (ELPs). ELRs are genetically modified polypeptides that
undergo a phase transition when in solution dependent on temperature: below a critical transition
temperature, the free polymer chains adopt random coil conformations; above it, they fold into an
organized structure known as ?-spiral [101]. Using this polysaccharide/polypeptide formulation, both
bilayer coatings [102] and multiple responsive multilayers [27] were made. In the latter, variations of
pH, ionic strength and temperature triggered a transition of wettability between a moderately
hydrophobic character (contact angle around 70º) to a superhydrophilic surface (contact angle of 0º).
These variations were observed above pH 11, ionic strength 1.25 M in NaCl, and temperature of 50ºC.
The genetic nature of ELRs permitted the inclusion of the cell adhesion sequence arginine-glycine-
aspartic acid (RGD), the minimal sequence required for recognition by cell membrane integrins [103].
The adhesion of osteoblast-like cells was higher in these films than in films ending in CHI or a
scrambled nonfunctional RDG analogue. Although cell adhesion was influenced by the exhibition of
specialized bioactive groups, the possibility to use external stimuli to control the attachment or
detachment of cells was not explored. The reason lies in the fact that the variation of the surface
properties evaluated in terms of wettability variations only occurred at values that are simply not
suitable for biological experiments. However, in another report from the same group [104], a multilayer
film made of ALG and CHI modified with poly(N - isopropylacrylamide) (PNIPAAm) was developed to
reproduce the cell-sheet technology developed by Okano and coworkers [105], which allows a thin layer
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
49
of cells to be harvested for reculture, transplantation or differentiation. Human osteoblast-like cells were
seeded until confluence was achieved at 37ºC and the temperature was lowered afterwards to 4ºC.
Cells started to peel and detached from the surface as a thin layer, which occurs due to the extension
of the PNIPAAm chains and increase of hydrophilicity. These cell-sheets could be harvested and seeded
again in a different culture support to demonstrate their viability. A similar approach was demonstrated
by Zahn et al. [106] who used an ion-induced detachment of myoblast cell layers through the eroding
effect of ferrocyanide on PLL/HA multilayers.
Temperature, ionic strength, and pH can be easily manipulated to influence the response of
“intelligent” materials contained within the LbL formulation. However, sharp variations of the last two
may be aggressive to cells as they are not capable of withstanding hypotonic/hypertonic and extreme
acid/alkaline conditions. Temperature changes, on the other hand, are usually more tolerated by cells
for temperatures up to 37ºC, and the example of cell-sheet technology is a fine example of that [107].
Another stimulus that may be exploited is light. The use of light would be a convenient way of
controlling a surface’s properties since it can be easily emitted or blocked on demand. Moreover,
biomedical applications could benefit from its noninvasive character, capability of deep tissue
penetration and fine spatial control over its intensity [108]. One example of light-responsive films is the
work of Ahmad, Saqib and Barret [109], who developed films containing anionic azobenzene-
functionalized polyelectrolytes. The polyelectrolytes were distinct and exhibited different
hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity character, which ultimately reflected upon the ultraviolet (UV)-visible
absorption spectrum of each film. Azobenzenes linked to hydrophilic groups exhibited higher absorption
maxima (423–440 nm) than azobenzenes linked to hydrophobic groups (407–414 nm), in both cases
values slightly higher than the maximum UV wavelength of 400 nm. Multilayer systems that respond to
light are seldom referred in the literature. This may be related to the fact that most light-sensitive
molecules respond mostly to light in the UV spectrum, which is harmful to biological cells. Nevertheless,
the presented example shows how the inclusion of light-responsive groups linked to distinct radical
groups may help shifting the maximum absorption wavelengths toward the visible spectrum.
2.4 Coating of implantable devices
The modification of implantable medical devices is perhaps the most evident application resulting from
LbL strategies in the biomedical field. The versatility of LbL and the possibility of developing surfaces
with specialized properties have already been applied as a means to improve the integration and to
adjust the biorecognition of implantable devices, such as prosthesis and stents. Currently, most of the
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
50
improvements in the performance of an implant are possible thanks to the development of more
anatomically-shaped geometries. This is particularly evident in the case of bone implants, which are
increasingly easier to attach to the bone and provide more comfort for the patients [110-112]. Besides
design, it is known that an efficient integration is determined mainly by the surface characteristics of the
implantable device (surface microstructure and chemical/biochemical nature), which influence the
subsequent adhesion of proteins and cells. It is common to find metallic implants (e.g. steel or titanium)
during surgical interventions [3,10,113]. However, it is difficult to assume that a metal with no
resemblance to biological materials provides appropriate integration and recognition by the body.
Therefore, LbL constitutes an adequate methodology to modify the surface of implantable devices, as it
could be employed regardless of their geometry.
2.4.1 Coating of synthetic implantable devices
Most metallic alloys are negatively charged, like other common materials found outside the medical
field (e.g., glass), and thus provide support for the formation of a multilayer coating by adsorbing a
primer polycationic layer [30]. Zhankovich et al. [114] proposed to coat a titanium alloy using multilayer
coatings of either CHI/GEL or CHI/HA to improve osseo-integration. Their study was based on prior
conclusions by the same group that had shown showed that while CHI/GEL coatings stimulated the in
vitro adhesion and proliferation of human osteoblasts, CHI/HA coatings reduced it [115]. So, using a
rat tibia model, shear strength analysis did not show any biomechanical difference between the coated
implants and a control of uncoated implants after 3 weeks. However, after 8 weeks, compared to the
titanium alloy control, shear strength was increased up to 1.84-fold and 1.86-fold for CHI/GEL and
CHI/HA, respectively, indicating improved osseo-integration of the implant to the surrounding tissue.
Interestingly, these results contradicted their expectation to observe significantly higher integration with
GEL-coated implants. The explanation to this similar osseo-integration observed in the rat tibia model
could be due to the long-term exposure of the coating to a biological environment. This exposure could
have led to the partial dissolution of the outer HA layer and its inhibitory effect decreased. CHI would
then come in contact with the biological tissue and promote osteoblast proliferation. Both works
demonstrate the potential of LbL modified implants in orthopedic implant surgery, even using very
simple biopolymers, where a regulated osteointegration is desirable to avoid early loosening, especially
when osteoporotic fractures are involved.
Aiming for the treatment of coronary artery diseases, stents have been coated with polymeric
films [116,117]. Stents with no modification can trigger thrombosis and cytokines secretion, leading to
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
51
in-stent restenosis – a particular refractory form of neointimal hyperplasia [118]. Schweizer et al. [119]
coated nitinol stents with a multilayer formulation of CHI and heparin, a well-known glucosaminoglycan
with anticoagulant properties. First, tubes made of the stent bulk material were coated and bent in a
37º angle, showing that the LbL coating could be maintained and withstand mechanical loading. Then,
they conducted a mineralization study by immersion in a calcium nitrate and ammonium phosphate
bath in agitation for one week. The formation of calcium phosphate particles with less than 100 nm was
observed in the coated stents, while in the control large microcrystals were formed. Large calcium
phosphate crystals may be dangerous if released and transported into the blood stream, but
nanocrystals are not expected to trigger high thrombogenicity. Furthermore, they may help to increase
the mechanical stability of the assembled multilayers. In the same study, titanium samples were coated
and studied simultaneously. Surprisingly, crystals on the order of 10 ?m were observed on coated
samples, much larger than in the case of coated nitinol ones. This conclusion alerts to the role of the
substrate used, since it is likely that synergistic effects occur between not only the coating constituents
but also between the assembled coating and the substrate’s chemistry. The use of CHI/heparin films
may also result in antibacterial activity and suppression of blood clot formation, respectively. In fact,
Meng et al. [120] had previously shown that stainless steel coronary stents with the same coating has a
better hemocompatibility and more efficient re-endotelyzation than bare metallic samples, using a
porcine coronary injury model.
Lin et al. [121] tested the hypothesis that a stent that promotes the adhesion of endothelial cells –
either circulating in the blood or migrating from neighbor tissues – facilitates its integration and reduces
risk of stent failure. Stainless steel stents were coated with heparin/collagen multilayers, which could be
or not be further functionalized with an anti-CD34 antibody. Both types of samples and a control of
uncoated stents were implanted in rabbit femoral arteries. While no significant difference of neointimal
hyperplasia was observed between uncoated metal stents and heparin/collagen multilayer modified
stents, neointimal hyperplasia on the anti-CD34 antibody-functionalized multilayer coated stents was
significantly inhibited and provided an accelerated adhesion of both vascular and endothelial cells
(Figure 2.3).

Post-surgical infection due to bacterial contamination constitutes another major issue that leads to
implant failure. Bacteria can form biofilms on the surface of implants, therefore compromising the
performance of the device [122]. Therefore, it is crucial that initial bacteria adhesion to an implant’s
surface is prevented. Building multilayer films that exhibit antifouling properties is a possible solution for
this problem. Rendering a surface non-fouling can serve as immuno-‘‘camouflage’’ to prevent immune
rejection of implanted biomaterials or to enhance the efficiency of injected drug delivery vehicles [123-
125]. Reisch et al. [126] demonstrated that films containing PAH and a PAA containing
phosphorylcholine side chains resisted the adsorption of albumin, which served as an estimation of
cellular adhesion. Caruso and coworkers [127] demonstrated that PSS/PAH multilayer films with a
terminal layer of PSS-b- poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) were up to five-fold more resistant to bovine serum
albumin (BSA) adsorption than PSS-terminated films. Moreover, the binding of coated polystyrene
particles to human colorectal cancer cells was reduced 6.5-fold in comparison to native PSS-terminated
particles. However, since LbL allows the inclusion of active agents to the formulation of a multilayer
coating, the most straightforward strategy to avoid deleterious effects caused by microorganisms is
perhaps the addition of antimicrobial agents. For instance, Hammond and coworkers [128] coated
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
53
silicon substrates with N,N - dodecyl,methyl-poly(ethylenimine) (DMPEI) as a polycation with microbicidal
activity and a polyanion, such as PAA. The surfaces proved to be lethal against airborne and waterborne
bacteria (Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus) and viruses (influenza virus, strain H1N1).
2.4.2 Cells as supports for the assembly of multilayer coatings
Cell therapies based on bioencapsulation strategies have recently found utility in the treatment of
numerous pathologies, such as for diabetes, bone and cartilage defects, and cancer. Usually, ALG is
the most frequently employed biomaterial for the encapsulation of cells due to its abundance, water
solubility, mild gelling properties, high biocompatibility, and resemblance to the natural extracellular
matrix (ECM). However, the diffusion of essential molecules in hydrogels is usually less efficient than in
liquefied environments, which may compromise cell survivability [129,130].
Developing a device that provides immune protection and selective permeability is an important and
ambitious step in the development of an effective encapsulating barrier [131-133]. In the field of LbL
implantable devices, cells or cell agglomerates can be used as suitable substrates for the buildup of
multilayers. Therefore, cell surface engineering offers great potential to improve clinical outcomes
associated with this promising class of therapeutic devices.
An application that would benefit greatly of such approach would be the treatment of diabetes. The
widespread clinical solution for this disease is that of islet transplantation, but this brings problems such
as immune rejection, inflammation, thrombosis, hypoxia and weakened revascularization [134-136],
leading ultimately to the destruction of the encapsulated cells. Krol et al. [137] demonstrated that
Langerhan cells could be effectively coated with the polycations PAH or PDADMAC. Coating pancreatic
cells with multilayers is an alternative to the conventional microencapsulation approaches within highly
viscous ultrapure alginate droplets [138-140]. By taking advantage of the negative charge provided by
the peri-islet capsule, polycations could be adsorbed to the membrane of the cells, followed by the
polyanionic PSS. The multilayer coating succeeded in providing immunological protection to the cells.
They also retained their insulin secretory function in vitro up to 4 days and diffusion was allowed
through the coating. Furthermore, insulin release increased when high quantities of glucose were
present. This is a very promising approach of LbL for the development of effective cellular therapies,
which seemed promising to solve diabetes related problems, and their application in vivo was most
anticipated.
Recently, Wilson et al. [141] presented a polyelectrolyte multilayer (PEM) comprised of ALG and
poly(L-lysine) (PLL)-g-PEG to coat the surface of pancreatic islet cells. The surface engineered islets
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
54
were introduced through the portal vein and into the liver microvasculature in diabetic mice. Two weeks
after transplantation, 47% of the mice receiving the coated islets converted from a diabetic to an
euglycemic state, while 25% of mice that received uncoated cells showed improvements.
Given these examples, one can see that LbL-based strategies have the potential to improve the
integration of diverse types of implants. It can be easily applied to existing biomedical devices implants
and even to biological materials like cells for transplantation purposes. The possibility to introduce
functionalized and bioactive materials to a surface may lead ultimately to a good integration in a living
system and constitutes an advantage in comparison to other conventional techniques (e.g., temperature
and plasma treatments). The possibility to coat biological structures directly is unusual and may have a
great impact in the management of cellular viability prior and after implantation. This technology may
be extended to develop cellular strategies, for instance in the form of cell infusions that may be injected
intravenously for delivery to targeted tissues, such as the heart, or with other therapeutic functions,
such as immunoregulation or systemic production of growth factors.
2.5 Engineering biomedical devices
2.5.1 Construction of films for wound healing
With LbL, one can develop films with just a couple of layers or hundreds, with obvious implications in
the films’ thickness. Thin coatings with several nanometers or membranes that may reach tens of
micrometers can be obtained this way. When considering the production of membranes, film casting
and hot-melt extrusion are the most recurrent used techniques [142]. However, these techniques are
not completely compatible with biological applications: the use of organic solvents in film casting and
the addition of plasticizers in hot-melt extrusion may cause adverse reactions when introduced in a
biological environment. Since LbL-based strategies disregard the use of such agents, thick multilayer
films appropriate for biological applications can be constructed.
2.5.1.1 Development of nanostructured substrate-free membranes
Multilayers adhere strongly to the underlying substrate and usually cannot be harvested without risk of
damaging the film. Thus, many strategies were developed to produce films that could be detached,
which are usually referred to as free-standing films. These free-standing films resemble membranes but,
unlike conventional membranes, they are nanostructured and exhibit nanoscale precision thanks to
their organization in layers. Such a device offers all the advantages of multilayered coatings and is
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
55
useful for applications such as wound healing and drug delivery, with the added benefit of manual
handling [143-145].
A typical approach to fabricate free-standings is through the use of sacrificial layers or substrates that
can be dissolved after the buildup [42,146,147]. Ott et al. [147] used silicon wafers precoated with PEI
to assemble chemically polymerized polyanions bearing aldehyde groups and polycations with
4-methylpyridinium moieties. After crosslinking, the film could be detached easily from the substrate by
salty solutions. The salt weakened the PEI interactions with the silicon wafers, after which robust free-
standing films could be harvested.
Using salty solutions is preferable to chemical solvents, since the latter may cause both chemical and
physical changes to the film during this stage. However, even salt may interfere in the internal
structures of the multilayers [68,148,149]. Consequently, other strategies have been introduced as
alternatives to the solvent-assisted detachment of multilayer films more recently. Larkin et al. [145]
used planar substrates of Teflon and polypropylene to assemble polymeric free-standing films.
Polymeric constituents and these substrates form weak van der Waals interactions, which make it
possible to peel the films safely without risk of damage. The proof-of-concept was demonstrated for 50
bilayers of CHI/HA, crosslinked by glutaraldehyde to increase their stability in aqueous solutions. A
unique feature of these detachable free-standing films was their optical transparency. The transmission
of light is critical for microscopy observations and makes them suitable to be used as cell culture
substrates. Indeed, in that work fibroblasts were seeded and could be observed under light microscopy.
Caridade et al. [150] recently developed CHI and ALG free-standing films assembled on distinct low
surface energy substrates. In comparison to the work of Larkin et al. [145] no crosslinking was made.
Instead, 100 bilayers were assembled (around 35 ?m). They also exploited the possibility to produce
free-standing films exhibiting asymmetrical properties, that is, distinct properties in each face of the
membrane. After the assembly was concluded, one side of the membrane was effectively made of ALG
and the other of CHI. This property is useful if one envisages having two distinct properties in distinct
faces of the same membrane. In this regard, the in vitro adhesion of myoblasts showed that cells
adhered more to the ALG face (200 cells?mm -2
) than to the CHI face (40 cells?mm -2
), showing how the
simple selection of the starting and ending constituents can significantly influence the biological
performance of free-standing films.

2.5.1.2 Healing of tissue defects in vivo
Free-standings may also result from hybrid approaches using LbL together with other techniques. Not
only that, they can be associated with an additional substrate that helps in the posterior application of
the membrane to a wound. In this sense, free-standings may serve as protective coating for wounds,
requiring ultimately that a film is harvested and used independently of the substrate.
The group of Takeoka and coworkers has developed a LbL-assisted strategy involving spin-coating and
casting for the purpose of healing wounds in animals. One of their first works reported the use of a
“spin-coating”-assisted-LbL subsequently followed by casting [151]. Shortly, CHI and ALG were
sequentially adsorbed onto spinning silica substrates to obtain a film 75 nm thick. Poly(vinyl alcohol)
(PVA) was cast over the bilayered films and left at room temperature during a cure time of 12 hours.
Together with this PVA layer, with a thickness around 70 ?m, the CHI/ALG film could be easily peeled
from the silica substrates, making it easier to carry and place over a tissue defect (Figure 2.4a).

The authors performed a minimally invasive procedure to repair a visceral pleural defect in beagle dogs:
the PVA/(CHI/ALG)n complex was placed in contact with the defect. Next PVA was dissolved using non-
aggressive aqueous solvents, such as phosphate-buffered saline (PBS). Over a period of 24 hours after

was able to sustain the stress due to ventilation (Figure 2.4b). Problems such as the reduction in the
pulmonary tissue volume due to suture, and pulmonary air leakage could benefit from the use of
multilayer thin films as protective membranes and sealants [152]. Later, this hybrid LbL technique and
ingredient formulation was used to develop tetracycline-loaded films with antimicrobial effects in a
murine cecal punctured model (Figure 2.4c) [153] and nanosheets as a protective membrane for full-
thickness burn-wound infection in a murine model (Figure 2.4d) [154]. Their production differed slightly
from the first proposed strategy, in the fact that tetracycline was cast in the opposite face to that of the
PVA, followed by a spin-coated layer of poly(vinyl acetate) and dissolution of PVA.
These two last examples are particularly important for the translation of such approach to humans.
Burn injuries are perhaps one of the most common skin defects. Such an injury creates a large skin
area which is susceptible to bacterial colonization, leading ultimately to infections, systemic sepsis,
severe septicemia and, if left untreated, death [155,156]. Full-thickness burn wounds may require
tissue grafting [157]; thus it is important to have an effective protective barrier that protects the wound
until grafting is carried out. The necessity for bacterial protection takes greater proportions when
considering gastro-intestinal lesions, where the presence of multiple microorganisms may lead to
bacterial peritonitis [158]. The presented examples were able to circumvent such problems and have
great potential for future wound treatments in human patients.
Although the technology of LbL membranes has the potential to act as wound healing dressings, there
has been little research on LbL coatings in vivo. Based on the existing animal tests with hybrid “spin
coating-LbL-casting” technology and on the robustness of films made purely with LbL, its broad
application may be a matter of time. Additionally, this evolution may benefit from the use of biomimetic
approaches and natural sources of adhesive ingredients (as mentioned in Section 2.3.1) for dressings
with improved mechanical and biological performances.
2.5.2 Multilayer coatings for enhanced cell adhesion on flat surfaces
The surface of an implant is the first contact with the biological environment, and its modification – if
any – will dictate the extent of its integration and long-term stability. Modifying surfaces is not limited to
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
58
devices currently used in surgical practice but also to more sophisticated ones for tissue engineering
and regenerative medicine.
The versatility of LbL can help achieving better cellular attachment by tuning a variety of factors. One of
those is the stiffness of the multilayer film. It was demonstrated by Schneider et al. [159] how films of
PLL and HA were assembled and crosslinked with increasing concentrations of a water-soluble
carbodiimide. Higher concentrations of carbodiimide allowed achieving higher crosslinking degrees and,
consequently, higher elastic moduli, as well as higher surface roughness. The cellular adhesion was
affected by the stiffness: human chondrosarcoma cells adhered and spread preferentially in stiffer films.
Using the same mechanism, Phelps et al. [160] assembled films of PLL and polyglycolic acid (PGA) and
selectively crosslinked it by exposing only the outermost layers to carbodiimide. This interface was
turned into a rigid external skin that promoted the adhesion of pre-osteoblast cells, while leaving the
interior of the film unaffected. Although unexplored, this structure could be useful to encapsulate an
active agent within. Because the crosslinking is selective and not fully uniform, the deactivation of
embedded bioactive species due to crosslinking may be avoided.
Martins et al. [161] used CHI/ALG films crosslinked with glutaraldehyde, to study the adhesion and
proliferation of osteoblast- and fibroblast-cell lines during 1 week. In the first case, the cells proliferated
in a rate similar to cells seeded onto CHI-ending films, but appeared as more elongated and with a
higher metabolic activity. In the case of fibroblast-like cells, the proliferation was inhibited in crosslinked
films. The results of these authors show that films with higher stiffness are not always clearly beneficial
to cells and that different cell types may behave differently when contacting with different substrates. In
fact, the authors justified that the reduction of positive charges due to CHI crosslinking affected both the
attachment and adhesion of this cell line – L929 human fibroblast-like cells – which are known to favor
their adhesion.
The addition of bioactive compounds is another form of tuning the adhesion and metabolism of cells in
a surface. Lee and Kotov [162] incorporated delta-like 1 Notch ligands (DL-1) at the surface of PEM
films. The Notch ligands stimulated hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) to differentiate into T-cell
lymphocytes and progressively develop their own ECM. Gribova et al. [31] developed PLL/PGA films to
study the effect of the stiffness and the exhibition of RGD-modified PGA on muscle cell differentiation. It
was shown that uncrosslinked films exhibiting RGD were the most appropriate to induce the
differentiation of myoblasts, while crosslinked films – with and without RGD – inhibited it and exhibited
an excessive cell confluence that led to detachment.

59
Aiming to use multilayer coatings in living organisms, Picart et al. [163] tested the performance of
CHI/HA coatings – either crosslinked with a carbodiimide or uncrosslinked – in vitro and in vivo. By
using a QCM and fluorimetry, degradation of the films in situ was followed upon their contact with an
enzyme solution containing lysozyme, chitosanase and hyaluronidase. The in vivo degradation was
studied by implanting both types of films in mouse peritoneal cavity for 1 week. In both cases,
crosslinked films were more resistant to degradation in comparison to native films, which showed
almost complete degradation by the end of the studies.
The use of LbL-based substrates for cell expansion is an ever-evolving field. In contrast to the case of
implantable devices, which consist on the improvement of already existing devices, the reviewed works
pushed forward toward new ways of improving cell adhesion. Most of the times it involved the
development of new types of substrates, such as the example of ligand-functionalized surfaces. It is
debatable whether the modification of 2D surfaces using LbL is a solution or an alternative to already
existing approaches. For the simple purpose of cell adhesion, conventional techniques such as grafting
or plasma can achieve the same result, usually with much faster processing times. As will be debated
in Section 2.6.1, the future innovations brought by LbL may lie in the coating of substrates with
increasingly complex geometry and the addition of bioactive or smart constituents that may further
extend the functionality of 3D multilayer cell substrates.
2.5.3 Multilayer reservoirs for drug loading and delivery
The technological advances in drug delivery have been driven by the need to develop systems that can
effectively encapsulate, protect and deliver an active agent with specific kinetics, such as micelles,
liposomes, polymersomes, and polymer particles/capsules [164-168]. Such wide availability of delivery
systems – not to mention the quantity of drugs available in the market – are proof enough that there is
need to develop drug delivery strategies capable of improving the efficacy and bioavailability of bioactive
agents.
2.5.3.1 Films loaded with active agents
Picart and coworkers have performed several works consisting on the assembly of PEMs loaded with
BMPs. First, PLL/HA films crosslinked with carbodiimide were doped with rhBMP-2 after
construction [169]. Myoblast cells were seeded on these films and showed differentiation into
osteoblasts, as evidenced by the increasing secretion of ALP. Consecutive in vitro cultures showed that
rhBMP-2 retained its bioactivity for the length of 3 successive experiments. Recent works using the
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
60
same formulation assembled onto tricalcium phosphate/hydroxyapatite (TCP/HAP) macroporous
granules [170] and titanium [171] demonstrated the osteoinductive character of the BMP-loaded
multilayers in a rat ectopic model. Furthermore, these coatings could be stored up to 1 year without
significant loss of bioactivity. By studying the secondary structure of rhBMP-2, Gilde et al. [172] showed
that this growth factor retained its bioactivity when the films were stored in the hydrated and, to a lesser
extent, in the dry state.
Hammond and coworkers also developed a series of multilayer formulations for the loading and release
of various growth factors. They constructed a multilayer composition of polycationic poly(?-amino-
esters) and noncytotoxic polyanions – heparin sulfate and chondroitin sulfate – intercalated with
fibroblast growth factor 2 (FGF-2, negatively charged below pH 9.6) [173]. Assembling more layers
equaled to more FGF-2 loaded and also a faster release. The bioactivity of the growth factor was
retained, as revealed by in vitro biological assays. Using films built with distinct constituents, the
released FGF-2 promoted the proliferation of a preosteoblastic cell line up to 12 days in culture. Loading
multiple growth factors is a strategy that may help, for instance, to accelerate joint implant integration
and reduce recovery time and failure rates by delivering active agents that intervene in the multiple
biological events. In another report [174], multiple growth factors – rhBMP2 and a recombinant human
vascular endothelial growth factor (rhVEGF) – were loaded by adsorption into multilayers assembled in
macroporous polycaprolactone/?-tricalcium phosphate. The release of rhBMP-2 was sustained over a
period of 2 weeks, while it took 8 days for rhVEGF to elute from the films. Using a rat ectopic bone
model, films loaded with both growth factors were able to potentiate the formation of de novo bone, to
an extent 33% higher than films loaded solely with rhBMP-2 was introduced.
2.5.3.2 Polyelectrolyte capsules with tunable permeability
From all the 3D shapes that can be coated with LbL, the simplest is the sphere. When coated, spherical
multilayer shells surround particles that can often be dissolved to produce hollow capsules. Multilayer
capsules present several advantages that are not coupled so often in other conventional fabrication
techniques: (i) they can be prepared under mild conditions of pH and temperature, avoiding the
denaturation of sensitive species and thus allowing encapsulation in high quantities [175]; (ii) a wide
variety of drugs can be encapsulated, regardless of their water solubility [176]; (iii) they allow tuning the
release kinetics of an encapsulated agent to the external environment simply by adding a variable
number of layers and selecting the shell constituents [177]; and (iv) specialized functions can be
attributed by using stimuli-responsive or biofunctional materials with relevant biological interest [178].

between 25 and 37ºC, the mean diameter of the microcapsules varied between 5.5 and 3.2 µm,
respectively (Figure 2.5b and Figure 2.5c). The release of BSA was also affected by temperature: the
release of this protein was more sustained in the latter case due to the temperature response of the
ELRs, which in the case resulted in a permeability decrease of the multilayer shells. The influence of the
number of layers was also studied. As expected, having more layers resulted in an added barrier to the
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
62
protein diffusion, that is, a high number of layers reduced the shell permeability (Figure 2.5d and Figure
2.5e).
Kainourgios et al. [180] developed PSS/PDADMAC multilayer shells using silica nanoparticles (around
500 nm in diameter) as templates. Following the dissolution of the template by ammonium fluoride and
hydrofluoric acid, hollow spheres were obtained. After chelation, two additional layers (PAA and
methoxy-polyethylene glycol amine) were deposited on their surface and crosslinked. Daunorubicin was
loaded and released at distinct pHs, showing a high quantity release at acidic pH values (pH=4, around
70%) in comparison to pH 7.4 (around 15%). The reduced release at pH 7.4 was attributed to the
electrostatic interactions between the sulfonate group of the PSS – which is negatively charged at this
pH value – and the amino group of the daunosamine sugar of daunorubicin, which is positively charged.
The cytotoxicity of these structures towards breast cancer cells was dose-dependent and higher for
increasing daunorubicin content.
Recently, Shen et al. [181] fabricated BSA-gel capsules via a two-step procedure. First, calcium
carbonate microparticles entrapping BSA were coated with PAH/PSS bilayers, followed by removal of
the sacrificial core. Afterwards, a heat treatment at 80ºC converted BSA into gel. By exploiting the
isoelectric point of BSA (pI=4.8), loading and releasing doxorubicin (DOX) as a model drug could be
tuned. At a pH higher than 4.8, the negatively charged BSA allowed a favorable loading of the
polycationic DOX and its release upon lowering the pH below 4.8. Thus, rather than exploiting the
permeability of the LbL shell to load and release bioactive agents, as described by Kainourgios and
coworkers [180], they relied on the jellified interior to retain DOX. Melanoma models were created in
the lungs of mice and after injection of DOX-loaded BSA-gel capsules they were more effective in the
reduction of the number of melanoma metastatic nodules than injected free DOX.
Ingredients other than polymers can be used to render capsules stimuli-responsive. For instance,
Liu et al. [182] used an emulsification method to produce magnetic alginate microspheres with around
600 nm in diameter and coated them with PAH/PSS multilayer coatings. After the assembly, the
emulsified alginate was liquefied by EDTA but remained entrapped within the coatings, along with the
iron oxide nanoparticles. DOX (cationic) was post-loaded by diffusion from concentrated solutions to the
interior and was immobilized by electrostatic interaction with alginate (anionic), with an entrapment
efficiency of about 56%. Applying a high-frequency magnetic field resulted in an increase of the internal
temperature, resulting in an increase in shell permeability and DOX release with higher kinetics.
Furthermore, increasing times of exposure to the magnetic field resulted in increased released
quantities.

2.5.3.3 Capsules for the intracellular delivery of encapsulated agents
Multilayer microcapsules have been demonstrated to be suitable carriers for drugs and to deliver them
either by conventional mechanisms of diffusion to the surrounding environment or by delivering them
directly to the intracellular environment. The latter possibility is particularly interesting. In theory, the
delivery of an active agent directly to the cells ensures that higher drug quantities will be available at the
targeted cell or tissue. Szarpak et al. [168] constructed microcapsules using HA and either PAH or PLL.
The microcapsules were labeled with fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) and co-incubated for 2 hours
with mouse macrophages, being both types internalized, deformed, and excreted by lysosomes. Caruso
and coworkers [167] reported that the shape of the capsules influences the internalization rate:
spherical capsules were more prone to undergo cellular uptake by human cervical cancer cells than
cylindrical ones.
Parak and coworkers [183] demonstrated the internalization of degradable dextran sulfate/poly(L-
arginine) and non-degradable PSS/PAH by embryonic fibroblasts for a period of 5 days. The
intracellular degradability of each capsule type could be followed thanks to the encapsulation of a
fluorescent compound, DQ-ovalbumin. Due to a characteristic self-quenching mechanism, this
compound exhibits a red fluorescence characterized by the close proximity of the fluorescent dyes, but
it shifts to a bright green upon proteolysis. After a culture time of up to 5 days, the biodegradable
capsules exhibited a green fluorescence, while the PSS/PAH capsules were in their majority red (Figure
2.6). This results showed that, although both types of microcapsules could be delivered to cells, the
availability of DQ-ovalbumin was higher when encapsulated within dextran sulfate/poly(L-arginine)
microcapsules.
The results from Parak and coworkers suggest that it is not enough to ensure that a drug is delivered to
cells: after delivery, the encapsulated agent needs to be available to the cellular machinery. Moreover,
with this strategy the release of the drug is mediated by the degradation of the capsule inside the cell,
making external control over this process not possible. In this regard, Palankar et al. [184] devised a
strategy to release an encapsulated agent on demand upon cellular uptake using infrared light. A
peptide ligand of the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecules was encapsulated
within PDADMAC/PSS microcapsules (around 2 ?m in diameter) doped with gold nanoparticles.

The stability and biodistribution of electrostatic self-assembled nanoparticles for systemic administration

A lot of effort has been done in the context of drug delivery devices made with LbL. This approach has
potential for the construction of nano- and micro-carriers that provide tunable release by varying not
only the number of layers but also external parameters, such as temperature and pH. It is even possible
to exploit mechanisms of delivery directly to the intracellular environment. Judging by the reviewed
works, multilayer microcapsules can be inherently uptaken by cells without requiring specific
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
65
functionalization wit bioactive materials. However, the intracellular degradation kinetics should be taken
into account since capsules made of nondegradable materials may limit the bioavailability of the
encapsulated agents. Much research has been carried out using DOX as a model drug. These reports
represent a step forward the usage of LbL systems in actual in vivo applications, such as in cancer
treatments, and their low or even absent negative impact in a living organism. Given the extensive
knowledge of such systems using chemotherapeutics to target cancerous cells, it is likely that cancer
treatments will be the most studied application using this class of carriers in the short term.
2.5.4 Biosensors
Biosensors are analytical devices that incorporate biological sensing elements. Screening metabolites
present in biological fluids and in the human body is of growing importance for medical analysis, rapid
disease diagnosis and drug discovery [186-188]. This concept has been transcribed to the LbL
technology, mainly in the form of capsules, where metabolite-sensitive fluorophores are immobilized
inside a carrier, resulting in a measurable response upon contact with a specific biological agent. Parak
and coworkers [189] developed microcapsules delimited by PSS/PAH multilayers and magnetite
nanoparticles that encapsulated seminaphtho-rhodafluor-1-dye (SNARF-1)-dextran conjugate as mobile
pH sensors. The purpose of using magnetite particles was to enable a magnetic separation of capsules
during their construction. SNARF-1 exhibits a pH-responsive fluorophore that emits green fluorescence
under acidic conditions and red under alkaline ones. Using this combination, they exploited the
mechanism of cellular intracellular uptake by fibroblasts and breast cancer cells. First, due to the
alkaline properties of the culture medium, the microcapsules exhibited red fluorescence. After 30
minutes of incubation, capsules internalized by lysosomal/endosomal compartments turned from red to
green, due to the acidic pH found inside the intracellular environment. The cells retained their viability
and capacity to divide and proliferate. Although two types of cells were used to study this biosensor,
there seemed to be no difference in the fluorescence response observed upon cellular uptake. In the
future, it could be interesting to have a biosensor of this class capable of measuring physiological
parameters in distinct types of cells with clear distinct signals.
This simple formulation is one of the pioneer works of LbL microcapsules that act as biosensors,
namely toward physical physiological parameters like pH. However, different approaches may allow
identifying other parameters such as biochemical signals. Pan, Zhang and Li [190] presented films
made of single-walled carbon nanotubes and CHI-dispersed tin disulfide nanoparticles assembled onto
glassy carbon electrodes by electrostatic interactions. While bare electrodes did not provide a clear
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
66
distinct electrochemical signal for individual compounds – dopamine hydrochloride and uric acid, in the
presence of ascorbic acid – the multilayer coating enabled the identification of clear separate
electrochemical voltammetric signals. Thus, the assembly of the coating allowed identifying
simultaneously two distinct compounds. This strategy could be useful for the fabrication of tailored
electrodes in a rapid and simple way that allow detecting and quantifying multiple specific metabolites
present in biological fluids.
Yu et al. [191] presented gold substrates coated with multiple dendritic stars of opposite charge
finished with an ending layer containing negatively charged carboxyl groups. These groups could be
functionalized with by carbodiimide and N - hydroxysuccinimide which allowed binding covalently
fluorophore-amino-modified single stranded DNA via amidation. Using this strategy, it was possible to
distinguish and quantify DNA hybridization behaviors between one mismatch and complementary target
DNA molecules, showing that such devices could be interesting DNA biosensor platforms.
Another approach is the use of reservoirs made by LbL that encapsulate sensing molecules. One such
example is the encapsulation of enzymes as sensing molecules. Enzymes are versatile biocatalysts
which have a wide range of important catalytic and sensing applications [192]. Kazakova et al. [186]
presented PSS/PAH microcapsules that acted as multilayer biosensors and as reservoirs of (i) glucose
oxidase, (ii) lactate oxidase or (iii) both enzymes. PSS was labeled with tris(4,7-diphenyl-1,10-
phenanthroline)ruthenium(II) dichloride complex (Ru(dpp)) – a well-known dye used in luminescence-
based oxygen sensors – and dihydrorhodamine 123 (DHR123) – a non-fluorescent molecule that yields
rhodamine123 which, in the presence of peroxidase, emits green fluorescence upon oxidation by
hydrogen peroxide. Oxygen-, glucose- and lactate-dependent spectrofluorimetric assays dependent on
concentration were conducted, showing reliable detection at the millimolar range in all cases.
The problem with enzymes is that they lack long-term stability and limited reusability for biosensing
purposes [193,194]. We described before how Parak and coworkers [189] introduced magnetite to
allow separation and harvesting during microcapsule production, but this concept could be used to
retrieve and reuse enzyme-encapsulating devices until the enzymatic content is depleted.
Garcia et al. [192] presented a thorough study in which they developed BSA-functionalized magnetic
nanoparticles (MNPs) coated with biotin- and avidin-modified horseradish peroxidase (HRP) layers
(Figure 2.7a and Figure 2.7b). The enzymatic activity of peroxidase adsorbed as a single layer was
compared to that of peroxidase in solution, revealing that the enzymatic activity was similar in both
cases. However, peroxidase activity increased linearly with the number of layers, exhibiting a four-fold
total activity upon the assembly of 5 layers in respect to the solution control (Figure 2.7c).

The use of colorimetric biosensors is particularly interesting. A patient could use it for rapid screening
purposes conveniently at home without any specific operation training. Colorimetric changes could
provide a quick indication of whether a person suffers from a specific disease. In a recent highlight from
McShane and Ritter [195] the potential of colorimetric biosensors was discussed. With the advent of
portable devices, such as smartphones and tablet PCs, it would be possible to install multiple
diagnostic software tools that permitted to identify and rate a response from a biosensor based on
colorimetric scales. Smart tattoos – color changing particles intended for a minimally invasive dermal
implantation – could react to the metabolites present in the interstitial fluids, resulting in measurable
shifts of their optical properties. Then, an external device could read that response, give a diagnostic
and even send it directly to a physician. Given the potential of LbL devices for biosensing and the
present technological advances, it is likely that this concept will grow, accompanied by a miniaturization
of biosensors, commodity and ease of use. LbL will contribute to this evolution since this technique
allows achieving higher levels of functionalization, customization and measurement of multiple
metabolites at once.
2.5.5 Implantable structural devices with tubular shape
LbL allows coating substrates with distinct geometries to obtain devices from thin coatings to
membranes and three-dimensional objects. Those could have adequate anatomic shapes that could be
used to replace or regenerate tissues or organs. Particular interesting examples of such devices are
tubular structures, which constitute another three-dimensional shape that can be obtained by LbL
besides spheres.
One typical approach to construct tubular structures is to coat the interior of cylindrical pores, which
usually lead to the fabrication of tubes with low caliber, in the order of nanometers. Liang et al. [196]
were able to conceive hybrid polyelectrolyte/nanoparticle tubes templated on the pores of
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
69
polycarbonate membranes, each pore with around 400 nm in diameter and maximum pore length of
10 ?m. The membrane was first functionalized with a PEI solution that acted as the primer layer and as
support for the assembly of PAA and PAH layers. The membrane was then dissolved with
dichloromethane, leaving intact only the coatings of the inner pores with tubular shape. To give
mechanical stability to these structures, the tubes were crosslinking with high temperatures (160ºC) or
in alternative they could be assembled with gold or cadmium telluride nanoparticles intercalated
between bilayers. Their inclusion could play an essential role in providing mechanical reinforcement,
affecting the properties of small blood vessels substitutes and the structure of cells. In both cases,
hollow tubes could be formed with an outer diameter similar to the size of the pore and wall thickness
ranging from about 50 to 80 nm. Yang et al. [197] studied the in vitro biological properties of CHI/ALG
tubes with around 400 nm of diameter and estimated wall thickness of 80 nm (thickness for 16
bilayers), fabricated using polycarbonate porous membranes. Their biodegradability in pancreatin
carried out overnight resulted in a diameter reduction to 160 nm, attributed to the CHI degradation due
to lipase present in pancreatic fluids. Cellular assays using human cervical cancer cells or breast cancer
cells demonstrated their low cytotoxicity. They also carried out cellular uptake experiments with each
cell type, showing that after 24 h the tubes could be found inside the cells. Due to the small size of
these nanotubes, such tubular structures could be useful as drug carriers for the intracellular delivery of
active agents.
Another approach for construction tubular structures is by coating sacrificial templates with cylindrical
shape to assemble multilayer coatings. Since this approach relies on the use of physical shapes, it is
possible to develop tubes with larger calibers that could be useful as blood vessel substitutes. Mueller,
Daehne and Fery [198] used tubular templates for the fabrication of hollow LbL tubes instead of porous
membranes. Glass fibers ranging from 5 to 10 ?m were coated with PDADMAC and PSS, after which
the fibers were dissolved by hydrogen fluoride. However, the authors warned for the possibility of
pearling instability, that is, the deterioration of a liquid cylinder into a series of droplets, also known as
the Rayleigh instability. This effect results from the tension of the wall surface provoked by a high ionic
strength at the time of template dissolution. To solve this issue, they added an additional layer of PAH,
which is known to withstand high concentrations of salt. Indeed, the addition of this material eliminated
pearling instability, resulting in the formation of stable hollow tubes. The tubes were dried and shown to
be resistant, with a Young’s modulus of around 200 MPa. Curiously, He et al. [199] took advantage of
the pearling instability to construct tubes that transform into capsules. They used the polycarbonate
porous membrane template to assemble PSS/PAH multilayer tubes. Then, by increasing temperature
Chapter 2. Polyelectrolyte multilayered assemblies in biomedical technologies
70
up to 138ºC, tube segments separated, closed and formed capsules. This interesting tubular-derived
capsular formation strategy can be useful for other applications, such as delivery of drugs or genes and
for the preparations of reactors or biochemical sensors [200].
In the work of Silva et al. [201] CHI/ALG hollow tubes were developed using glass tubes (around 1 mm)
as templates. Glass was first coated with a thin sacrificial layer of paraffin, which served as the
substrate to adsorb 100 bilayers. Upon assembly, the paraffin was dissolved by dichloromethane,
resulting in hollow cylindrical structures with a caliber comparable to the template (Figure 2.8a).
Afterwards, some tubes were crosslinked by genipin (Figure 2.8b) which provided structures with
storage and Young’s moduli about twice the uncrosslinked tubes when immersed in PBS (Figure 2.8c),
an important property for implantable devices. In vitro biological studies up to 7 days using a fibroblast-
like cell line demonstrated that the cells adhered preferentially to crosslinked films, showing a more
elongated and spread morphology (Figure 2.8d) in comparison to native films.
