4.2.2 Thin polymer network films
Nanostructured thin network films are structures in which surface confinement brings a range of
opportunities for engineering stimuli-responsive properties. These are polymeric networks – in many
cases very thin hydrogel films prepared from water-soluble polymers chemically linked to a surface,
resulting in a soft surface with well-defined mechanical, physical and biochemical properties (see Figure
4.1b) [31]. This kind of polymer network provides a soft three-dimensional scaffold similar to that of
macroscopic hydrogels, capable of hosting a wide-array of functionalities, ranging from proteins to
inorganic nanoparticles, but typically produced at the nano- and micro- scales. They can undergo
substantial swelling and contraction in response to external stimuli, making them excellent candidates
for “smart” surfaces with sensing and actuating characteristics [13].
The advantage towards their macroscopic counterparts is that gel thin films exhibit a fast swelling and
shrinkage kinetics. In fact, this behavior was predicted by the Tanaka and Fillmore’s model which states
that the characteristic time of the swelling transition is directly proportional to the square of the linear
size of the gel [32]. A critical issue for understanding and predicting the properties of surface-attached
polymer networks is the impact of confinement on their swelling behavior. Chemical linkage of the thin
gel to a surface prevents swelling in the parallel direction to that of the substrate, effectively confining
the volume change to one dimension. Such an effect has an impact in properties such as the structure,
mechanical properties, dynamics, and permeability of the network [33]. Additionally, the swelling
behavior of the polymer network is also influenced by the crosslinking degree of the film, as well as the
nature of the polymer, e.g. if it is stimuli-responsive.
An interesting property of thin gel polymer networks is that they are not limited to surfaces: they can
also be processed in the form of freestanding films if neither adhesion or covalent bonding to the
surface is triggered [4]. Therefore, it is possible to synthesize thin responsive membranes that can be
used in the selective separation of molecules and particles. While traditional membranes can perform
this function based on parameters like size and charge, responsive membranes can demonstrate a
gating function controlled by external stimuli. For instance, pores in the membrane can be switched
between an “open” or “closed” state and allow the passage of specific solution components at a
specific time in function of one or more stimuli [34,35].
Summarizing, thin polymer networks have a fast swelling/shrinking response and can accommodate in
their bulk various chemicals, biomolecules and nanoparticles. These properties make of thin gel
polymer networks attractive systems in microtechnology, namely as selective membranes, intelligent
drug delivery devices and biosensors [36-38].

4.2.3 Grafting
Grafting is a technique by which a polymer is attached to a substrate, usually solid [39]. The bound
polymer chains are often called “grafts” or “brushes” and lend their properties to the substrate (see
Figure 4.1c). There are two major approaches of grafting that can be applied: “grafting-to” and
“grafting-from” [40-42].
The “grafting-to” method refers to a chemical reaction between an end-functionalized polymer and a
suitable surface containing complementary functional groups, and requires that the polymer is modified
beforehand. Reactive end-functionalized polymers can be obtained through techniques such as
controlled/living radical polymerization (CRP), group transfer and ring opening metathesis
polymerizations [43-45]. A drawback of the “grafting-to” approach is the low density yield of the grafted
chains: steric repulsions between polymer chains hamper the formation of dense polymer brushes [46].
Another drawback is that with increasing molecular weight of the polymer’s the reaction between the
polymer end-group and the complementary group on the substrate becomes less efficient [47].
Nevertheless, “grafting-to” is simple to perform and, thanks to the covalent bond formed between
surface and polymer, the brushes are robust and capable of withstanding both chemical and physical
efforts.
The “grafting-from” method refers to the preparation of polymer brushes in which the polymerization is
triggered by initiator-functionalized surfaces. The immobilization of initiators on the surface can be
achieved by treating the substrate with plasma or glow discharge in the presence of a gas or forming
initiator-containing SAMs on the substrates. It can produce tethered layers of higher grafting densities
than the “grafting-to” approach since the active centers (radicals, ions, and ion pairs) of the growing
chains at the surface are easily accessible for monomer molecules in the swollen brush during the
course of polymerization [48,49].
Regardless of the method – “to” or “from” – the principles are common to both: (i) the grafting
techniques imply chemical attachment of polymers to the surface; (ii) the reaction occurs under
appropriate reactive conditions, which are usually specific for the kind of materials and substrates
involved; (iii) the polymers can be grafted to distinct types of surfaces, e.g. metals, glasses and silica,
and not limited to planar substrates but also applied to spherical ones; and (iv) the substrates often
assume the properties of the grafted polymer, with stimuli-responsive grafts rendering a smart-
responsive surface.

A grafted polymer brush can be composed of chains from a single homopolymer – single-component
homopolymer brushes – two or more different homopolymers – mixed brushes – or block-copolymers –
block-copolymer brushes. In the first case, when dealing with smart surfaces, the responsive behavior
originates from the inherent properties of the grafted polymer chains, their grafting densities, or by
changes in the balance between polymer–polymer and polymer-solvent interactions [50]. In mixed
polymer brushes, response comes from phase segregation, which causes the switching of the spatial
distribution of the functional groups that are exhibited by the brush exterior. Consequently the materials’
properties can be switched between among the ones of the constituent polymers [51]. The responsive
behavior of block copolymer brushes (as in mixed brushes) is based on the phase segregation of the
different blocks. The combination of different polymeric blocks in the responsive film broadens the
range of properties upon switching, so that the surface changes from the property of one polymer to the
property of the second polymer, or is locked in some intermediate state [52]. Graft-modified surfaces
with stimuli-responsive behavior have been extensively used in biology and nanotechnology. The cell-
sheet technology achieved through the attachment of poly(N -isopropyl acrylamide) (PNIPAAm), a
thermoresponsive polymer, is one of the most representative examples of the grafting approach in
tissue engineering [50]. Other applications based on other and stimuli (e.g. pH and ionic strength) have
also been addressed, such as the switchable wettability of substrates, controlled release of drug delivery
devices and sensors.
4.2.4 Layer-by-layer
Layer-by-layer (LbL) is a self-assembly-driven surface modification strategy that allows the construction
of nanostructured films onto distinct geometries, from simple bidimensional surfaces to more complex
three-dimensional porous structures. The principle behind it lies in the existence of multiple
intermolecular interactions where the cooperative effects of multipoint attractions play the most
important role (see Figure 4.1d) [11,53,54]. Constructing a multilayer film usually has two
requirements: (i) a reactive surface as the assembly support and (ii) a combination of two or more
ingredients for the constitution of the film that can interact with each other. The buildup process is
initiated by dipping the substrate in a solution of one ingredient that shows complementary interactions
with the surface, forming therefore the first layer. Then another ingredient follows, interacting with the
preformed layer, assembling a second one. Between each dip, a rinsing step is performed to remove
excess of non-adhered material from the interface. In comparison with SAMs and polymer brushes,
usually neither the surface nor the ingredients require modification prior to the LbL construction since
Chapter 4. Stimuli-responsive surfaces for biomedical applications
145
assembling the layers rely on the intrinsic properties of each counterpart and their spontaneous
assembly.
Usually the most important requirement is that two distinct materials possess complementarity, i.e. that
the properties of both materials result in attraction. In other words, LbL is a generic surface
modification technique with which (in theory) any material and surface can be used for this end, in
opposition to the methods described in the previous sections. The most representative buildup
mechanism relies on electrostatic interactions among surface/ingredient and ingredient/ingredient. For
instance, a polycation can be adsorbed to a negatively charged surface to form a layer. A polyanion can
then adsorb to the now positively charged interface, rendering it with a negative charge [55]. This
process can be repeated as many times as necessary under aqueous conditions to construct films with
thickness at the order of a few nanometers to tens of micrometers. Although electrostatic self-assembly
(ESA) is the most exploited mechanism, other interactions can be present, such as hydrophobic
interactions and hydrogen bonding [53,56].
LbL offers ease of preparation at mild conditions of temperature, pressure and pH, versatility, fine
control over the materials structure and robustness under physiological conditions. Additionally, the
mild and non-aggressive processing conditions of LbL make of it an appealing technique for tissue
engineering applications. There is a vast choice of available materials that one can add to a multilayer
formulation, such as proteins, nucleic acids, polysaccharides, and virus particles, as well as various
organic polymers, molecular assemblies [57-59]. and inorganic substances (e.g. clay platelets [60],
grapheme [61] and glass nanoparticles [62]). Furthermore, although LbL has been first introduced as a
surface engineering technique of planar surfaces [63], the concept has been extrapolated to 3D. The
sequential mechanism of layer adsorption can be extrapolated to construct thick membrane-like films
with tens of micrometers assembled on non-adhesive substrates (e.g. through van der Waals
interactions with polypropylene) to produce freestanding films [64]. Other types of complex geometries
with distinct shapes and sizes and as a result, devices such as porous scaffolds and drug delivery
capsules can now exhibit new properties with the option of further tuning by varying the nature of the
LbL ingredients and number of layers [65,66].
LbL films and shells can contain stimuli-responsive ingredients in order to render a system with a smart
response. Exploiting the advantages of LbL and intelligent multilayer systems have already been
proposed for different biomedical applications, including for biomimetic composite-like coatings, to
control the release of drugs, or to manipulate the adhesion of attached cells. In particular, systems
assembled using weak polyelectrolytes (e.g. chitosan and alginate) are inherently responsive towards
Chapter 4. Stimuli-responsive surfaces for biomedical applications
146
ionic strength and pH responsive, since they interfere with the electrostatic balance within the internal
structure of the film [58,67,68]. In similarity with polymer brushes, multilayer films with temperature
responsive properties have also been fabricated to control the cell attachment/detachment to a surface
for cell sheet technology, and to fabricate surfaces with acute wettability transitions [69,70].
4.3 Exploitable stimuli and model smart biomaterials
4.3.1 Physical stimuli
4.3.1.1 Temperature
Among the stimuli used to control the response, temperature has been extensively studied in the
biomedical field as certain diseases manifest temperature changes and this factor can be easily
controlled and applicable both in vitro and in vivo conditions. Thermo-responsive systems have a critical
solution temperature at which the phase of the polymer and solution is discontinuously changed
according to their composition.[8] PNIPAAm is the thermo-responsive polymer most used for conferring
thermo-responsiveness to surfaces. It exhibits a lower critical solution temperature (LCST) at about
32ºC in aqueous solution, changing sharply from a hydrophilic to a hydrophobic state upon heating [71].
It is believed that this transition involves the breakage of intermolecular hydrogen bonds between the
water molecules and the amide groups in the polymeric chains, which are replaced, above the LCST, by
intramolecular hydrogen bonds amongst the dehydrated amine groups. PNIPAAm has been
copolymerised with hydrophilic or hydrophobic monomers in order to control the kinetics of the
response [72,73].
Typically, above the LCST of PNIPAAm based surface-grafted polymers, surface wettability decreases
and the thickness of the grafted layer decreases (deswelling). The work of Shi and co-workers [74]
illustrates this behavior for bioactive composites of poly(L-lactic acid) (PLLA) reinforced with Bioglass ®
(BG) and grafted with PNIPAAm through the use of plasma activation. The water contact angle for the
PNIPAAm modified PLLA+10% BG composite was 51.9±2.4º, at 25ºC and at 37ºC it changed to
58.8±2.4º, being consistent with the increase in the surface hydrophobicity above the LCST. The range
of wettability can be further amplified to the super- hydrophobic/hydrophilic regimen by using
substrates with increasing roughness [75], which is also predicted in the Wenzel model [76].
Besides the grafting of PNIPAAm-based polymers on distinct substrates, LbL assembling has also been
used to confer temperature-responsiveness to surfaces. Serpe et al. [77] were the first to apply the LbL
Chapter 4. Stimuli-responsive surfaces for biomedical applications
147
technique to produce temperature-responsive PNIPAAM/-co-acrylic acid (AA)/polyallylamine coatings.
Since then, LbL surfaces containing PNIPAAm have already been suggested for cell sheet
engineering [70].
Other thermo-responsive polymers may be used instead of PNIPAAm. Poly(N-vinylcaprolactam) (PVCL)
is another thermo-sensitive polymer that can be deposited onto surfaces, which possesses very
interesting properties for biomedical applications such as solubility in water, biocompatibility, a
transition temperature around 31ºC and its cytoxicity has been referred as being much lower than the
one of PNIPAAm.[78,79] Thermo-sensitive films based on triblock copolymers have also been
prepared [80].
Nature also houses inspiration for the development of new polymers. Elastin-like recombinamers (ELRs)
– a recombinant class of elastin-like polymers (ELPs) – are genetically engineered peptide-based
materials that mimic the structure of natural elastin [81]. By exploiting microorganism systems, tailored
recombinant elastins based on the pentapeptide poly(VPGVG) can be produced and, thanks to their
recombinant nature, recombinant peptides with precision over the primary aminoacid content is
possible, being able to introduce relevant functional sequences, for example to improve cell adhesion,
trigger biomineralization and vascularization [82-84].
In aqueous solution, and below a certain transition temperature (Tt), the free polymer chains are
disordered, consisting in fully hydrated random coils. When the temperature is increased above Tt, the
structure loses the water molecules from hydrophobic hydration and the chains fold and assemble into
a ?-spiral conformation [85-87]. Although often associated with temperature-responsive polymers, the
fact is that such transition phenomenon can occur due to other stimuli, such as pH, ionic strength,
redox reactions and in specific modifications even due to light. In this perspective, ELRs could be
classified as a multiple-responsive material, and surfaces modified with this kind of macromolecules
have already been demonstrated to respond towards temperature, pH and ionic strength at the same
time [69].
Biosensing surfaces displaying topologically modified self-assembly with ELRs have been developed by
Chilkoti’s group. The “thermodynamically reversible addressing of proteins” (TRAP) technology obtained
by covalent micropatterning of ELRs onto glass surfaces against an inert background allows a reversible,
spatio-temporal modulation of ligand-binding triggered by the phase transition of the ELR at a solid-
liquid interface. Such technology can be applied in different systems for bio-analytical sensors in order
to detect single biomolecules [88,89].
Chapter 4. Stimuli-responsive surfaces for biomedical applications
148
Smart thin coatings using an ELR containing RGD sequences are also a new and interesting example of
thermo-responsive surfaces. These coatings can be fabricated through simple deposition of the ELR
dissolved in aqueous-based solutions onto chitosan membranes [82]. It was shown that the
conformational changes suffered by the ELR at its inverse temperature transition modified the
topography at the nanoscale and the wettability of the polymeric substrate, which could be potentially
used to control cell adhesion and protein adsorption (see Figure 4.2).

4.3.1.2 Light
Light could be an interesting stimulus in the context of stimuli-responsive surfaces, as it is widely used
in Nature as a source of energy. Photo-responsive polymers change their properties when irradiated
with light, due to light-induced structural transformations of specific functional groups (e.g.
chromophores) along the polymer backbone or side chains [90-92]. An important aspect of photo-
sensitive polymer systems is that using irradiation as a stimulus is a relatively straightforward, non-
invasive mechanism to induce a responsive behavior. The most well studied examples of photo-
responsive polymers are those that contain azobenzene groups. Azobenzene is a well-known
chromophore with an irradiation-induced cis -to-trans isomerization that is accompanied by a fast and
complete change in electronic structure, geometric shape, and polarity. By incorporating azobenzene
derivatives into polymer structures, materials with variable shape, polarity, and self-assembly behavior
can be obtained [91]. Azochromophores have been incorporated into a variety of polymeric
systems [10,91]. Other chromophores, namely spiropyran and its derivatives have been incorporated
terminally or pendantly to confer light sensitivity [93,94]. Spiropyran groups are relatively non-polar, but
irradiation with the appropriate wavelength of light leads to the zwitterionic merocyanine isomer that has
a larger dipole moment.
Illustrative works where photo-responsive LbL films were prepared can be found elsewhere [91,95]. The
studies related with photo-responsive LbL systems have shown that the photoresponsive cis –trans -
isomerization rates in the layers are highly dependent on the functional groups attached to the
Chapter 4. Stimuli-responsive surfaces for biomedical applications
149
chromophores [91]. Most of the works regarding photo-responsive polymers require isomerization
induced by ultraviolet (UV) radiation or visible light. Recent years have also seen a growing interest in
employing near-infrared (NIR) radiation as a trigger to activate delivery of encapsulated material from
LbL systems [96]. The use of NIR light is particularly attractive in biomedical applications because of
the weak absorption of NIR radiation by most tissues.
Photo-isomerizable monolayers applied to surfaces can also be used to control surface properties, such
as wettability [97]. In this case, the water contact angle was found to be lower for the spiropyran-
modified surfaces after irradiation with UV light, when compared with the contact angle found for visible
light. This was ascribed to the changes in the surface energy of the surfaces correlated to the switching
of the surface-bound spiropyran molecules between polar, zwitterionic and nonpolar forms.
4.3.2 Chemical stimuli
4.3.2.1 pH
“pH” has also been extensively studied in the biomedical field because this factor can be easily
controlled and applicable both in vitro and in vivo conditions. It is well-known that there is a pH change
along the gastrointestinal tract from the stomach (pH=1–3) to the intestine (pH=5–8) and chronic
wounds and tumor tissue are also slightly acidic. So, for example, pH-responsive systems can be used
for releasing drugs in the intestine in order to avoid their degradation in the environment of the
stomach [8]. They have also been investigated for gene delivery and gene therapy. “pH”-responsive
polymers contain ionizable groups that can accept and donate protons in response to a pH change.
Examples of pH-responsive polymers are chitosan, alginate, hyaluronic acid, PAA, poly(ethyleneimine)
(PEI), poly(N,N-dyakylamino ethylmethacrylates (PDAAEMA) and poly-lysine [98]. Grafting of pH-
responsive polymers has been used to confer pH-responsiveness to a surface. For example, chitosan
was grafted onto the surface of PLLA/BG composites [99]. In an acidic medium, chitosan becomes
positively charged due to the protonation of the free amine groups. The pH-responsive behavior of the
PLLA/BG composites modified with chitosan was confirmed by contact angle measurements. After
modification, the contact angle changed from 88.9±4.05º at pH 7.4 to 67.6±2.3º at pH 5.4. The
unmodified PLLA/BG composites revealed a hydrophobic character, presenting a contact angle of 82º,
independently of the pH.
In LbL, the growth of polyelectrolyte-based coatings is dependent on pH [100,101]. For instance, for
chitosan/alginate films, a value of 56 nm was obtained for the final thickness of the films built at a pH
Chapter 4. Stimuli-responsive surfaces for biomedical applications
150
of 7.0 and 34 nm for the multilayers assembled at a pH of 5.5 [101]. When the charge density of the
adsorbing species decreases (i.e., chitosan at a pH of 7.0), more polyelectrolyte chains are needed to
overcompensate and invert the surface charge, explaining the higher thickness associated with the
deposition of polymers at pH 7.0. Also, LbL coatings of polyelectrolytes respond intrinsically to pH.
Multilayer films conceived with chitosan and ELRs were demonstrated to be pH-responsive [69]. At high
pH values, the roughness of the substrates increased due to the triggering of the ELR self-assembly
mechanism into aggregates, besides the variation of the internal electrostatic interactions.
Micro- and nano-scale porosity can be introduced in LbL films by pH variations, thus allowing to control
film permeability [102,103].
4.3.2.2 Ionic strength
Polymers that contain ionizable groups are typically sensitive to ionic strength. In fact, due to the
attractive Coulombic interactions between oppositely charged species, such polymers may be insoluble
in deionized water but soluble in the presence of a determined oncentration of added electrolytes where
the attractive charge/charge interactions are shielded, as higher ionic strength solutions reduce the
range of electrostatic interactions [104]. So, changes in the ionic strength can lead to changes in the
polymer solubility and, therefore, in the length of the deposited polymer chains. Ionic strength is also an
important parameter that allows controlling film swelling. In the case poly-lysine/hyaluronic acid LbL
films prepared at an ionic strength of 0.15 M in NaCl, reversible swelling and deswelling occurs when
the ionic strength is cycled between 0.15 and 0.225 M [105]. Ionic strength has also been used to
control the permeability of LbL films as ionic variations can introduce porosity [106].
4.3.3 Biochemical stimuli
4.3.3.1 Antigens
Antigen-antibody interactions have been also explored under the scope of stimuli-responsive surfaces.
Such interactions are quite specific and associated with the complex immune responses that help
recognize and neutralize foreign infection-causing objects in the body.
Ai and co-workers [107] showed that platelets coated with anti-“immunoglobulin G” (IgG) multilayers
could be targeted to IgG-coated surfaces. An antigen responsive membrane based on dextran grafted
with both a fluorescent fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) antigen and anti-FITC IgC antibody was
proposed by Zhang and co-workers [108]. When free sodium fluorescein was added to the membrane,
Chapter 4. Stimuli-responsive surfaces for biomedical applications
151
antibody-antigen crosslinks were broken by competitive binding of the free antigen. The disruption of the
crosslinks caused the reversible swelling of the membrane. So, such membranes could be used as
gates for selective diffusion controlled by the presence of an antigen.
4.3.3.2 Enzymes
Bacteria located mainly in the colon produce reductive enzymes (e.g. azoreductase) or hydrolytic
enzymes (e.g. glycosidases) capable of degrading various types of polysaccharides, such as pectin,
chitosan, amylase/amylopectin, cyclodextrin and dextrin [109-111]. For example, polymer systems
based on alginate/chitosan are responsive to chitosanase and azoaromatic bonds are sensitive to
azoreductase [112,113]. Enzyme responsive polymers present the advantage of not requiring an
external trigger for decomposing, exhibit high selectivity and work under mild conditions, although is not
straightforward to determine the beginning of degradation. An interesting example regarding enzyme-
responsive surfaces are the ones developed by Todd and co-workers, which present cell adhesive
arginine-glycine-aspartic acid (RGD) sequences on-demand, that is, by enzymatic hydrolysis of inactive
RGD containing precursors that carry cleavable steric blocking groups [114].
4.3.3.3 Glucose
Glucose-responsive polymers can be specifically used in the controlled relase of insulin and for glucose
sensing. Typically, glucose oxidase (GOX) is conjugated to a pH-sensitive polymer [115]. GOX oxidizes
glucose to gluconic acid, inducing a pH change and the corresponding release of the insulin
encapsulated in the pH-system. For example Imanashi and co-workers [116] grafted GOX-conjugated
PAA onto a cellulose film. At neutral and high pH the PAA chains were extended due to the negative
charged of the carboxylate groups, occluding the pores of the cellulose membrane. The gluconic acid
that resulted from the addition of glucose led to a local pH decrease, protonation and subsequent
collapse of the PAA chains, leading to the insulin release.
4.3.4 Multiple responsive surfaces
Smart surfaces that respond simultaneously to more than one stimulus could be particularly interesting
regarding biomedical applications and could be used, for instance, to control in a more effective way
drug release or cell response. Some representative works where this type of surfaces was developed will
now be given. For example, dual responsive coatings of chitosan-graft-NIPAAm and alginate were
Chapter 4. Stimuli-responsive surfaces for biomedical applications
152
built [70]. AFM analysis confirmed that PNIPAAm is able to reconform upon temperature swaps even
when combined with other layers in a polyelectrolyte multilayer, demonstrating that the nano-
assemblies are thermo-responsive. In another work, a smart and stable polymer brush interface based
on PNIPAAm, PAA and poly(NIPAAm-co-AA) was able to reversibly respond to temperature, ionic
strength and pH, independently or simultaneously [117].
Thermo- and pH- sensitive films of poly(N,N -dimethyl aminoethyl methacrylate)-poly(propylene oxide)-
poly(N,N -dimethyl aminoethyl methacrylate)/PAA ((PD-PPO-PD)/PAA) were prepared by Tan and co-
workers [80]. These films present a thickness of 2150 nm at 6ºC and of 941 nm at 20ºC, when they
were deposited from distilled water at pH 7. This volumetric transition does not occur any more when
the same films were prepared from water at pH 4 because PPO already forms hydrogen bonds with
PAA (mostly in the protonated, neutral form) which are not available any more for water molecules.
Other interesting example of multi-responsive coatings are the PNIPAAm-co-AA copolymers sensitive to
pH and temperature that were prepared by Xia and co-workers [75]. The combination of this dual
stimuli-responsive coating combined with surface micro and nanostructure enabled the water contact
angle (CA) of the surface to be controlled over a range of 150º. On a flat surface, however, the CA
change was only 13º and 9.6º for a temperature range of 21–45ºC and a pH range of 2–11,
respectively.
4.4 Biomedical applications of smart surfaces
4.4.1 Smart coatings for tissue engineering, regenerative medicine and drug
delivery applications
Smart coatings can be used to control the properties of the surface of a substrate, such as an implant,
by changing the surface chemistry, topography and/or hydrophobicity, and therefore modifying protein
adsorption and cell adhesion. These coatings can be simultaneously used to release a drug or bioactive
compound in a controlled way. Some representative examples of smart biomaterial coatings will now be
presented.
Protein adsorption on PNIPAAm coatings has been investigated by distinct authors, showing that
adsorption is typically unfavorable below the LCST, being stronger above the LCST [118-120]. For some
proteins and some conditions, protein adsorption might become irreversible, inhibiting repeated
switching. It was found that protein adsorption reversibility on PNIPAAm coatings depends whether the
Chapter 4. Stimuli-responsive surfaces for biomedical applications
153
phase transition back to the hydrated protein resistant state is energetically more favorable than the
interactions formed between chains and the protein in the collapsed state [119].
Several studies have focused on the influence of the LbL film composition on protein
adsorption [121,122]. For instance, the adsorption of human serum albumin (HSA) onto
chitosan/alginate multilayer assemblies was assessed in situ using QCM-D [123]. It was found that the
behavior of human serum albumin (HAS) on biomaterials surface can be tuned by adjusting parameters
of the polyelectrolyte system such as pH, layer number, crosslinker and polymer terminal layer. The key
role of electrostatic interactions during HSA adsorption was evidenced in that work, since oppositely
charged surfaces were more effective in promoting protein adhesion. Also, novel protein-based systems
have been developed by self-assembly, introducing the possibility to prepare, in a controllable way, thin
reservoirs of proteins [124] and, by embedding biologically active proteins, film functionalization can be
achieved [125]. The LbL approach has enabled protein encapsulation to release active proteins in a
way that is applicable to objects of any desired geometry and size scale [126]. Moreover, microcapsules
with a hierarchical shell-within-shell structure of different proteins entrapped in polymeric layers have
been developed [127].
In the field of active molecule release, it is also very interesting to develop LbL films in which one of the
components hydrolyses above a critical pH value leading to film erosion and release of the active
molecule. This concept has been used for the pH triggered release of anionic polysaccharides and of
deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) from poly-(?-amino ester)-DNA films [67,128]. The decomposition or
release of active compounds can also occur through enzymatic hydrolysis [129]. For example, DNA and
non-activated DNAase were co-encapsulated in hollow polyelectrolyte capsules. The enzyme can be
activated by a chemical trigger which diffuses through the polyelectrolyte membrane, activating the
enzyme, the subsequent hydrolysis of DNA and the diffusion of small oligonucleotides through the
capsule wall [130]. LbL can also be used to coat inorganic microspheres to conceive smart
microreservoirs. Huang and Chang [131] developed multilayer microcapsules made of azido- and
acetylene-functionalized PNIPAAm that shrunk upon increasing the temperature from 25 to 50ºC
(Figure 4.3). These microcapsules were also permeable to low-molecular weight substances, such as
dextran.

There are many other interesting examples related with the field of active molecule release. For
instance, pH-responsive polymers may be used to deliver fragile biomolecules such as peptides or
oligonucleotides to the cytoplasm of macrophages, as the work of Murthy and co-workers
evidenced [132]. They used pH cleavable acetal linkages to remove poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) grafts
that mask the delivery vehicle and disrupt the endosome causing the delivery of biomolecules into the
cytoplasm before they are degraded in the lysosomes. PNIPAAm/-co-AA microgels/polyallylamine
coatings retained their thermo-responsiveness within the multilayer and allowed their use for thermally
triggered release of insulin [133]. An antimicrobial coating that can simultaneously discourage bacteria
attachment to the implant surface and release, in a tuneable dosage and rate, antibiotics into the
surrounding tissues has also been developed [134].
Regarding the use of smart surfaces to control cell response, several works can also be found in
literature. For example, Picart et al. [135] investigated the effect of grafting an RGD peptide onto distinct
LbL films on the adhesion of primary cells, and observed an enhanced cell proliferation for the
functionalized films. Boura et al. [136] evaluated the adhesion properties of endothelial cell on two
types of polyelectrolyte films ending either by polylysine, or poly(allylamine hydrochloride) (PAH), and
compared them to data obtained on polylysine or PAH monolayers, glass and fibronectin-coated glass.
They found that the cells seeded on the LbL films showed a good morphology and resisted to
physiological shear stress better, when compared to the cell seeded on glass or fibronectin.
Photo-responsive layers composed of made of PNIPAAm and spiropyrans have been used to tailor cell
adhesion by switching light on or off [95]. Cell adhesion has also been photo-chemically controlled
Chapter 4. Stimuli-responsive surfaces for biomedical applications
155
using RGD-functionalized azobenzene poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) surfaces [137]. It was found
that azobenzenes enhanced cell adhesion but, upon UV-irradiation-induced trans -cis isomerization,
which shortened the distance of the RGD-containing peptides from the surface, cell adhesion decreased.
Nakanishi et al. [138] built self-assembled monolayers having photo-cleavable 2-nitrobenzyl groups that
could be used to template cell adhesion. Bovine serum albumin (BSA), inert to cell adhesion, was
adsorbed over this monolayer. Upon exposing defined regions with UV light, BSA was released from
such regions. Finally, fibronectin, a protein promoting cell adhesion, was then incubated and covered
the irradiated regions. This method allowed producing patterned regions for cell adhesions and by
subsequent illumination it could be also possible to induce cell migration and proliferation.
4.4.2 Smart biomineralization
In medical devices for orthopaedic applications, either under traditional replacement concepts or
regeneration strategies, such as tissue engineering, it is important to promote the production of
bonelike apatite onto the biomaterial’s surface. It has been shown that surface biomimetic
mineralization may be triggered by either temperature or pH [74,99]. For PNIPAAm modified composite
PLLA film with 10% BG, it was found that the conformational changes occurring at the surface affect the
mineral formation below and above the LCST [74]. No mineral phase could be observed at 25ºC after 2
weeks in simulated body fluid (SBF). However, at 37ºC the treated film could form dense precipitates
with the typical cauliflower morphology, containing needle-like nanometric structures, characteristic of
biomimetic-formed apatite. Moreover, by exposing some regions of the surface to the plasma treatment,
a patterning could be made to combine stimuli and spatial control of biomimetic apatite [74]. This
allowed the insertion of PNIPAAm in specific chosen areas. Again, no apatite formation was observed
for these modified films at 25ºC. On the other hand, apatite aggregates were formed at 37ºC, with a
circular shape and randomly distributed over the composite surface, being consistent with the
PNIPAAm patterning generated during the plasma activation step. These apatite patterned surfaces
could be used in fundamental studies on differentiation, adhesion, proliferation and cell-cell signaling of
bone-related cells. These surfaces could also be used in fundamental co-culture studies involving bone
cells and other cell types [139,140].
For chitosan-modified PLLA/BG composites no apatite formation was found at pH 5.4 [99]. On the
other hand, a dense apatite layer of a carbonated apatite mineral similar to the major mineral
component of vertebrate bone tissue was formed at pH 7.4. For the unmodified substrates an apatite
Chapter 4. Stimuli-responsive surfaces for biomedical applications
156
layer was formed at both pH. Temperature and pH were chosen in the above mentioned works, but this
concept of smart apatite formation can be extended for other source of responsiveness and for other
type of mineral deposition.
4.4.3 Cell sheet engineering
The use of smart surfaces, specifically thermo-responsive surfaces, has been applied to the so-called
“cell sheet engineering”. This technology has been proposed to construct ideal transplantable tissues
composed exclusively of cells [141]. Initially, Okano and co-workers proposed temperature-responsive
cell culture polystyrene substrates prepared by the grafting of PNIPAAm onto these surfaces, which
allow the culture of confluent cell monolayers at 37?C and their recovery as single cell sheets when the
temperature is below the LCST of PNIPAAm. Afterwards, they have combined these smart surfaces with
patterning, with the aim of producing complicated three-dimensional tissues [142-145]. For instance,
micropatterned dual thermo-responsive surfaces that enable the culture and recovery of patterned
heterotopic cell sheets were proposed [142,143].
Okano and co-workers have shown that it is possible to obtain cell sheet constructs with five layers,
where the viability of the transferred cells and the adequate organization of the functional cell-cell
junctions were demonstrated [144]. Direct transplantations of cell sheets have been already
successfully applied to corneal epithelia, mucosal epithelia, periodontal ligament cells, bladder epithelia
and esophageal epithelia [141]. Cell sheets have also been layered in order to successfully recreate
thicker tissue-like constructs such as cardiac and more recently bone [146].
The LbL approach has also been explored as a potential alternative to the traditional grafting techniques
employed for cell sheet engineering. It was shown that (chitosan-graft-NIPAAm)/alginate LbL films
enabled the attachment and proliferation until confluence of cells at 37ºC and the spontaneous
detachment of cell sheets along with their deposited extracellular matrix by simple temperature
modulation (Figure 4.4) [70]. Thus, these multilayered thermo-responsive surfaces could potentially be
used in cell sheet engineering. The mild conditions and the absence of harmful solvents, the simplicity
of the method and the ability to modulate cellular adhesiveness by controlling the “nanometric”
thickness of the coatings are some of the advantages of this novel strategy. A completely new strategy
for cell culture focusing on the design of three-dimensional smart surfaces by supercritical fluid
technology has also been recently proposed based on supercritical carbon dioxide [147]. This approach
might overcome the limitations on cell expansion and harvesting of currently existing techniques.

4.5 Conclusions
The latest advancements in healthcare have emphasized the need to develop dynamic devices that can
adjust themselves to a specific situation. Although many of these concepts are still under development
in the lab bench, substrates modified with stimuli-responsive properties have already been proposed for
controlling the adhesion of cells or proteins, microfluidics and biosensors.
From the literature, it is clear that such advances are owed to the variety of methods that one can use
to modify an interface and to the wide array of materials that can be used to build it. Thus substrates
that respond to distinct physical, chemical and biochemical stimuli can be made with potential for new
cutting-edge applications in biology and biotechnology. In the next decade, we expect to assist to the
rise of dynamic smart systems with new designs and complexity moving further into the third dimension.
Switchable surfaces exhibiting alternating biological active signals will be used to develop new cell
culture protocols. Substrates with dynamic molecular conformation upon the contact with a specific
biochemical agent will be used as biosensors for rapid diagnostic. Stimuli-responsive interfaces built
onto drug reservoirs will be further optimized to tune and control better the release of encapsulated
therapeutic molecules. With such nature, smart surfaces offer opportunities for a wide array of
applications in medicine and tissue engineering where an interface with switchable properties is needed.

Chapter 5. Materials and methods
Many of the materials used in this thesis – both polymeric constituents and reactives – were either
purchased or obtained by biological processes. The detailed specifications of the suppliers can be found
in the experimental subsections of each chapter of Section III. Likewise, equipment suppliers are also
discriminated in those subsections.
5.1 Materials
5.1.1 Polysaccharides
Several polysaccharides were used for the conception of multiple layer-by-layer (LbL) constructs.
Namely, chitosan (CHI) was used in every experimental work, throughout chapters 6 to 11. CHI is a
biodegradable linear polysaccharide composed of randomly distributed N -D-glucosamine and N -
acetyl-D-glucosamine, linked by ?-(1-4) glycosidic bonds (Figure 5.1a). It is obtained by partial
deacetylation of chitin – which is found in the exoskeleton of shellfish, like shrimp and crabs – in the
solid state under strong alkaline conditions or by enzymatic hydrolysis in the presence of a chitin
deacetylase. In this process, named N - deacetylation, the acetyl functional groups of chitin are removed.
Conventionally, the compound is called “chitosan” when the degree of deacetylation of chitin reaches
about 50%. CHI undergoes a conformational transition in solution around a pH value of 6. Its amine
groups, as is characteristic of polybases, are protonated at pH below the pKa and deprotonated at
higher pH values [1-3].
Levan is a linear ?-(2-6)-linked fructose polymer (fructan) exhibiting hydroxyl groups that form strong
adhesive bonds with various substrates (Figure 5.1b). This polymer – which was used along CHI in
Chapter 6 – can be produced by almost every fructan synthesizers: one particular example is levan
produced by extremophilic and halophilic bacteria Halomonas smyrnensis (Figure 5.2). They are found
in highly saline environments to provide adhesion and protection. The fact that superior
bioadhesiveness can be achieved under such harsh conditions points to the excellent adhesive
properties that levan and its derivatives can provide. In comparison to petrochemically-derived
adhesives, levan is biodegradable, biocompatible, nonallergic, nontoxic and water-soluble, useful
properties for high-value biomedical applications [4-6].
Chapter 5. Materials and methods
174
Occasionally, alginate (ALG) was also used as a multilayer constituent, in Chapters 6, 7 and 11. ALG is
a linear anionic copolymer composed of two monomers: ?-D-mannuronic acid, ?-L-guluronic acid
(Figure 5.1c). It can be obtained from the cellular wall, accounting for up to 45% of the dry weight of
these seaweeds. ALG has stimuli-responsiveness toward pH. The carboxylic acid groups from the
guluronate and mannuronate monomers can be deprotonated above pH values of 3.2 and 4,
respectively. Thus, alginate behaves as polyacid and exhibits polyanionic behavior above these pKa
values [7-10]. ALG and also CHI, which share a marine origin, both show biocompatibility, adhesiveness,
nontoxicity, as well as bacteriostatic, fungistatic, antimicrobial and hemostatic activities [10-12]. These
properties make of these polysaccharides suitable constituents for multilayer formulations that resort to
natural materials.

All materials used in the present thesis were bought from specialized commercial distributors. Among
the purchased materials were CHI and ALG: medium molecular weight chitosan (Brookshield viscosity
200-800 cP, molecular weight 190-310 kDa) and alginic acid sodium salt from brown algae (molecular
weight 100-200 kDa). The sodium salt group enabled ALG to solubilize in water more easily, in
comparison to its unmodified form. Levan was obtained by biological processes, as described below.
Chitosan as-received often contains impurities and debris resulting from the deacetylation process of
chitin and requires a purification procedure. Purification of CHI exploits the fact that it undergoes a
conformational transition in solution around a pH value around 6, making it soluble below this value
and precipitate above it. For purification a method described by Signini and Filho [13] was adapted. A
CHI solution at 1% (w/v) using acetic acid at 1% (v/v) as solvent was prepared. The solution was
vacuum-filtered twice through filter papers with 20–25 ?m of pore size, to remove impurities. The
filtered solution was neutralized using sodium hydroxide (NaOH) at a molar concentration of 1 M and
was added drop-wise until pH was 8. The precipitated chitosan was then repeatedly rinsed in distilled
water until the pH of the residual waters meets the same value of distilled water (around pH 7). CHI
was rinsed with ethanol, vacuum-filtered and stored at -80 ºC before being lyophilized.

5.1.1.2 Levan phosphonate modification
Levan as-produced does not possess groups exhibiting electrostatic charge. For the purpose of
producing multilayer films with CHI driven by electrostatic interactions, phosphonate groups were
introduced in the structure of levan. This way, it was expected that the introduced groups provided
negative charge for interaction with the polycationic CHI. For the production of phosphonated levan
(Ph-levan), 4 g of levan was dissolved in 100 mL of pyridine by vigorously mixing on a magnetic stirrer
for 48 hours at ambient conditions and then the solution was cooled down to 0ºC. In an ice bath, 4 mL
of phosphorus trichloride (PCl3) was added slowly in a drop-wise manner to the well-stirred solution.
After stirring for 30 min under ambient conditions, 100 mL of saturated sodium carbonate (Na2CO3)
was added. The aqueous phase containing the modified polymer was separated and freed from pyridine,
and then subjected to dialysis against distilled water for at least 4 consecutive days with frequent
exchanges of the solvent (3–5 times per day). The polymer was freeze-dried and an overall recovery
yield of about 50% was achieved.
5.1.2 ELR expression and purification
Elastin-like recombinamers are genetically-engineered polypeptides that can exhibit precise amino acid
length and sequence, and stimuli-responsiveness toward external stimuli, such as temperature, pH,
ionic strength, and some toward light. An exhaustive description of elastin-like macromolecules has
already been provided in Section I, as Chapter 3.
From Chapter 7 to Chapter 11, ELRs were used as one of the constituents of the multilayer films and
coatings. Expression conditions and purification protocols were adapted from Meyer and Chilkoti [15]
and Girotti et al. [16]. ELRs were obtained by the induced gene expression from a stock of recombinant
Escherichia coli strains containing the desired expressing gene. This stock of recombinant bacteria had
been previously obtained. The artificial nature of ELRs means that it is necessary to design and
synthesize their genes de novo in order to obtain them. It is impossible to obtain a complete synthetic
gene, through an approach involving genetic engineering. The repetitive structure of recombinamers
implies that a monomer deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) segment or “monomeric gene” encoding a
specific polypeptide sequence can be created and subsequently seamlessly joined independently of the
presence of restriction sites in the target DNA to generate multimerized genes that express the whole
recombinamer. Three strategies can be employed to obtain the polymeric genes. One is
concatemerization method, a random, directional concatenation of the monomeric gene. This method
Chapter 5. Materials and methods
177
allows multimeric genes with a defined distribution and discrete lengths to be obtained in a single
cloning cycle. The other is the iterative-recursive method, which allows complete control of the size and
distribution of the individual blocks that play central roles in formation of the supramolecular structures.
Finally, recursive directional ligation (RDL), an alternative method in which DNA segments with two
different restriction sites flanking the insert are joined in sequential steps, with the length of the ligated
segments growing geometrically in each step (Figure 5.3) [17].

5.1.3 Synthesis of magnetic nanoparticles
For the purpose of constructing LbL-based systems with magnetic response in Chapter 11, magnetic
nanoparticles (MNPs) were first synthesized. MNPs are structures susceptible to magnetic fields, often
used to enhance medical imaging diagnosis of soft tissues (e.g., magnetic resonance imaging, MRI) and
temperature-mediated treatments such as hyperthermia and tissue ablation [19-21]. Their magnetic
responsiveness also allows spatial mobilization/immobilization dependent on the application of a
magnetic field on demand. In a typical synthesis of spherical iron oxide MNPs, 10 mL of a solution
containing 1.2 g of iron(III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3?6H2O) and 0.6 g of iron(II) chloride tetrahydrate
(FeCl2?4H2O) was added drop-wise to 25 mL of ammonium hydroxide solution (NH4OH, made of 33%
ammonia, NH3, in H2O) over 4 h under an inert nitrogen atmosphere. The products of the reaction
were collected by magnetic separation and washed three times with ethanol and water. The last
washing step was made with ethanol, after which the products were left to dry at room temperature.

5.2.2 Phosphonate-levan modification assessment
To assess if the modification of levan into Ph-levan was successful in Chapter 6, two techniques were
used: energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) analysis, for the elemental analysis of phosphorous, and
Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra, by comparing both modified and unmodified levan samples
within wavelength values of 400–4000 cm -1
. EDS is performed using a scanning electron microscope
(SEM) which, besides the morphology and surface of a sample, allows determining its elemental
composition. When the electron beam bombards a sample, X-rays are produced as a result of the
ionization of an atom by high-energy radiation. Consequently, an inner shell electron is removed. To
return an ionized atom to its ground state, an electron from a higher energy outer shell fills the vacant
inner shell and, in the process, releases an amount of energy equal to the potential energy difference
Chapter 5. Materials and methods
181
between the two shells. The excess energy is unique for every atomic transition and allows determining
the atomic element in analysis [24]. In FTIR, infrared radiation passes through a sample: some of this
radiation is absorbed by the sample some of it is transmitted through. The detected infrared spectrum
is the result of transitions between vibrational energy states, which can range from simple coupled
motion of two atoms in a diatomic molecule to a more complex atomic motion in a large polyfunctional
molecule. Thus, it is possible to detect functional groups, for instance, in a modified polymer by
measuring characteristic absorption spectra, in respect to an unmodified sample [25].
5.2.3 Elastin-like recombinamers bioproduction assessment
ELRs used throughout Chapters 7 to 11 were characterized following a multitude of techniques. To
assess that the desired ELR was appropriately synthesized and produced, amino acid composition
analysis and matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF) mass spectroscopy
were used. The amino acid composition was determined according to the AccQTag Waters method and
the derivatized amino acids analyzed by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). In general,
an ideal derivatizing reagent must consist of an appropriate reactive group and a strong fluorophore.
Typically, the protocol of the manufacturer requires the use of 6-aminoquinolyl-N -hydroxysuccinimidyl
carbamate to react with primary and secondary amines to produce unsymmetrical urea derivatives that
are highly fluorescent. Such conjugates can be separated in chromatographic columns and be detected
sensitively using ultraviolet fluorescence detectors [26,27]. MALDI-TOF mass spectroscopy was used to
determine the molecular weight of the produced ELRs. In MALDI-TOF, proteins are liberated in an
ionized form from a target surface by firing a laser pulse at crystallized proteins. The ionized proteins
are accelerated through a vacuum tube by an electrical field and reach a detector. Smaller proteins are
accelerated to higher velocities than heavier proteins, and the “time-of-flight” is proportional to “m/z”.
The charge “z” of ionized proteins is often 1, making the m/z value equal to the mass value [28].
5.2.4 Magnetization of MNPs
Magnetic particles can be classified as ferromagnetic and paramagnetic/superparamagnetic. Whereas
the former exhibit a permanent magnetic dipole moment, with a paramagnetic particle a magnetic
dipole moment is induced only when an external magnetic field is applied [29-32]. The magnetization of
the MNPs was therefore measured as a function of an applied external magnetic field. Typically, a
vibrating sample magnetometer is used, which is capable of generating a magnetic field and detect the
magnetization exhibited by a tested material.

5.2.5 Measurement of charges
The charge exhibited by each polymer in aqueous solution was determined by the measurement of zeta
(?)-potentials using laser Doppler electrophoresis. When a solid surface is in contact with an aqueous
solution, the formation of an interfacial charge causes a rearrangement of the local free ions in the
solution to produce a thin region of nonzero net charge density near the interface. The arrangement of
the charges at the solid-liquid interface and the balancing counter-ions in the liquid is usually referred to
as the electrical double layer. This region consists in a thin layer of counter-ions immediately next to the
charged solid surface, called the compact layer, or Stern layer. The counter-ions in the compact layer
are immobile due to the strong electrostatic attraction, while counter-ions outside the compact layer are
mobile. This last part of the electrical double layer is called the diffuse layer. The ?-potential is the
electrostatic potential at the boundary dividing the compact layer and the diffuse layer [34]. This
potential may depend on the polymer concentration, pH and ionic strength. Thus, solutions of each
polymeric material were prepared considering one of two situations: (i) the conditions that would be
used afterwards for the construction of the LbL films and coatings, in an attempt to relate both charge
and successful or unsuccessful multilayer construction, or (ii) the conditions in which the developed
coatings are placed after their construction, to determine their behavior at, e.g., physiological conditions.

and to a reference sample while they are subjected to a controlled temperature program. It provides
direct, model-independent determinations of the transition properties, such as enthalpy, entropy, and
transition temperature, and is an appropriate technique to study the inverse temperature transition of
ELRs [35,36]. Experiments were performed with water solutions of 3K-VRGDV at 50 mg?mL -1

5.3 Assessment of LbL films’ growth
5.3.1 In situ monitoring
In order to determine if a set of ingredients can be used to construct multilayer films and coatings, a
quartz-crystal microbalance with dissipation monitoring (QCM-D) was used in Chapters 6, 7 and 8, a
technique that is able to detect adsorbed surface density changes in the order of ng.cm -2
and measure
the viscoelastic properties of the resulting surface in real time. In this technique, a sensor is composed
of a thin AT-cut quartz disk sandwiched between a pair of electrodes. Quartz allows exploiting the
piezoelectric which makes it possible to convert an electric AC voltage across its electrodes into
mechanical motion, exciting the quartz to oscillation at a fundamental frequency of 5 MHz. Therefore,
the use of quartz sensors for QCM requires the use of “chips” that are coated by the electrode material,
which can be one of a number of metals but being gold the one mostly used. An AT-cut quartz crystal
can be excited at its fundamental frequency (5 MHz) and at several overtones: 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11 and 13,
corresponding respectively to 5, 15, 25, 35, 45, 55 and 65 MHz, although different overtones can be
monitored, depending on the equipment’s supplier. When a thin film is deposited onto the sensor
crystal the frequency decreases. If the film is thin and rigid, the decrease in frequency (?F) is
proportional to the mass of the film. However, when using polymers, the adsorbed film is not rigid and
this relation is not valid. At the same time, monitoring of ?D gives an indirect indication of the film’s
viscoelastic properties. An increase in ?D represents a shift towards a film with a higher viscous
component and damping properties typical of “soft” polymeric LbL films. The dissipation values for a
soft film are higher due to increased energy loss from the crystal, whereas smaller dissipation values

5.4 Assembly and characterization of multilayer films
5.4.1 In planar substrates
After determining if a set of constituents provided a favorable multilayer construction, they were
reproduced outside of the QCM-D. Hybrid multilayer films based on the diverse polymeric materials
used herein were constructed by dipping alternately glass substrates into the polyelectrolyte solutions
for 10 min, with an intermediate rinsing step of 5 (Chapter 6) or 10 min (Chapter 7 - Appendix and
Chapter 8) in NaCl 0.15 M. In similarity to most metallic alloys, glass is negatively charged, and thus
provided support for the formation of a multilayer coating by adsorbing CHI as a polycation primer
layer [47].
In Chapter 6, fresh CHI and Ph-levan polyelectrolyte solutions were prepared (1 mg?mL -1
, 0.15 M NaCl,
pH 5.5). Commercial glass from a local store were acquired and cut into 100×20 mm 2 slides and
cleaned thoroughly by immersion in a sequence of absolute ethanol, 2-propanol and chromosulfuric
acid for 24 h. The construction was assisted by an in-house developed dipping robot that allowed the
automated assembly of each layer in a programmed manner. The construction proceeded until 100
layers (50 bilayers) were adsorbed. Films consisting of CHI and ALG were produced in parallel under
the same experimental conditions for control purposes. In Chapter 7 – Appendix, films of CHI and
either HAP3 or H3A20H3 were assembled onto glass pieces (1 cm 2 ). The number of CHI/HAP3 and
CHI/ H3A20H3 bilayers assembled was defined based on the results from the QCM-D screening stage.
In Chapter 8, five pairs of CHI and ELR-RGD were prepared by manual dipping at the surface of regular
glass microscopy slides cut into 1 cm 2 pieces after undergoing a cleaning stage with acetone, absolute
ethanol and 2-propanol.

5.4.1.2 Contact angle measurements
The wettability of a surface can be quantified by the measurement of contact angles. The contact angle
of a liquid drop on a solid surface is the angle at which a liquid/vapor interface meets a solid surface. It
is defined by the mechanical equilibrium of the drop under the action of three interfacial tensions and
Chapter 5. Materials and methods
188
allows quantifying the wettability of a solid surface by a liquid via the Young equation. Surfaces with high
energy typically exhibit a low contact angle, whereas hydrophobic surfaces exhibit low surface
energy [49].
In Chapter 7 – Appendix, PBS-contact angles were measured for coatings of CHI/HAP3 and
CHI/H3A20H3 at 4 and 50ºC. The number of layers was defined based on the results from the QCM-D.
The coatings were immersed in PBS placed under each temperature condition. After periods of 10 min
of immersion in each temperature condition, the samples were withdrawn and contact angles were
measured. If wettability did not change significantly, the samples were placed in immersion for an
additional period of 10 min at the same temperature.
In Chapter 8, coatings up to 10 layers – 5 pairs of CHI and 3K-VRGDV – were characterized for their
wettability for each layer assembled using the sessile drop method, at 37ºC and pH 7.4. These
measurement conditions were chosen to simulate the behavior of the films under physiological
conditions of temperature and pH for each assembled pH. An approach described by Park et al. [50]
was used to measure contact angles dependent on several temperature, pH and ionic strength
conditions: the samples were immersed in a beaker of PBS placed under each condition. After 1 hour,
the samples were withdrawn and contact angles were measured (Figure 5.7). The time of 1 h was
determined to be enough to have a stable surface. Therefore, measurements were performed for a pH
range from 4 to 12, ionic strength from 0 to 1.5 M of NaCl, and three relevant temperatures: 25, 37
and 50ºC. Upon determining the wettability transition parameters, three cycles were performed by
changing the transition values above and below each transition value.

5.4.1.3 Surface topography
Atomic force microscopy (AFM) measurements were performed in LbL-coated glass slides cut into
pieces of 1×1 cm 2 , in Chapter 7 – Appendix and Chapter 8, following a similar protocol to that of
contact angle measurements, in both cases scanning an area of 1×1 µm 2 . This technique is a
synthesis of the mechanical profilometer, using mechanical springs to sense forces, and the scanning
tunneling microscopy (STM), using piezoelectric transducers for scanning. In force microscopy, a
probing tip is attached to a cantilever-type spring. In response to the force between tip and sample, the
cantilever is deflected. This deflection is then translated into a visual image [51].
In Chapter 8, 5 pairs of CHI/3K-VRGDV were immersed in PBS for 30 min. To assess the influence of
pH in the coatings, the samples were immersed in PBS at two pH values: 7.4 and 11. To avoid the
formation of crystals during the acquisition, the samples were immersed shortly in ultrapure water for
removing excess of saline solution. The samples were then retrieved and introduced in the device.

In Chapter 7 – Appendix, CHI/monoblock and CHI/triblock samples were immersed in PBS at room

When a multilayer film is rough, viscous and/or thick, AFM may not be appropriate technique to scan
its topography. In these cases, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) – a technique that allows observing
the surface of an object by bombarding it with an electron beam – presents itself as a viable alternative.
SEM was used in Chapter 6 to evaluate the topography of CHI/Ph-levan and CHI/ALG films. The
surfaces to be observed were left to dry overnight at room temperature and sputtered with gold prior to
SEM observations.
5.4.2 In three dimensional substrates
5.4.2.1 Preparation of spherical microparticle templates
Multilayer combinations made of CHI and 3K-VRGDV were extrapolated to the third dimension in the
form of capsules. For this purpose, microparticles of calcium carbonate (CaCO3) served as spherical
templates, which are easily obtained and provide a very simple three-dimensional structure to perform
LbL. Microcapsules made of these constituents were constructed in Chapters 9, 10 and 11. Prior to the
shell assembly, the template microparticles were produced. Typically, aqueous solutions of sodium
Chapter 5. Materials and methods
190
carbonate (Na2CO3) and calcium chloride (CaCl2) were prepared at 1 M. Co-precipitation of both
solutions was performed by adding a volume “V” of Na2CO3 followed by a volume “V” of CaCl2 to a
variable volume of a precipitation medium/bath under rapid stirring for 30 seconds. The volume of the
precipitation medium was of “2V” (Chapters 9 and 11) or “4V” (Chapter 10). Stirring was then stopped
and the suspension of newly synthesized CaCO3 microparticles left to react and precipitate for 15 min.
The supernatant was then removed and the particles washed twice or three times with ultrapure water
to remove residual salts.
The co-precipitation could occur in a precipitation medium that, besides water, contains an agent for
encapsulation. The encapsulation is achieved due to the physical entrapment of such agent in the newly
formed solid microparticles. In Chapter 9, a the entrapment of a “fluorescein isothiocyanate”-tagged
bovine serum albumin (FITC-BSA) entrapment was achieved following the method described by
She et al. [52], by preparing a precipitation medium with a FITC-BSA concentration of 5 mg?mL-1. In
this work, SEM was used to evaluate the morphology of the sacrificial templates. Specimens were pre-
coated with a conductive layer of sputtered gold and micrographs recorded at 10 kV. In Chapter 10,
DQ-ovalbumin was entrapped from a medium at 160 ?g?mL -1
. DQ-ovalbumin is a protein chemically
saturated with BODIPY dyes. The close proximity of the dye molecules causes a self-quenching
mechanism characterized by the exhibition of red fluorescence. However, upon enzymatic degradation,
their proximity is revoked and dye-labeled peptide fragments are released, exhibiting a fluorescence shift
from red to green [53]. It is therefore an excellent agent that can be used to follow cellular uptake and
intracellular traffic by monitoring the changes in the fluorescence emitted. Finally, in Chapter 11, a
precipitation medium containing either rhodamine-B isothiocyanate or MNPs was prepared at
500 ?g?mL -1
using the same method.
5.4.2.2 Construction of the multilayer shells
The templates – either doped or empty – were immersed alternately in CHI and 3K-VRGDV solutions
(300 µg?mL -1
, pH 5.5, 0.15 M of NaCl) for 10 min each, then washed with 0.15 M NaCl (pH 5.5).
Centrifugation was avoided to avoid damage and aggregation of the particles each time the samples
were to be retrieved from solution; simple precipitation of the suspension was used instead (3 to 5 min).
In Chapter 10, where the internalization by cells was to be studied, each adsorption step was followed
by three washing steps with 0.15 M NaCl, pH 5.5, with the first being accompanied by 4 sequential
ultra-sound pulses of 3 seconds each to disaggregate the substrates. This extra step was performed in
order to ensure a more thorough washing, microcapsule separation and therefore avoiding major
Chapter 5. Materials and methods
191
biological shock due to undesired residues and aggregation. This construction process was repeated to
increase the number of bilayers until the desired coating had been obtained. In Chapter 9, the effect of
the number of layers in the multilayer shell permeability was object of study, thus samples with 1, 3
and 5 bilayers were constructed. In Chapters 10 and 11, the coatings were constructed with 2 and 3
bilayers, respectively. After construction, three approaches were followed: (i) in Chapter 9, the CaCO3
core was immediately dissolved with ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA, 0.2 M, pH 5.5), which is a
known chelating agent of metal ions, like calcium ions, and washed twice PBS; (ii) in Chapter 10, the
microcapsules followed a washing procedure with EDTA (0.2 M, pH 7.4) and four with ultrapure water,
with centrifugation at 1000 rpm for 25 min in between and ultrasound pulses timed as described above.
Although centrifugation should ideally be avoided, the extra washing steps to which the microcapsules
were submitted could lead to increased losses in microcapsules’ number. In the case of microcapsules
intended for cellular contact rather than microscopic observations, Dulbecco's modified Eagle medium
(DMEM) was used for the washings instead of water. The result is a batch of hollow multilayer shells
entrapping a desired agent inside. A schematic of this procedure can be found in Figure 5.8; (iii) in
Chapter 11, the coated particles were left intact for the time being to be employed further in the
construction of compartmentalized devices.

solution and the resulting suspension extruded through a 25G needle, at a rate of 0.33 mL?min -1
, into a
0.75% (w/v) solution of CaCl2 under mild stirring. ALG beads containing coated microparticles were

Chi/ALG multilayer shell. They were immersed alternately in CHI and ALG solutions (300 µg?mL -1
, pH

chelated simultaneously with the liquefied alginate bead.

5.4.2.4 Encapsulation losses and pre-loading efficiency
It should be noted that for drug delivery studies in Chapters 9 and 11, described below, all
supernatants were collected during the diverse construction stages of the multilayer microcapsules,
from the synthesis of the sacrificial templates to the chelation stage. This was necessary in order to
calculate the BSA or rhodamine losses during each construction stage and determine the pre-loading
efficiency. 150 ?L of sample was pipetted into a white, opaque 96-well plate in triplicate. Distilled water
was used as blank. The excitation (?exc) and emission (?em) wavelengths used for the calibration curve
and FITC-BSA mass calculations were 485 and 528 nm, respectively. All supernatants collected during
entrapment, construction and chelation were measured and quantified. The percentage of FITC-BSA
mass lost was plotted both for each stage and cumulatively. The encapsulation efficiency was
calculated by subtracting the cumulative losses of each architecture (i.e., microcapsules with distinct
number of layers) from the initial FITC-BSA mass. A similar approach was followed for rhodamine, for
which the excitation (?exc) and emission (?em) wavelengths were 530 and 590 nm, respectively.

5.6 Mechanical resistance of compartmental units
A centrifugal rotation test was performed with the samples suspended in PBS to measure the
mechanical resistance of the (CHI/ALG)3 macrocapsules (Chapter 11). 100 samples were placed in
centrifuge tubes and rotated at a starting centrifugal load of 500g. After 5 min, the number of intact
beads was counted. Those that remained intact were submitted to incremental centrifugal loads (500g
incremental steps) up to a maximum of 5000g. This experiment was performed three times.
5.7 Magnetic responsiveness assays
Macrocapsules containing MNP-loaded microcapsules were suspended in a PBS-filled square
polystyrene Petri dish placed upon a 1×1 cm 2 grid (Chapter 11). A 1.3 T permanent neodymium
Chapter 5. Materials and methods
196
(NdFeB) bar magnet (diameter: 4 mm; length: 2.5 cm) was used to apply the external magnetic field.
Ten samples were placed 3 cm away from the magnet, with the latter placed at a height of 1.4 cm from
the PBS surface. The movement was recorded on video and the mean normalized distance traversed by
the samples plotted as a function of time.
5.8 In vitro biological studies
5.8.1 Cell seeding
The biological response of cells to biomaterials in vitro is critical to estimate if a harmful reaction is
triggered upon contact of a newly developed system with a living organism, common when biomedical
applications are envisaged. Herein, cells were either seeded onto a substrate modified with multilayers,
or seeded first onto a cell culture support and incubated in the presence of microcapsules in
suspension in the culture medium.
In Chapter 6, L929 cells – a murine fibroblast cell line – were routinely cultured with DMEM
supplemented with 3.7 g?L -1
sodium bicarbonate, 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1%
penicillin-streptomycin at pH 7.4. Cells were grown in 75 cm 2 tissue culture flasks and incubated at

added. At 90% of confluence, L929 cells were washed with PBS and subsequently detached by
trypsin-EDTA at 37ºC. To inactivate the trypsin effect, cell culture medium was added. Cells were then

V

5.8.5 Alkaline phosphatase assays
The activity of alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is evaluated using a p-nitrophenol assay. Paranitrophenyl
phosphate, which is colorless, is hydrolysed by alkaline phosphatase at pH 10.5 and 37ºC to form free
paranitrophenol, which is colored yellow. The expression of the enzyme ALP by osteoblasts, whether in
a membrane form or in secretory form, is a characteristic of these cells and therefore its expression can
be a strong indicator of these cells in culture [63]. For alkaline phosphatase (ALP) assays, samples
collected on each time point were washed with PBS and immersed in 1 mL of ultra-pure water to lyse
the cells. To each well of a 96-well plate were added 20 µL of sample plus 60 µL of substrate solution
(0.2% (w/v) p-nytrophenyl (pNP) phosphate/1 M diethanolamine hydrochloric acid (HCl), at pH 9.8).
The plate was then incubated in the dark for 45 min at 37ºC. After the incubation period, 80 µl of a
stop solution (2 M sodium hydroxide (NaOH)/0.2 mM ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA)), was
added to each well. The absorbance was then measured at 405 nm using p-nitrophenol as standard.
For each experiment, a standard curve was constructed from reference suspensions at known cell
concentrations. Values reported reflect means±standard deviation (SD) of three independent
experiments, and analyzed using t-student test. All results were considered to be statistically significant
at p-value less than 0.05.

Chapter 6. Adhesive nanostructured multilayer films using a
bacterial exopolysaccharide for biomedical applications 5
Abstract
Medical adhesives and sealants often require that long-term adhesiveness is achieved. In this work,
nanostructured coatings consisting of chitosan and the adhesive bacterial exopolysaccharide levan are
fabricated using layer-by-layer (LbL) assembly. Taking advantage of the electrostatic self-assembly
mechanism of LbL, the charges of both chitosan and a phosphonate-derivatized levan (Ph-levan) are
measured and the feasibility to construct hybrid films is monitored and confirmed using a quartz crystal
microbalance with dissipation monitoring (QCM-D). The adhesive properties between two identical
bonded films with a total of 100 layers are compared to control films in which Ph-levan is replaced by
alginate, revealing that the detachment force of the former is about 3 times higher than the control.
Scanning electron microscopy of the films surface shows that the surface of Ph-levan films is smooth
and homogeneous. Cell adhesion tests were conducted using a L929 cell line. Early cell adhesion is
significantly higher in chitosan/Ph-levan films when compared to chitosan/alginate controls. These
findings establish levan derivatives as bioinspired ingredients for conceiving medical adhesive devices
that allow achieving enhanced mechanical and biological performance.
