8.1 Introduction
The modification of surfaces has been a key aspect in biology and biotechnology, including cell
expansion, biomaterials development and preparation of substrates for regenerative medicine) [1-3]. In
the field of implantable devices, the surface is the first contact with the organism and dictates the
subsequent biological events, namely the cellular behavior and biointegration. Thus, surface
engineering is of the utmost significance to lead to the conception of devices with an improved
biological performance [4-6].
Surface modification has been also implemented to produce stimuli-responsive surfaces for a variety of
applications, including in biomineralization control [7], cell sheet engineering [8,9], surfaces with
extreme wettabililty transitions [10], and microfluidics [11], mostly based on variations of the hydration
state of polymeric films deposited at the surfaces. Usually, the modification is performed by grafting
stimuli-responsive polymers onto a substrate, which are typically synthetic and nonbiodegradable, such
as poly(N -isopropylacrylamide) (PNIPAAm) [12]. A good example of the latter is the work developed by
Okano et al. [9] regarding cell-sheet engineering.
In more recent years, emphasis has been given to non-harmful and versatile techniques to modify
polymeric substrates: the sequential adsorption of proteins and polysaccharides, known as layer-by-
layer (LbL) adsorption, is one of the most promising today. The principle behind LbL adsorption lies in
the existence of multiple intermolecular interactions, such as electrostatic contacts, hydrophobic
interactions, and hydrogen bonding, where the cooperative effects of multipoint attractions play the
most important role. It is a simple and versatile technique which allows producing robust coatings, even
in substrates with complex geometries; because it discards the need of organic and harmful solvents, it
is an attractive technique for tissue engineering applications [13-15]. Multilayer systems have already
been proposed for different biomedical applications, including for biomimetic composite-like coatings, to
control the release of drugs, or to manipulate the adhesion, differentiation, proliferation and even
function of attached cells [16-19].
In this work, we plan to conceive coatings using natural and nature-inspired macromolecules in a
multilayered fashion using the LbL approach at mild processing conditions. Natural materials are
intricate and multifunctional structures that often inspire scientists to design novel classes of
materials [20]. It is the case of elastin-like recombinamers (ELRs), also designated as elastin-like
polymers (ELPs). This family of peptide-based polymers was developed by Urry, relying in genetic
Chapter 8. Layer-by-layer assembly of chitosan and recombinant biopolymers into biomimetic coatings
with multiple stimuli-responsive properties
286
engineering techniques, and have their basic structure rooted in elastin, the extracellular elastic protein
of higher animals [21-23]. In aqueous environment they are known to have self-assembly behavior and
exhibit a transition temperature (Tt): below Tt, the free polymer chains adopt random coil
conformations; above it, they fold into an organized structure known as ?-spiral. Although ELRs respond
primarily to temperature, the effects of other stimuli, such as pH, ionic strength and concentration, also
affect the transition phenomenon [24]. Their recombinant nature is one of their attractive properties
because it allows tuning their physicochemical properties and introducing sequences to extend their
functionality, including biologically relevant domains [25,26]. The work of Girotti et al. [27], who were
able to biosynthesize an extracellular matrix analogue enclosing the cell attachment sequence arginine-
(glutamic acid)-(aspartic acid)-valine (REDV), is an example of such versatility. Thus, ELRs are an
attractive option over the most commonly used formulations in LbL adsorption.
Swierczewska et al. [28] have previously reported the use of ELRs for LbL thin films. However, the
peptides were modified and conjugated with either poly(ethyleneimine) (PEI) or poly(acrylic acid) (PAA)
to provide positive or negative charge, respectively. Our groups have also shown that ELRs can be
successfully combined with polysaccharides to conceive coatings and some may even be applied using
a multilayer approach [29,30]. In order to explore the potential of ELR properties and the advantages of
LbL, we intend to conceive nanostructured thin coatings made from the sequential adsorption of a
polysaccharide and an ELR modified with the arginine-glycine-(aspartic acid) (RGD) cell adhesion motif,
labeled ELR-RGD. RGD is expected to increase the cell adhesion in vitro and prove useful in the design
of devices with tunable cell attachment or even improved host integration. We selected chitosan (CHI)
because, besides being a well-known biocompatible material, it is one of the few polysaccharides
exhibiting positive charge (at acidic conditions), is abundant, and its production is environmentally
safe [31,32].
The proposed system will also allow expanding the concept of multilayered films to a new attractive
class of peptide-based polymers, making them more robust than simple monolayers, and could bring
new possibilities in the development of nanostructured coatings of materials in tissue engineering. The
buildup of the multilayers will be monitored in real time using a quartz-crystal microbalance with
dissipation monitoring (QCM-D). Distinct techniques, such as contact angle measurements, atomic
force microscopy (AFM), and cell adhesion tests will be used to characterize it. We hypothesize that
coatings containing this ELR may exhibit changes both in topography and wettability, depending on
Chapter 8. Layer-by-layer assembly of chitosan and recombinant biopolymers into biomimetic coatings
with multiple stimuli-responsive properties
287
several stimuli, namely temperature, pH and ionic strength, and improved biological in vitro
performance.
8.2 Experimental section
8.2.1 ELR-RGD expression and purification
The featured ELR monomers of RGD were designated as ELR-RGD. Expression conditions and
purification protocols were adapted from Meyer and Chilkoti [33] and Girotti et al. [34]. Gene expression
of a recombinant Escherichia coli strain BLR(DE3) containing the expressing gene of ELR-RGD was
induced in a 12 L Applikon fermenter, in terrific broth medium (TB) with 0.1% of carbenicilin and 0.1%
of glucose, under controlled conditions of temperature (37ºC) and pH (7.00). The fermentation was
stopped after registering an optical density variation at 600 nm inferior to 0.25, in a time-frame of 1 h.
Subsequent to fermentation, the culture was harvested by centrifugation, resuspended and lysed by
ultrasonic disruption. Insoluble debris was removed by centrifugation and the cleared lysate was
subjected to several cycles of cold and warm centrifugations, of 4 and 40ºC, respectively. All the
purification steps were carried out in a sodium chloride (NaCl) solution at 0.5 M. The polymer in
solution was then frozen at -24ºC and freeze-dried.
8.2.2 ELR-RGD characterization
Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC) experiments were performed on a Mettler Toledo 822e (United
States) with a liquid nitrogen cooler accessory. Both temperature and enthalpy were calibrated with an
indium standard at the same experimental conditions used for the studied materials. Water solutions of
ELR-RGD at 50 mg?mL -1
were prepared at pH 7.4. In a typical DSC run, 20 ?L of the solution were
placed inside a standard 40 ?L aluminum pan hermetically sealed. The same volume of water was
placed in the reference pan. All samples were equilibrated for 5 minutes at 5°C inside the sample
chamber just before the beginning of each experiment. A heating rate of 5ºC?min -1
was used. To assess
the biopolymer molecular weight, matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF)
mass spectroscopy was performed in a Voyager STR, from Applied Biosystems, in linear mode and with
an external calibration using bovine serum albumin (BSA). Amino acid composition determination was
previously used to assess the composition of ELRs [27].

with multiple stimuli-responsive properties

8.2.3 Buildup and characterization of the self-assembled coatings
Medium molecular weight grade CHI was purchased from Sigma and purified. Solutions of purified CHI
and ELR-RGD were prepared at 0.1 mg?mL -1
in 0.15 M NaCl. The pH of the solutions was adjusted to
5.5. ?-potential of each solution was determined using a Nano-ZS from Malvern (United Kingdom), at
25ºC. A Q-Sense E4 quartz-crystal microbalance (Q-Sense AB, Sweden) with dissipation monitoring
system was used for monitoring in situ the deposition of CHI/ELR-RGD multilayers at the surface of
gold-coated crystals. This technique has previously been extensively described [35-37]. Very briefly, an
AT cut quartz crystal can be excited at its fundamental frequency (5 MHz) and at several overtones: 25,
35, and 45 MHz (fifth, seventh, and ninth overtones, respectively). When a thin film is deposited onto
the sensor crystal the frequency decreases. If the film is thin and rigid the decrease in frequency (?F) is
proportional to the mass of the film. However, when using polymers, the adsorbed film is not rigid and
this relation is not valid: the film begins dissipating energy and exhibiting the typical viscoelastic
behavior, which is evident by the change in the dissipation (?D). The crystals were first cleaned in an
ultrasound bath at 30ºC, and immersed successively in acetone, ethanol, and isopropanol. Adsorption
took place at 25ºC and pH 5.5 and at a constant flow rate of 50 mL?min -1
. Starting with the CHI
solution, each one was pumped into the system for 10 minutes. Each deposition cycle was followed by
a rinsing step with 0.15 M NaCl, at pH 5.5, for 10 min, and ?F? and ?D were monitored in real time.
The frequency of each overtone was normalized to the fundamental resonant frequency of the quartz
crystal, by diving it by ? (where ?=5; 7; 9). The thickness of the films was estimated using the Voigt
model through the Q-Tools software, from Q-Sense [38]. The area density was calculated by multiplying
the thickness by the layer density (1200 kg.m -3
led to obtaining calculations with the best fitting).
8.2.4 Contact-angle measurements
Phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) contact angles were measured in a DataPhysics OCA15 system. The
coatings were prepared at the surface of regular glass microscopy slides, from Marienfeld (Germany).
The glass was cleaned using the same protocol to which QCM-D crystals were submitted. Coatings up
to 10 layers – 5 pairs of CHI and ELR-RGD – were characterized for their wettability for each layer
assembled, at 37ºC and pH 7.4. An approach described by Park et al. [39] was used to measure
contact angles dependent on several temperature, pH and ionic strength conditions. The
measurements were performed for a pH range from 4 to 12, ionic strength from 0 to 1.5 M of NaCl,

with multiple stimuli-responsive properties
289
and three relevant temperatures: 25, 37 and 50ºC. The samples were immersed in a beaker of PBS
placed under each condition. After 1 hour, the samples were withdrawn and contact angles were
measured. The time of 1 h was determined to be enough to have a stable surface. Upon determining
the wettability transition parameters, three cycles were performed by changing the transition values
above and below each transition value.
8.2.5 Atomic force microscopy measurements
AFM measurements were performed in a MultiMode STM microscope controlled by the NanoScope III
from Digital Instruments system, operating in tapping mode at a frequency of 1 Hz. Glass slides were
cut into pieces of 1×1 cm 2 and used as substrates for multilayer adsorption. Surfaces coated with 5
pairs of CHI/ELR-RGD were immersed in PBS for 30 min. To assess the influence of pH in the coatings,
a similar protocol to the contact angle measurements was followed. The samples were immersed in
PBS at two pH values: 7.4 and 11. To avoid the formation of crystals during the acquisition, the
samples were immersed shortly in ultrapure water for removing excess of saline solution. The samples
were then retrieved and introduced in the device. The analyzed area was 1×1 µm 2 .
8.2.6 Cell culture studies of SaOs-2 osteoblast-like cells
Cell studies were performed onto coatings of 5 pairs of layers, ending in ELR-RGD, CHI or ELR-RDG (-)
(negative control), assembled at the surface of glass coverslips with 1 cm of diameter. Tissue culture
polystyrene (TCPS) was used as a positive control. Cell adhesion was studied using the SaOs-2
osteoblast-like osteosarcoma cell line. Cells were seeded on the surfaces (5×10 4 cell?mL
-1 ) and
incubated in serum free Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM), loaded with 1%
antibiotics/antimicotics at 37ºC, 5% carbon dioxide (CO2). The substrates were analyzed at different
time points: 4 h, 24 h and 3 days. At each time point, cells on the coated surfaces were washed with
PBS twice, fixed in formalin (3.7%) and nuclei of the cells stained with 4',6 diamidino-2-phenylindol
(DAPI), and the actin was stained with phalloidin.
For alkaline phosphatase (ALP) assays, samples collected on each time point were washed with PBS
and immersed in 1 mL of ultra-pure water to lyse the cells. To each well of a 96-well plate were added
20 µL of sample plus 60 µL of substrate solution (0.2% (w/v) p-nytrophenyl (pNP) phosphate/1 M
diethanolamine hydrochloric acid (HCl), at pH 9.8). The plate was then incubated in the dark for 45 min

with multiple stimuli-responsive properties

at 37ºC. After the incubation period, 80 µl of a stop solution (2 M sodium hydroxide (NaOH)/0.2 mM
ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA)), was added to each well. The absorbance was then measured
at 405 nm using p-nitrophenol as standard. For each experiment, a standard curve was constructed
from reference suspensions at known cell concentrations. To access cell viability, (3-(4,5-
dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-5-(3-carboxymethoxyphenyl)-2-(4-sulfophenyl)-2H-tetrazolium) (MTS) assay was
performed. MTS is bioreduced by cells. The values for absorbance of this reduced product at 490 nm
are directly proportional to the number of living cells in the substrates.
8.3 Results and discussion
8.3.1 ELR-RGD characterization
For the past two decades, much work has been done on the widely investigated poly(styrene
sulfonate)/poly(allylamine hydrochloride) (PSS/PAH) system – considered so far as a model of
multilayered thin films – and CHI/hyaluronan [16]. However, the buildup mechanism is not always
straightforward to every material and distinct or several forces may influence the construction [40,41].
Furthermore, coatings for tissue engineering applications should ideally contain other materials with
more relevant features, including biological activity. It is the case of the biopolymer used in this work,
which contains the RGD cell adhesion motif, depicted in Figure 8.1a.
The ELR-RGD, with 371 aminoacids and theoretical molecular weight of 31371 Da, contains 2
monomers of RGD, 2 aspartic acids, and 3 lysines isolated at the amino-terminal and exhibits a Tt of
around 23ºC in solution at physiological pH (data not shown). In contrast to our previous work [30], this
ELR-RGD was engineered to facilitate electrostatic interactions during the multilayer buildup. In Figure
8.1b, MALDI-TOF spectrum shows a high intensity peak at 31229 Da, which is approximate to the
theoretical value for this biopolymer.
In order to confirm if the produced ELR matched the theoretical amino acidic composition, peptide
sequencing tests were performed. In Table 8.1, it can be confirmed that the produced biopolymer
composition matches well the predicted amino acid composition. These results point to the
bioproduction of a stock of ELR-RGD retaining the desired amino acid sequence.

8.3.1 Analysis of CHI/ELR-RGD film buildup

At the working pH of 5.5, we relied on the protonation state of the ELR-RGD aspartic acids: under such
conditions, these residues are deprotonated and negatively charged (pKa ranging from 3.0–4.7) [43].
This would allow them to interact by electrostatic self-assembly (ESA) with the positively charged amine

with multiple stimuli-responsive properties
293
groups of CHI. Prior to the monitoring, the ?-potential of CHI and ELR-RGD solutions was measured at
working conditions (pH=5.5 and ionic strength at 0.15 M), showing a charge of +17.0±0.6
and -8.4±0.33 mV, respectively. ELRs are essentially hydrophobic by nature but can be modified to
include specific charged residues. CHI is also insoluble in water and can only be dissolved at acidic
conditions, below its pKa (approximately 6) [44]. It has been reported that electrostatic deposition
demands appropriate matching of the charge density of the used polyelectrolyte pair, rather than a
minimum charge density [13,45], but in this case the ?-potential showed no charge balance (i.e. equal
absolute values). Although ESA was a driving force of construction, other forces, like hydrophobic
interactions, are likely to participate on the assembling phenomenon. In fact, Figure 8.2a shows the
successful combination of the used pair, at the assembly pH of 5.5, near the pKa of CHI. We can
assume that a fraction of already deprotonated amine groups interacts with the hydrophobic residues of
the ELR-RGD structure and allow the construction of the coating.
The QCM-D data was used to estimate the thickness variations of the film along with the adsorption
cycles. Figure 8.2b shows the results calculated using the Voigt model implemented in the Q-Tools
software from Q-Sense [38]. It can be observed that the thickness increased linearly during the buildup,
in accordance with the evolution of ?F? and ?D variations. After the deposition of 20 layers, the film
had a thickness of 81 nm, corresponding to an approximate total area density of 9.6 µg.cm -2
(multiplication of thickness by the layer density. 1200 kg.m -3
allowed for the best fitting). Figure 8.2b
also shows the thickness of each layer (“thickness increase” in the graphic). Overall, the increase of
thickness is higher for the adsorption steps of ELR-RGD. This is the result of the lower charged exhibited
by the recombinamer, which requires that more material is needed to overcompensate the charges of
the underlying CHI ones. The results obtained through QCM-D measurements demonstrate that ELR-
RGD can be used successfully with CHI to conceive a viscoelastic polymeric coating using the LbL
approach.
8.3.2 Characterization of the self-assembled coatings
When a material adheres to a substrate, it is expected that such phenomenon will result in
physicochemical changes at the surface [46,47]. The measurement of contact angles is an easy
method that allows a quick assessment of the modification of a surface in terms of wettability, and its
usefulness is even higher when such wettability is significantly different for each layer. Figure 8.3 shows
the contact angle variation of the CHI/ELR-RGD film with the buildup, up to 10 layers.

The films were adsorbed onto glass (contact angle of 28.6±2.9º). Each measurement was performed
after 1 hour of immersion in PBS at 37 ºC. While films ending in ELR-RGD retained their moderate
hydrophobic behavior (approximately between 62º and 71º), the ones ending in CHI increased gradually,
from 20.4±4.4º in the first layer to 40.1±3.9º in the fifth (layer 9). The increasing values of contact
angles obtained for CHI-ending films can be explained by the influence of the underlying adsorbed
layers on the coating interface. When using weak polyelectrolytes, the most charged polymer tends to
be adsorbed as a thin layer with flat chain conformations, while the less charged polymer tends to be
adsorbed as a thicker layer, forming loopier-type structures [48,49]. Since ELR-RGD is a modified
version of the basic repeating block of elastin with charged amino acids, CHI appears as the most
charged polymer, as already presented by the ?-potential measurements. Furthermore, the thickness
increase of each layer displayed in Figure Figure 8.2b helps to demonstrate that the ELR-RGD layers are
overall thicker than the ones of CHI. Thus, the surface properties of the CHI layer may reflect the effect
of the underlying ELR one, even in terms of wettability, while the opposite does not occur.
The featured films were conceived using a recombinant ELR, a biomaterial exhibiting stimuli-responsive
properties in solution. It would be interesting to observe how the wettability of the films behaves when
they are exposed to several stimuli. To achieve this goal, we have measured the contact angles of 5
pairs of layers ending in ELR-RGD, labeled (CHI/ELR-RGD)5, assembled in glass substrates, at different

Taking the case of the temperature, at 25ºC an initial wettability exhibiting values of 67.1±4.7º was
measured, corresponding to a moderate hydrophobic surface. However, upon increasing the
temperature to 50ºC, the contact angle values decreased to those of a superhydrophilic surface,
corresponding to a totally wettable surface. ELRs show a phase transition in solution above Tt, similar to
the transition of other temperature-sensitive polymers with lower critical solution temperature (LCST).
However, the hydrophobicity of such a surface did not increase with the switch to high temperatures. In
fact, while the hydrophobicity of surfaces modified with LCST polymers increases [9], the behavior of
ELRs when adsorbed onto a surface is opposite to the expected, more in accordance to the case of
polymers with an upper critical solution temperature (UCST), which become more hydrophilic [50].
Such atypical wettability behavior of ELR-RGD temperature-responsive coatings has been previously
observed in a thin ELR monolayer adsorbed onto CHI substrates [30]. We have shown that upon the
transition, the collapsed biopolymer aggregates into micelle-like structures, as suggested by topography
Chapter 8. Layer-by-layer assembly of chitosan and recombinant biopolymers into biomimetic coatings
with multiple stimuli-responsive properties
296
measurements. They assume a conformation where the hydrophobic chains are directed to the inside
and the charged residues to the outside of such organizations. Additionally, while the properties of such
surfaces change at 50ºC, the polymer in solution shows a transition at 23ºC, where the association is
much more facilitated than at the surface, to which the polymer is tightly connected.
Similar results to that of temperature response were obtained for pH and ionic strength, and even
exhibiting similar contact angle values. In the case of pH, ELR-RGD has lysines in its structure, which
amine groups are protonated below the pKa values ranging 9.4–10.6 [43]. Above the pKa, the amine
groups are deprotonated and the hydrophobicity of ELR-RGD increases. It is known that the more
hydrophobic the ELR the lower the Tt in solution is [34]. Thus, with the increase of pH, the mean
hydrophobicity of ELR-RGD also increases, up to a pH of 11. At this value, the transition to a
superhydrophilic regimen was detected, as depicted in Figure 8.4. In the case of ionic strength,
Reguera et al. [51] suggested that an increase in the salt concentration increases the polarity of the
solvent. This creates a higher difference in polarity with respect to the hydrophobic moieties of the
polymer, causing more and more ordered structures surrounding the polymer chains. As observed, a
transition was detected upon the increase of ionic strength to 1.25 M, which is in accordance to the
behavior of this family of polymers. These results show that the wettability of (CHI/ELR-RGD)5 films are
strongly dependent not only on temperature but also on pH and ionic strength, which influence the Tt of
ELRs in aqueous solutions as well. Furthermore, the films were submitted to three cycles of variations
and still retained full reversibility and similar contact angle values, showing that the films are robust and
capable of withstanding sharp changes of the environment, while retaining functionality.
The results presented so far reflect the nature of the studied ELR, and characterize the conceived film
as a stimuli-sensitive coating that could prove to be useful in the development of controlled release
systems and in surfaces capable to control cell behavior. In order to have full understanding of this
behavior, the wettability was further studied for several arrays of conditions, consisting in the
combination of pH and ionic strength, at three relevant temperatures: 25ºC (room temperature), 37ºC
(temperature of the body), and 50ºC (determined to be the temperature of transition of ELR-RGD at the
surface). The diagram of Figure 8.5 is the graphical representation of the measurements performed in
(CHI/ELR-RGD)5, in an attempt to characterize the coating wettability.

The measurements performed have revealed the conditions of wettability transition for temperature, pH,
and ionic strength: 50ºC, 11, and 1.25 M, respectively. The transition was also revealed to be rapid and
independent of the contribution of the other stimuli: an “all-or-nothing” response towards external
stimuli. In other words, the wettability of these systems shifts from a moderate hydrophobic regimen to
superhydrophilic only when a stimulus equals or exceeds the above mentioned values, and there is no
evidence of cross-dependencies between the three variables. Therefore, observing Figure 8.5, one can
easily identify the parameters of transition at room temperature and 50ºC. In the former, the wettability
shifts at pH 11 or ionic strength 1.25 M, as previously stated; in the latter, 50ºC is already the
temperature at which the wettability shifts, therefore any combination of the other two stimuli can be
disregarded.

The measurements performed at 37ºC are of particular interest for biomedical applications, since
ultimately these coatings are intended to be used in a biological environment. In the graphic, the
wettability of the surfaces at 37ºC is similar to the case at room temperature, showing transitions
dependent on pH and ionic strength at 11 and 1.25 M, respectively. However, our measurements
showed that in the range of pH 10–11 and of ionic strength 1–1.25 M, intermediate values could be
observed (CAs of 30.5 ±20.6º). Such behavior is an interesting one: upon heating an ELR in solution
above the Tt, aggregation occurs and the solution becomes cloudy; given a few hours, or further
increasing the temperature, the aggregates gradually settle and the result is a clean phase separation of
solvent and polymer [52]. At the studied surfaces, the equivalent to this “cloudy point” could only be
observed for this small range of values and the wettability shift is only fully achieved – and quickly, not
gradually as in solution – for pH 11 and ionic strength 1.25 M, as is the case at room temperature.
Thus, the diagram summarizes the response of the films ending in ELR-RGD as a function of three
distinct variables, showing an independent and immediate effect of three of the parameters influencing
the conformation of ELRs.

the factor that contributes the most to the increase of roughness. Similar results were also obtained in

8.3.3 Cell culture studies of SaOS-2 osteoblast-like cells
Smart surfaces have been used in different fields in situations where it is relevant to control the
adhesion of cells or microorganisms, protein adsorption or transport properties for the release of
bioactive agents. In many cases, it is desirable that the substrate interacts favorably with cells. It has
been reported that the RGD sequence is the minimal sequence required for recognition by cell
membrane integrins, such as ?5?1 and ?V?3 integrins [55-57]. The affinity of cells for materials should
be improved with the incorporation of a peptide having this sequence.
So far, we have been able to expand the concept of LbL to a class of materials that is not commonly
used in literature. We also presented results showing that the films display distinct properties for
different conditions of temperature, pH and ionic strength. This feature could be exploited to modulate
protein and cell adhesion by playing with one of the mentioned stimuli. Unfortunately, the presented
transition values are simply not suitable for most biological applications. We expect to take advantage
on the recombinant nature of ELRs in the near future to produce films that could be triggered at lower
values. Nonetheless, the biological performance of the current films was analyzed in order to determine
if this kind of multilayer film is suitable for future tissue engineering devices with good response from
cells, without any hazardous reaction.
In vitro studies were performed using SaOs-2 osteoblast-like cells. Although other possibilities could be
explored, one of the uses we envisaged for these coatings is in orthopedic applications in order to
improve host integration. To prove that the superior cell attachment was due to a specific interaction
with RGD, the cell behavior was compared to surfaces with a negative control of ELR containing a
scrambled RDG sequence, labeled RDG (-)
, in the form of 5 bilayers with CHI, (CHI/ELR-RDG (-)
)5. The
scrambled RDG sequence has been previously shown to have significantly less cellular adhesion [58]
and is similar to ELR-RGD in all aspects, except for the position of the G and D aminoacids.

coatings, cell culture was performed at 37ºC, at which the surface is moderately hydrophobic (see

8.4 Conclusions
Our results show that ELRs containing biologically relevant peptide sequences can be successfully
combined with CHI in a sequential multilayer approach based on electrostatic and hydrophobic
interactions. QCM-D results allowed us to study the construction of the polymeric films and its
properties, showing the buildup of a film with a linear growth. Although glass was used to assemble
such coatings, it is expected in the future that such straightforward surface modification technique will
allow us to coat other substrates with more complex geometries, including scaffolds or particles. The
stimuli-responsive properties of the films were extensively studied, showing acute and independent
cyclic response towards temperature, pH and ionic strength; the values of transition for each stimulus
were identified: 50ºC, 11, and 1.25 M, respectively. Below each critical transition point, the surfaces
were more hydrophobic. Above those, the surface acquired a very hydrophilic character due to the
biopolymer chain collapse and subsequent exposure of charged residues to the outer region of the
coating. The transition was also evident in the changes in the topography of the surfaces as we
increased the pH of the film above the transition values, increasing their roughness due to the
aggregation of ELR chains on the top layer.
SaOs-2 osteoblast-like cells were used to test the biological performance of the multilayered system
studied in vitro of the films. The cells showed increased adhesion and activity with ELR-RGD ending
coatings, in comparison to the ones ending with both CHI and the non-bioactive ELR-RDG (-)
. This work
demonstrates the potential to use natural and nature-inspired macromolecules to modify surfaces
taking advantage of a simple layer-by-layer technique, which can be further extrapolated to more
complex devices. The potential of this technology can further stimulate the development of other similar
biomedical products in the near future, such as devices entirely processed through layer-by-layer for the
delivery of pharmaceuticals, cell culture or structures for tissue engineering.

Chapter 9. Nanostructured and thermoresponsive recombinant
biopolymer-based microcapsules for the delivery of active
molecules 9
Abstract
Multilayer capsules conceived at the nano- and micro-scales are receiving increasing interest due to
their potential role as carriers of biomolecules for drug delivery and tissue engineering. Herein we report
the construction of microcapsules by the sequential adsorption of chitosan and a biomimetic elastin-like
recombinamer into nanostructured layers on inorganic microparticle templates. The release profile of
bovine serum albumin, which was studied at 25 and 37°C, shows higher retention and Fickian diffusion
at physiological temperature. The self-assembled multilayers act as a barrier and allowed for sustained
release over 14 days. The capsules studied are non-cytotoxic towards L929 cells, thereby suggesting
multiple applications in the fields of biotechnology and bioengineering, where high control of the delivery
of therapeutics and growth/differentiation factors is required.
9 This chapter is based on the following publication:
Costa R. R., Custódio C. A., Arias F. J., Rodríguez-Cabello J. C., and Mano J. F., Nanostructured and thermoresponsive
recombinant biopolymer-based microcapsules for the delivery of active molecules, Nanomedicine: Nanotechnology, Biology
and Medicine 2013, 9 : 895-902, DOI:10.1016/j.nano.2013.01.013.

9.1 Introduction
Recent advances in biomedicine have been driven by the need to develop systems that can effectively
encapsulate, protect and deliver an active agent with specific kinetics [1-5]. Such need comes at a time
when various classes of biomolecules of interest for the treatment of several diseases and the
development of new biomedical devices are becoming widely available. With this increasing availability,
the use of smart materials to control the delivery and release of specific agents has followed a similar
trend.
Ideally, a biomolecule carrier should act as a compartment in which the permeability of a drug to the
exterior can be tuned as this would allow the release rate to be controlled when concerning both
therapeutics in traditional drug-delivery applications as well as tissue engineering agents that influence
the proliferation and differentiation of cells. The layer-by-layer (LbL) self-assembly of macromolecules –
a simple, versatile and inexpensive surface-engineering technique that can be used, under mild
conditions, to encapsulate sensitive active agents and biomaterials by either manipulating the
architecture of a device or by way of external stimuli – is an approach with the potential to address this
issue. These “capsules” could then deliver the encapsulated agents to the target cells by making use of
simple release mechanisms into the biological environment [6-9] or by digestion of the cells
themselves [10-13]. Although often applied to flat surfaces, LbL can be used to coat surfaces with
complex geometries and shapes and can be extrapolated to three dimensions [14-19]. Hollow
multilayer capsules are a good example of 3D structures that can act as drug carriers. Inorganic
particles are typically used as templates for this purpose as they can be chelated under non-aggressive
conditions [20-22]. The use of LbL techniques will therefore ultimately allow control of both the release
profile of a specific agent and the permeability of the system by varying the materials and number of
layers in the capsule architecture.
The concept of post-construction permeability is of great interest for drug-delivery and tissue-engineering
applications as a carrier must be able to retain and preserve the drug but also release it when
necessary and in a controlled fashion. An ability to switch the permeability of a multilayer capsule
between an “open” and a “closed” state has been demonstrated previously [23-25], but has yet to be
fully validated. Temperature, for example, has been suggested to be a possible mechanism for post-
loading therapeutic agents using temperatures as high as 50 to 70°C [26-30]. However, such
temperatures are not suitable for biological applications. Herein we intend to demonstrate the
Chapter 9 – Nanostructured and thermoresponsive recombinant biopolymer-based microcapsules for
the delivery of active molecules
312
entrapping properties of self-assembled coatings with varying numbers of nanolayers combined with the
response of a biocompatible system towards an external temperature-based stimulus.
In light of the likely benefits of natural and nature-inspired biomaterials combined with stimuli-
responsiveness [31,32], we aimed to construct a new generation of therapeutic containers using a
multilayer approach. Chitosan (CHI) and a biomimetic elastin-like recombinamer (ELR) – a recombinant
version of elastin-like polymers (ELPs) – were used as constituents for the microcapsule shell. CHI is a
well-known natural material with cationic behavior [33]. whereas ELRs are genetically engineered
polypeptides that mimic natural elastin and exhibit a primary smart response towards temperature.
These recombinant macromolecules are soluble below a specific critical transition temperature (Tt) in
an aqueous medium, but undergo a phase separation characterized by the dominant presence of
hydrogen bonds and hydrophobic interactions above it [34-38]. They also allow fine control over the
peptide structure, thus making it possible to introduce motifs with biological relevance, such as cell-
adhesion and mineralization promoters, into their primary valine-proline-glycine-valine-glycine (VPGVG)
sequence [14,39,40].
The primary structure of the ELR used herein was designed to present a bioactive behavior by the
inclusion of L-arginine-glycine-L-aspartic acid (RGD) residues, while exploiting the negative aspartic acid
moieties to enable subsequent self-assembly with chitosan into nanostructured multilayers (schematic
structure can be found in Supplemental Figure 9.1). The present work focuses on our ability to
construct CHI/ELR microcapsules and to use the temperature-responsive nature of ELRs to control the
permeability of engineered multilayer systems. The resulting microcapsules were characterized for their
encapsulation efficiency of a model protein, namely bovine serum albumin (BSA). The permeability of
the BSA-loaded microcapsules with a varying number of layers was studied at 25 and 37°C, and the
biocompatibility of these structures was evaluated in vitro.
9.2 Experimental section
9.2.1 Materials for the microcapsule composition
Medium molecular weight chitosan was purchased from Sigma (reference 448877) and purified by a
series of filtration and precipitation in water and ethanol steps, followed by freeze-drying. ELR
bioproduction was induced using a fermentation process from an Escherichia coli strain BLR(DE3)
containing the appropriate expression gene. Subsequent to fermentation, the culture was harvested and
Chapter 9 – Nanostructured and thermoresponsive recombinant biopolymer-based microcapsules for
the delivery of active molecules
313
lysed by ultrasonic disruption. Insoluble debris was removed by centrifugation and the cleared lysate
was subjected to several cycles of cold and warm centrifugations. The polymer in solution was stored at
-24°C and then freeze-dried. The detailed methodology has been described previously [35].
9.2.2 ELR aggregate-size measurements
ELR aggregate size was measured using a Nano-ZS from Malvern (United Kingdom) in the temperature
range 25–37°C after stabilization for 5 minutes. Samples were prepared at 300 µg?mL -1
in phosphate
buffer solution (PBS, Sigma reference P4417), pH 7.4. A total of 20 runs were performed for each
sample to obtain a final average value at constant temperature.
9.2.3 Entrapment of BSA in calcium carbonate particles
BSA entrapment was achieved following the method described by She et al. [8]. Thus, to encapsulate 1
mg of BSA, aqueous solutions of anhydrous sodium carbonate (Na2CO3 granular, ?99.5%, Sigma
reference 222321) and calcium chloride (CaCl2 anhydrous powder Reag. Ph Eur, VWR reference
1.02378.0500) were prepared at 1 M. Co-precipitation of both solutions was performed by adding 100
µL of Na2CO3 followed by 100 µL of CaCl2 to 200 µL of BSA tagged with fluorescein isothiocyanate
(FITC) (66 kDa, Sigma reference A9771) at 5 mg?mL -1
and stirring rapidly for 30 seconds. Stirring was
then stopped and the suspension of newly synthesized calcium carbonate (CaCO3) microparticles left to
react and precipitate for 15 min. The supernatant was then removed and the particles washed twice
with ultrapure water to remove residual salts and non-entrapped protein. Each supernatant was retained
for fluorescence measurements and determination of entrapment losses.
9.2.4 Construction of the multilayer shells and microcapsule formation
The CaCO3 sacrificial templates entrapping FITC-BSA were immersed alternately in chitosan and ELR
solutions [300 µg?mL -1
, pH 5.5, 0.15 M of sodium chloride (NaCl, Reag. Ph Eur, Panreac reference
131659] for 10 min each, then washed with 0.15 M NaCl (pH 5.5). Centrifugation was avoided to avoid
damage and aggregation of the particles each time the samples were to be retrieved from solution;
simple precipitation of the suspension was used instead (3 to 5 min). This process was repeated to
increase the number of bilayers until the desired coating had been obtained (1, 3 and 5 bilayers). After
construction, the CaCO3 core was removed by chelation with ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA
Chapter 9 – Nanostructured and thermoresponsive recombinant biopolymer-based microcapsules for
the delivery of active molecules
314
powder, ACS reagent, 99.4–100.6%, Sigma reference E9884; 0.2 M, pH 5.5). Each supernatant and
solution was retained for fluorescence measurements and determination of losses during the
construction and chelation stages.
9.2.5 Determination of pre-loading encapsulation efficiency
Fluorescence measurements were performed using a Synergie HT microplate ELISA reader (BioTek,
USA). Thus, 150 ?L of sample was pipetted into a white, opaque 96-well plate in triplicate. Distilled
water was used as blank. The excitation (?exc) and emission (?em) wavelengths used for the calibration
curve and FITC-BSA mass calculations were 485 and 528 nm, respectively. All supernatants collected
during entrapment, construction and chelation were measured and quantified. The percentage of
fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC)-BSA mass lost was plotted both for each stage and cumulatively. The
encapsulation efficiency was calculated by subtracting the cumulative losses of each architecture from
the initial FITC-BSA mass.
9.2.6 In vitro biological performance
A murine fibroblast cell line (L929, European Collection of Cell Cultures) was used for the biological
assays. Thus, L929 cells were cultured in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM, Invitrogen
reference 42400-028) with phenol red supplemented with 10% of fetal bovine serum (FBS, Invitrogen,
reference 10270-106) and 1% antibiotic/antimicotic (Gibco reference 15240062) in a humidified
atmosphere with 5% carbon dioxide (CO2) at 37°C. For the cell viability test, 2×10 3 cells were seeded
on 48-well plates and incubated at 37°C, 5% CO2. After 24 hours, microcapsules were added to the
culture medium in a ratio of 40 microcapsules per cell. After each culturing period, samples were
washed twice with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS). A 250 ?L aliquot of fetal bovine serum (FBS)-free
culture medium and 50 ?L of (3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-5-(3-carboxymethoxyphenyl)-2-(4-sulfophenyl)-
2H-tetrazolium) (MTS) reagent were added to each well. A cell-free well was used as control. Plates
were incubated for 3 h at 37ºC, 5% CO2, protected from light. After incubation, 100 ?L of this solution
was transferred to a 96-well plate and the plate read using a Synergie HT microplate ELISA reader
(BioTek, USA) in 490 nm absorbance mode.
Visualization of the actin cytoskeleton was performed using (tetramethylrhodamine B isothiocyanate)-
phalloidin (TRITC-phalloidin, Sigma reference P1951). After each culture period, samples were washed
Chapter 9 – Nanostructured and thermoresponsive recombinant biopolymer-based microcapsules for
the delivery of active molecules
315
twice with PBS and fixed with 4% formalin in PBS for 15 min at room temperature. After fixation, cells
were incubated with TRITC-phalloidin (10 ?g?mL -1
) for 45 min and washed three times with PBS. To
stain the nucleus, the cells were incubated with 4',6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI, Sigma reference
D9564) (1 ?g?mL -1
) for 5 min then washed with PBS. Cells were observed under an Axioimager Z1M
Zeiss fluorescence microscope (Zeiss, Germany).
9.2.7 Quantification of FITC-BSA release
The microcapsules were resuspended in PBS at either 25 or 37°C. The upper limit of five bilayers for
the microcapsule architecture was chosen to study the effect of temperature along with small changes
in the number of different layers. This study was conducted over 14 days, removing the surrounding
PBS from each container every 24 h. An additional sample was taken after 12 h from the start of the
study. PBS was fully refreshed at each time point, and 100% BSA was considered to be the total mass
remaining in the microcapsules after their construction. The release experiments were performed under
mild agitation to improve the diffusion of BSA through the incubating medium. All experiments were
performed in triplicate (n=3), with each sample containing the number of capsules resulting from the
attempted encapsulation of 1 mg of BSA. To determine the type of release profile for each condition,
the release kinetics were determined using the Korsmeyer kinetic model (equation 9.1):

9.2.8 Microscopy characterization of the CaCO3 microparticles and multilayered
microcapsules
A Leica Cambridge S360 scanning electron microscope (United Kingdom) was used to evaluate the
morphology of the sacrificial templates. Specimens were pre-coated with a conductive layer of sputtered
gold and micrographs recorded at 10 kV. An Olympus FV1000 confocal laser scanning microscope
(CLSM, Germany) was used to evaluate the morphology of (CHI/ELR)5 microcapsules loaded with FITC-

the delivery of active molecules

BSA. A final layer consisting of a cationic dye (rhodamine B, 10 -6
M) was further adsorbed. All samples
were stabilized at either 25 or 37°C and observed under hydrated conditions.
9.3 Results
In order to evaluate the thermal response of the featured ELR, the size variations of peptide aggregates
in aqueous solution were measured as a function of temperature. The results, which are plotted in
Figure 9.1, show an increase in aggregate size from around 10 to 3000 nm in aqueous PBS solution.
This variation occurs at a Tt of 29°C and is accompanied by an increase in solution turbidity, thus
showing that this ELR possesses a Tt in solution above the working room temperature and below the
physiological one of 37°C.

29°C and increased turbidity above it.
CaCO3 particles were prepared by co-precipitation of Na2CO3 and CaCl2 solutions under vigorous
stirring in a BSA medium and subsequently tagged with FITC. The resulting inorganic particles, with a
diameter of around 5-6 µm (Figure 9.2A), were used as BSA-containing sacrificial templates for the
alternating incubation with aqueous chitosan and ELR solutions. After construction, the core was
chelated with EDTA to form hollow microcapsules, as confirmed by CLSM Figure 9.2B).

Structures with one, three and five bilayers, henceforth referred to as (CHI/ELR)1, (CHI/ELR)3 and
(CHI/ELR)5, were constructed to study the effects of capsule architecture on the subsequent release of
BSA at 25 and 37°C. In order to determine the total encapsulation efficiency, the fluorescence of each

stage (Figure 9.2C), losses during the construction stage were higher for capsules with fewer layers.
The effect of the shell architecture became more evident during the chelation stage, with our

The ability to retain an active agent and protect it until delivery is one of the most important features of
a drug-delivery system. Our results showed BSA retentions of greater than 70% of the initial 1 mg after
construction of the microcapsules, with cumulative losses of 28%, 26% and 25% for (Chi/ELR)1,
(CHI/ELR)3 and (CHI/ELR)5, respectively (see Figure 9.2C for stage losses, and Supplemental Figure
9.3 and Supplemental Table 9.1 for detailed cumulative calculations). However, an ability to release this
active agent in a controlled manner after encapsulation is equally important. As such, the influence of
the total number of layers and temperature on the release profile of BSA from the capsules was
investigated. BSA release at different temperatures was studied over a period of 14 days, and the
cumulative release profiles for (CHI/ELR)1, (CHI/ELR)3 and (CHI/ELR)5 capsules loaded with BSA at
room (25°C) and physiological temperatures (37°C) can be seen in Figure 9.5.

shows that BSA release is sustained over the period studied, with a visible absence of significant burst

rate constants, K, in Table 9.1), with smaller quantities of released FITC-BSA being detected from

Fitting with other models (zero-order, first-order and Higuchi) can be found in the Supplementary
Information (Supplemental Figure 9.6 to Supplemental Figure 9.11). The data for capsules incubated at
25°C fit an anomalous (non-Fickian) mode of diffusion (n > 0.43), thus suggesting a combination of
pure protein diffusion and shell relaxation/swelling mechanisms under these conditions. The
(CHI/ELR)5 capsules were an exception to this, with a Fickian mode of diffusion (n <0.43). The
capsules also follow a Fickian diffusion model at 37°C. In comparison to the capsules at 25°C, a pure
diffusion mechanism occurs under physiological conditions. This effect results from the restructuration
of the film which occurs upon deposition of each additional layer [42]. The result is a more densely
packed multilayer structure with decreasing polymeric mobility and no anomalous relaxation/swelling
mechanism, together with a more compact and stable shell.
9.4 Discussion
The development of drug-delivery systems that can encapsulate, protect and deliver a therapeutic
molecule or growth factor in a controlled fashion is of major importance for both current healthcare
applications and in the fields of tissue engineering and regenerative medicine. Herein we have exploited
temperature and the smart response of ELRs as an actual drug-release mechanism for a pre-
encapsulated model protein. Furthermore, our aim was to develop a system that is able to respond at a
temperature which will be useful for future applications in human biological studies.
We have conceived and developed biocompatible thermoresponsive microcapsules by taking advantage
of the self-assembly properties of chitosan and an ELR using a multilayer approach. The fact that the
majority of LbL studies performed to date have involved conventional polyelectrolytes has hindered the
extrapolation of this technology to systems exhibiting other capabilities and complexities, including those
Chapter 9 – Nanostructured and thermoresponsive recombinant biopolymer-based microcapsules for
the delivery of active molecules
322
that could respond to external stimuli. We have previously demonstrated that, unlike most conventional
multilayer combinations, combining these two materials is more favorable when both electrostatic and
hydrophobic interactions are exploited, thus allowing for the construction of films as thin as 40 nm
(considering a total of five bilayers) [43]. This is feasible if construction is performed under conditions
close to the pKa of the polysaccharide, where both protonated and deprotonated groups can be used.
Our results, especially those observed in CLSM (Figure 9.2B and Figure 9.3), demonstrate that it is
possible to extrapolate this technology from 2D to 3D and to construct micrometric devices using a non-
conventional combination of polymers.
In order to determine the pre-encapsulation efficiency (see Figure 9.2C), all three construction stages
were screened for each architecture [(CHI/ELR)1, (CHI/ELR)3 and (CHI/ELR)5]. There was no
difference between any of the cases studied during the entrapment stage. Note that at this stage the
shell has not yet been assembled, thus meaning that the encapsulation efficiency is solely dependent
on the protein/CaCO3 interaction, which at this point in the process is common for all groups. In the
following construction stage, and in contrast to our expectations, the losses were higher for thinner
capsules. As more adsorption steps and manipulation are involved as construction proceeds, we
expected to find higher protein losses for (CHI/ELR)5 microcapsules since BSA should diffuse
continuously from the sacrificial core, even if only in insignificant quantities. The explanation for our
finding may reside in the fact that the protein lost to the polymer incubation solutions may be retaken
up during the addition of subsequent layers to the shell. Indeed, using CLSM we were able to identify a
high concentration of FITC-BSA near the capsule shell (see Figure 9.2B). As for the chelation stage,
although there is a statistically significant difference between (CHI/ELR)1 and (CHI/ELR)3, the
numerical difference is not meaningful (12.7% vs. 11.3%, respectively). Thicker capsules are also able
to retain more protein than those with a lower number of bilayers since multilayer shells can act as
barriers that hinder the diffusion of molecules from the inner cavity to the surrounding medium [8].
The microcapsules described herein have been shown to undergo temperature-dependent size
variations, with two possible shrinkage mechanisms explaining the shrinkage observed upon increasing
the temperature. Thus, as discussed previously, the ELR collapses to a more ordered, self-assembled
state upon increasing temperature above Tt [35-37], although it is also likely that shrinkage is further
amplified by a thermodynamic rearrangement of the layers. Such a rearrangement is driven by the
tendency of shells with an even number of layers (1:1 ratio of electrostatic forces) to minimize the
Chapter 9 – Nanostructured and thermoresponsive recombinant biopolymer-based microcapsules for
the delivery of active molecules
323
shell/water interface [30]. This is the same mechanism used for post-loading procedures, which have
been reported to take place at typical temperatures in the range 50–70°C [27-30].
Despite the fact that such structures have been reported to respond to temperature changes, this has
only been applied as a means to post-encapsulate molecules within pre-formed microcapsules.
However, other than the exploitation of post-encapsulation procedures, the temperatures required for
this are not suitable for biological applications. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time that
such a significant size reduction has been observed at temperatures as low as 37°C. For example,
using oppositely charged copolymers of poly(styrene sulfonate) (PSS) and poly(allylamine hydrochloride)
(PAH) with poly(N -isoproprylacrylamide) (PNIPAAm), Glinel et al. [27] have reported a size reduction of
only 15% at 60 °C, whereas the present work shows a reduction of 42% at 37°C. Furthermore, these
microcapsules retain a temperature response over a relevant temperature range and the changes occur
under physiological conditions, similar to what has been demonstrated for the ELR in solution (Figure
9.1). These results allow us to anticipate future applications in the field of biomedicine in areas such as
drug delivery, cell/tissue engineering and regenerative medicine.
In order to be used in biomedicine, it was important to assess whether the microcapsules and their
content were harmful to cells. The biological performance in vitro is presented in Figure 9.4. This study
showed that the viability of L929 cells in contact with the capsules (loaded and unloaded) was
comparable to those used as positive control. The morphology of lone L929 cells and cells in contact
with loaded (CHI/ELR)5 microcapsules was also similar. These results show that these structures are
non-cytotoxic towards L929 cells and can therefore be safely used in biomedical applications. Such
applications could include the simple release of a biomolecule from a drug release device, with the
microcapsules being compacted to form a tablet that can be administered orally. Since these
microcapsules are highly retentive at physiological temperatures, they could release specific active
agents in quantities within a therapeutic time window. Further possibilities include transcutaneous
vaccines for the delivery of biomolecules into the skin, and the local application or injection of
microcapsules loaded with growth factors at a defect site in a tissue or organ to facilitate its
regeneration. This site could also be a tumor, with low molecular weight anti-cancer drugs being loaded
into these reservoirs to kill tumor cells [44]. It should be noted that the temperature at tumor sites is
usually slightly higher than 37°C and hyperthermic treatments are used to further increase the
temperature locally. For the specific use of these microcapsules in cancer treatments, experiments at
slightly higher temperatures (e.g., up to 42°C) using low molecular weight molecules (most
Chapter 9 – Nanostructured and thermoresponsive recombinant biopolymer-based microcapsules for
the delivery of active molecules
324
chemotherapeutic drugs have low molecular weights) should be performed in the future. Growth factors,
which tend to have a higher molecular weight than chemotherapeutic agents, are also of interest for
tissue-engineering applications, where they could be used in vitro to control cell metabolism and
proliferation and to trigger stem cell differentiation. Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF, around 40
kDa), for example, has shown great potential in angiogenesis, one of the most relevant mechanisms in
tissue-engineering applications. Similarly, human platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF, around 20-30
kDa) is one of the most active factors in cell migration and differentiation. However, the success of
these growth factors in therapeutic applications often requires a spatiotemporal controlled-release
system for delivery [45]. This could be achieved by diffusion of the encapsulated load into the medium
and by internalization of individual capsules by the cells. The latter case would require the cells
concerned to be larger than the individual microcapsules. We did not observe the uptake of capsules by
L929 cells in this study, most probably because the size difference between L929 (around 5 to 10 µm)
and microcapsules at 37°C (3.21±0.63 µm, Figure 9.3B) is too small for such a phenomenon to occur.
In contrast, some stem cells, such as adipose stem cells, may reach 50 µm, thus meaning that
applications which envisage their differentiation may be exploited in the future using this kind of
micrometric device.
Figure 9.5 shows the BSA-release properties of microcapsules with different numbers of layers at
distinct temperatures, together with the Korsmeyer model fitting parameters calculated in Table 9.1. It
should be noted that these systems were not designed to operate in an “on/off” basis, such as when
exploiting a temperature-dependent post-loading approach, but rather to achieve distinct release profiles
that could prove to be useful for the sustained release of molecules in the body or in vitro.
The permeability of BSA to the exterior was easily tuned by varying the number of layers. Thus, similarly
to the chelation stage during construction, the multilayer shell was able to act as a more effective
barrier as the number of layers in it increased, thus allowing for a more sustained release and retentive
microcapsule. The results obtained at 25 and 37°C were also interesting as the capsules proved to be
more retentive at the latter. These results relate well with the size variations observed in Figure 9.3: the
thermoresponsive effect of the CHI/ELR microcapsules results in a reduction in both their size and their
permeability, thus making them more retentive. It is notable that, regardless of the test conditions,
100% of the BSA contained in the microcapsules was not released, most likely due to an interaction
between the protein and the nanostructured shell. It is possible that a combination with enzymatic
Chapter 9 – Nanostructured and thermoresponsive recombinant biopolymer-based microcapsules for
the delivery of active molecules
325
degradation, a mechanism which has been used previously [6,46,47], could lead to total release of the
load. However, such a study was outside the scope of this work.
9.5 Conclusion
In summary, size and permeability variations have been achieved by exploiting the temperature
response of the ELR, which is amplified by a thermodynamic rearrangement of the multilayer structure
at the molecular level. The use of different numbers of layers has allowed the permeability of the shells
to be tuned, thus resulting in distinct release profiles for each architecture tested. We envisage the
exploitation of these properties at physiological temperature for applications where a long-term release
with low initial drug burst is desired. Similarly, the degradation mechanisms of a cellular environment
can be simulated to release an active agent completely over the appropriate time period. Due to
micrometric size of these capsules, delivering small quantities of growth factors or differentiation agents
directly to the cells by digestion is envisaged. The genetically encoded nature of ELRs offers the
possibility to engineer molecules containing biologically relevant motifs that could be recognized by
specific cells, such as the present case of RGD inclusion. All these possibilities, together with their non-
cytotoxic character, make these microcapsules a promising alternative for more highly effective drug
delivery and tissue engineering.

Chapter 10. Cellular uptake of multilayered capsules produced
with biomimetic and genetically engineered macromolecules 10
Abstract
Multilayered microcapsules of chitosan and biomimetic elastin-like recombinamers (ELRs) were
prepared for intracellular delivery of active agents. Two ELRs containing either the bioactive RGD
sequence or a scrambled nonfunctional RDG were used to construct two types of functionalized
polymeric microcapsules, both with spherical shape around 4 ?m in diameter. Cell viability studies
using human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs) were performed for microcapsule/cell ratios between
5:1 and 100:1. After 3 and 72 hours of incubation no cytotoxicity was found. Nonetheless, cells
incubated with RGD-functionalized microcapsules exhibited higher mean viability values than RDG ones.
Internalization efficacy and bioavailability of encapsulated proteins was assessed by monitoring
fluorescence changes of DQ-ovalbumin. The data showed that microcapsules’ surface functionalization
did not influence significantly the internalization by hMSCs, although DQ-ovalbumin was degraded faster
from within RGD-functionalized microcapsules. The developed microcapsules let foresee strategies for
targeting intracellular drug delivery and to increase drug efficacy.

10.1 Introduction
In the field of drug delivery, there has been great interest in the development of nano- and micro-
carriers of active agents, such as micelles, liposomes, polymersomes, and polymer capsules [1-3].
Such devices may control the release of encapsulated biomolecules and also their efficacy by delivering
them to the location where they are most needed. In particular, the use of nanostructured nano- and
micro-capsules made using layer-by-layer (LbL) strategies has been studied as a method to encapsulate
and deliver drugs in a controlled manner [4-8]. The principle behind LbL adsorption lies in the existence
of intermolecular interactions attracting distinct polymer chains, such as electrostatic contacts,
hydrophobic interactions, and hydrogen bonding, which drive the assembly of layers with only a few
nanometers onto a surface [9-11]. With this simple and versatile technique, robust coatings can be
assembled into bidimensional templates and even complex three-dimensional substrates. For instance,
spherical nanostructured microcapsules have been conceived resorting to sacrificial silica (with 500 nm
to 5 µm, dissolved in hydrogen fluoride) and porous calcium carbonate particles (with 3 to 5 µm,
dissolved in ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid, EDTA) [12]. These structures have already been found to
be useful as drug carriers – including of stem cell differentiation promoters – with release kinetics
dependent on the number of layers or external stimuli, and as biosensors [13-15].
Multilayer microcapsules may encapsulate and deliver bioactive agents to cells or tissues following
conventional release mechanisms to the biological environment [16] or by digestion within the cells
themselves [17]. The latter possibility is particularly interesting: by delivering an active agent directly to
the cells, where the whole metabolic machinery is found, high drug concentrations could be made
available to the targeted tissue using minimal cargo amounts during its encapsulation. Moreover, it
could also be possible to circumvent undesirable side effects to circumventing tissues or cells due to
premature drug leakage.
Carriers such as dendrimers, micelles and biodegradable nanoparticles have been frequently developed
for the intracellular delivery of bioactive agents [18-21]. As carriers, multilayer-coated capsules present
several advantages that are not often found together in other conventional fabrication techniques: (i)
they can be prepared under mild conditions, what makes it possible for large amounts of sensitive or
easily denatured biological molecules [22] and even cells [23] to be encapsulated, (ii) it is possible to
encapsulate drugs with low water solubility [5], (iii) they allow controlling better the release kinetics by
Chapter 10 – Cellular uptake of multilayered capsules produced with biomimetic and genetically
engineered macromolecules
340
varying the number of layers and their composition [24], and (iv) the shell can provide a high degree of
functionality by selecting biofunctional constituents that may participate in biological mechanisms [25].
The primary objective of the present work is the design of multilayer microcapsules made of natural and
nature-inspired macromolecules exhibiting bioactive sequences for intracellular drug delivery. Namely,
chitosan (CHI) and elastin-like recombinamers (ELRs) were used as constituents of the multilayer shells
which were assembled onto spherical particles of calcium carbonate. CHI is a well-known polycationic
polysaccharide of marine origin which shows biocompatibility, adhesiveness and nontoxicity, as well as
bacteriostatic, fungistatic, anti-microbial and hemostatic activities [26]. ELRs, a recombinant type of
elastin-like polymers (ELP), are temperature-responsive and biomimetic polypeptides that are soluble in
aqueous media below a specific critical transition temperature (Tt) but undergo a phase separation
above it [27]. Their recombinant and modular nature is most likely their most attractive property
because it allows tuning their physicochemical properties and introducing selected relevant amino acid
domains to extend their physiological functionality [28,29]. LbL adsorption can be exploited using ELRs
alongside polysaccharides, such as CHI and alginate, by taking advantage of strong electrostatic
interactions and the stabilizing effect of weaker hydrophobic interactions [30].
Herein, human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs) were incubated with ELR-functionalized
microcapsules with the cell adhesion motif arginine-glycine-aspartic acid (RGD). The inclusion of the
loop RGD motif of the human structural protein fibronectin in the primary structure of the ELR was
expected to add bioactive character to the microcapsules, while exploiting the negatively charged
aspartic acids to enable the electrostatic self-assembly mechanism with CHI to occur. It has been
reported that the RGD sequence is the minimal sequence required for recognition by the cell adhesion
receptor integrins [31]. It is also known that nano/micro-particles modified with RGD show enhanced
internalization [32-34]. However, this comparison is often made with unmodified controls, that is, do
not undergo any functionalization. Therefore, in addition to RGD, we also constructed microcapsules
functionalized with an ELR containing a nonfunctional scrambled RDG sequence. To our knowledge, this
is the first time that the internalization efficacy of RGD-functionalized LbL microcapsules is compared
with a microcapsule type that substitutes the bioactive group with a nonfunctional analogue, similar in
every aspect except for the position of the G and D residues, instead of removing it.
The resulting microcapsules will be characterized in terms of morphology, and cytotoxicity after
incubation with hMSCs. The internalization efficacy of the microcapsules will be quantified by flow
cytometry in order to identify the existence – or absence – of a receptor-mediated uptake and
Chapter 10 – Cellular uptake of multilayered capsules produced with biomimetic and genetically
engineered macromolecules
341
consequent influence in the intracellular processing between each microcapsule type. Furthermore,
Capsules loaded with DQ-ovalbumin will permit to follow the availability of this protein inside the cells by
monitoring the fluorescence changes of the capsules.
10.2 Experimental section
10.2.1 Materials
Medium molecular weight chitosan (ref 448877), sodium carbonate anhydrous (Na2CO3, ref 222321)
and EDTA (ref E9884) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Chitosan was further submitted to a
purification stage consisting in a series of filtration and precipitation in water and ethanol steps, adapted
from the method described elsewhere [30], followed by freeze-drying. The final degree of deacetylation
was determined to be 82% by 1 H-NMR. Calcium chloride (CaCl2) was purchased from VWR (ref
1.02378.0500). Two custom-made ELRs containing either a RGD or RDG sequence – henceforth
referred to as ELR-RGD and ELR-RDG (-)
, respectively – were purchased from Technical Protein
Nanobiotechnology (Spain). The characterization of the molecular weight and amino acid composition of
the acquired batches were determined by matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass
spectroscopy (MALDI-TOF) and amino acid content analysis, respectively, and can be found
elsewhere [25]. DQ-ovalbumin (ref D12053) was obtained from Invitrogen.
Paraformaldehyde (ref P6148), Triton X-100 (ref T9284) and Accutase TM
(ref A6964) were purchased
from Sigma-Aldrich. Human mesenchymal stem cells from human adipose tissue, (hMSCs, ref R7788-
115) its basal medium, Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM, ref 31966-021), fetal bovine
serum (FBS, ref 16000-044), penicillin streptomycin solution (ref SV30010), trypsin-ethylenediamine
tetraacetic acid (EDTA, ref SV30010), Dulbecco's phosphate-buffered saline (DPBS, ref 14190-136),
4-(2-hydroxyethyl)-1-piperazineethanesulfonic acid (HEPES, ref 15630049), Trypan Blue stain 0.4% (ref
15250061), Alexa Fluor 488 phalloidin (ref A12379), LIVE/DEAD ® Viability/Cytotoxicity Kit, for
mammalian cells (ref L3224), Alamar Blue ® (ref DAL1025) and DAPI (ref D21490) were supplied by
Invitrogen . All cell culture plastic-ware and consumables were acquired from NUNC.

10.2.2 Measurement of the charges
The ?-potentials of the ELRs were determined using a Nano-ZS equipment from Malvern (United
Kingdom), at 25ºC. Aqueous solutions of each ingredient in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) (pH = 7.4)
were used, at a concentration of 300 ?g?mL -1
.
10.2.3 Synthesis of calcium carbonate sacrificial templates
Aqueous solutions Na2CO3 and CaCl2 were prepared at a concentration of 1 M. Typically, the
coprecipitation of both solutions was performed by adding 1 mL of Na2CO3 solution followed by 1 mL of
CaCl2 to 4 mL of ultrapure water (Milli-Q) under heavy stirring for 30 s. The stirring was then stopped
and the suspension of the newly synthesized calcium carbonate (CaCO3) microparticles was left to
precipitate and react for 15 min. The supernatant was removed and the particles were washed three
times with 0.15 M sodium chloride (NaCl) adjusted to pH 5.5. To produce microcapsules preloaded
with a protein cargo, the medium where the precipitation occurs consisted of an aqueous solution of
DQ-ovalbumin at a concentration of 160 ?g?mL -1
. Unless otherwise stated, all changes of solutions
during the template synthesis and construction of microcapsules were performed by leaving the particle
suspension precipitating for 10 min, followed by removal of the supernatant and replacement with the
next solution – polymeric or for washing.
10.2.4 Construction of the multilayer shells and microcapsule formation
The CaCO3 sacrificial templates were immersed alternately in solutions of CHI and one of the ELRs
(300 µg?mL -1
, pH 5.5, 0.15 M NaCl) for 10 min under mild stirring. Each adsorption step was followed
by three washing steps with 0.15 M NaCl, pH 5.5: to disaggregate the substrates, the first was
accompanied by four sequential ultrasound pulses of 3 seconds each, with the following being just
rinsed. This process was repeated until 2 CHI/ELR bilayers were assembled. After the construction of
the multilayers, the CaCO3 core was dissolved by EDTA, at 0.2 M, pH 5.5. From this point on, the
precipitation of the microcapsules was aided by centrifugation steps (1000 rpm, 25 min) and
ultrasound pulses timed as described above. The newly formed hollow microcapsules then followed a
washing procedure with EDTA (0.2 M, pH 7.4) and four with ultrapure water. The microcapsules were
stored at room temperature until use for a maximum of 24 h in a renewed medium of ultrapure water.
In the case of microcapsules intended for cellular assays – loaded with DQ-ovalbumin – DMEM was
Chapter 10 – Cellular uptake of multilayered capsules produced with biomimetic and genetically
engineered macromolecules
343
used for the washings and storage instead of water. The microcapsule production yield resulting from
the mixture of 1 mL of Na2CO3 and CaCl2 was estimated to be with a total of 1.1×10 6 microcapsules
by microscopy observation.
10.2.5 Characterization of the hybrid microcapsules
The morphology of the produced microcapsules – designated (CHI/ELR-RGD)2 and (CHI/ELR-RDG (-)
)2 –
was determined using an environmental scanning electron microscopy (ESEM) (FEI Quanta 200FEG). A
number of 2.2×10 4 microcapsules suspended in 200 ?L of H2O was placed on top of a silicon wafer
(1 cm 2 ) and dried overnight at 37ºC before the analysis. The samples were placed inside the
equipment in a platform with a 20º tilt. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained
using a JEOL JEM-1011 HR instrument operating at 80 kV. Prior to the observation, a number of 10 4
microcapsules suspended in 60 ?L of H2O was pipetted onto a TEM grid and left to dry overnight at
room temperature. A confocal laser scanning microscope (CLSM, Olympus FV1000, Germany) was
used to evaluate the morphology of the microcapsules. For this, a final solution of a cationic dye
(rhodamine B, 10 -6
M) was further adsorbed after the normal construction of the microcapsules. All
samples were stabilized at 37°C and observed under hydrated conditions. The fluorescence intensity
profiles of 3 distinct microcapsules were plotted using ImageJ software (to assess the formation of
spherical hollow structures (provided by NIH, version 1.47v).
10.2.6 Cell culture
hMSCs were cultured in DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS and 100 U?mL -1
penicillin, 0.1 mg?mL -1
streptomycin replaced every two day and maintained at 37ºC in a 5% carbon dioxide (CO2) humidified
environmental chamber. Near-confluence cells (passages 2–6) were harvested after enzymatically
treatment with trypsin/EDTA or Accutase TM
and suspended in culture medium, cell counts were
evaluated using a standard Trypan Blue exclusion assay and seeded at 3×10 3
cell?cm -2
on the diverse
surfaces utilized and then incubated during 24 hours in standard conditions. Afterwards, the culture
medium was refreshed by serum-free medium containing a suspension of CHI/ELR microcapsules.
After 3 h of CHI/ELR microcapsules co-incubation, the cultures were maintained for longer times, by
supplementing the microcapsule suspension with additional fresh medium to reach the final serum
concentration of 2% FBS.

10.2.7 Cell viability assays
Metabolic activity was evaluated by Alamar Blue ® and cell viability by LIVE/DEAD® assays. The relative
number of hMSCs metabolically active within each experimental condition was evaluated by the Alamar
Blue ® assay according to the manufacturer guidelines. Briefly, 24 hours after cells seeding, cells culture
was washed and then (CHI/ELR-RGD)2 and (CHI/ELR-RDG (-)
)2 microcapsules in serum-free culture
medium were added in incremental ratios of 5 to 100 microcapsules per cell. After 3 and 72 h of
microcapsules co-incubation, the fluorimetric reduction of 10% Alamar Blue ® reagent in culture medium
was measured with a microtiter plate reader (SpectraMax M2e Molecular Devices). Non-treated cells
were employed as positive control and their fluorescence was considered as the 100% of cells viability.
The viability of cells co-incubated with CHI/ELR was also examined by a LIVE/DEAD ® assays. Ten
microcapsules per cell of each CHI/ELR microcapsule type were added to the cell culture. The ratio of
microcapsules per cell was selected after obtaining the results of the cell viability assays. In this assay,
the co-incubation with calcein AM and ethidium homodimer-1 allows distinguishing the cytoplasm of live
cells (with esterase cleavage of calcein accompanied by green fluorescence), and dead cells (which
compromised membranes enable to stain nucleic acids with red fluorescence). LIVE/DEAD ® assays was
carried out at different time points (0, 72 and 240 h) according to the manufacturing specifications.
10.2.8 Statistical analysis
Values reported reflect means±standard error (SE) of four samples of four independent cell culture
viability experiments at 3 or 72 hours of incubation. The influence of microcapsules/cell ratio on cell
viability was analyzed using one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) and the post test of Bonferroni. All
treatment-related effects were considered to be statistically significant at p-value less than 0.05. All data
was analyzed using GraphPad Prism 6.0 (GraphPad Software, Inc., La Jolla, CA).
10.2.9 Internalization and intracellular processing experiments
hMSCs were seeded on circular cover glasses (diameter: 10 mm; Thermo Scientific CB00100RA1)
deposited in a 48-well plate and incubated during 24 h in standard conditions. (CHI/ELR-RGD)2 and
(CHI/ELR-RDG (-)
)2 microcapsules were added to the culture. After 3 or 72 h of incubation, samples
were washed with DPBS three times.

Samples for microscopy analysis – confocal, phase-contrast, epifluorescence, and differential
interference contrast (DIC) microscopy (Nomarski) – were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde for 10 min,
permeabilized with 0.2% Triton X-100, and stained with DAPI. A confocal microscope (Leica
Microsystems, Heidelberg GmbH, microscope confocal Leica SP5) was used for analyzing
microcapsules inside the cells. Z-series were performed with a Z-step of 1 µm. The images of each
fluorophore and phase contrast were overlaid to obtain a multilayer image using ImageJ software
(National Institutes of Health). Bright field and fluorescence microscopy were performed in a NIKON
Eclipse Ti fluorescence microscope, equipped with a digital camera system (Digital sight DS-2MBWc),
using blue, green and red filters.
