1.5×10 5 hMSCs were seeded in a 25 cm
2 flasks and cultured as described above. (CHI/ELR-RGD)2
and (CHI/ELR-RDG (-)
)2 microcapsules were added at a microcapsule-to-cell ratio of 10:1 and incubated
during 72 h. The cell cultures dissociated by Accutase TM
treatment – specially developed for gentle and
effective cell dissociation – were washed, counted, suspended in DPBS, 25 mM HEPES 5% FBS and
analyzed in a flow cytometer (Beckman Coulter). The assay was repeated three times. All treatment-

10.3 Results and discussion
First, CaCO3 microparticles were coated with two bilayers of chitosan and the ELRs containing either
the motif RGD or RDG. Hollow capsules were produced by their subsequent incubation with EDTA and
chelation of the sacrificial core – henceforth referred to as (CHI/ELR-RGD)2 or (CHI/ELR-RDG (-)
)2,
respectively. The morphology of the microcapsules was evaluated by CLSM and SEM, and the capsules’
wall by TEM (Figure 10.1). TEM (Figure 10.1A), which was used solely to observe the wall delimiting the
interior and exterior of the microcapsules, showed a multilayer shell that could be distinguished at the
borders of the structure. For the morphological analysis, the samples for microscopy observation were
prepared at 37ºC.
Chapter 10 – Cellular uptake of multilayered capsules produced with biomimetic and genetically
engineered macromolecules
346
Figure 10.1. (A) Representative TEM image of a microcapsule showing a detail of the multilayer shell
delimited by the dashed lines. (B) CLSM micrograph of several microcapsules with the wall tagged with
rhodamine. Micrograph is representative of both (CHI/ELR-RGD)2 and (CHI/ELR-RDG (-)
)2 microcapsules.
(C) Fluorescence intensity plot profile of three individual microcapsules depicted in (B). The peaks
coincide with the capsules’ walls, while the plateau in between corresponds to the hollow interior. SEM
images of (D) (CHI/ELR-RGD)2 and (E) (CHI/ELR-RDG (-)
)2 microcapsules, with a vertical tilt of 20º.
It is known that this kind of polysaccharide/polypeptide microcapsules experience size variations
according to the temperature of the incubation medium. Costa et al. [36] demonstrated that this class
of microcapsules have a diameter of 5.5 ?m at room temperature but shrink when incubated at 37ºC,
to around 3 ?m. Therefore, this temperature was chosen to prepare the samples and assess their
morphology under a temperature similar to that of a biological environment.
The preparation of individual polymeric capsules while avoiding aggregation is difficult but necessary for
applications that require cellular uptake and survival. Figure 10.1B shows several CHI/ELR
microcapsules observed under CLSM. All microcapsules showed diameters of 3–4 ?m and had their
own individual walls (which served as polymeric reservoirs for the rhodamine dye) and hollow interior
(hence not dyed after the 10 minutes treatment). The graphic in Figure 10.1C, where the fluorescence
intensity is plotted as a function of the length of the lines drawn, confirms that the interior was empty
and thus the dissolution of the CaCO3 core was successful. In Figure 10.1D, the morphological analysis
Chapter 10 – Cellular uptake of multilayered capsules produced with biomimetic and genetically
engineered macromolecules
347
of (CHI/ELR-RGD)2 microcapsules shows that the integrity of the wall was maintained through the
process of its construction to the moment of their use. This observation indicates that the used
operational conditions permitted to obtain individual spherical microstructures. No signs of aggregation
were found, what makes the produced microcapsules suitable for the subsequent cellular studies. In
Figure 10.1E, microcapsules made of CHI and the ELR-RDG (-)
can be observed. Unlike RGD, RDG is a
nonbioactive motif similar to RGD in all aspects, except for the position of the G and D amino acids. As
such, the scrambled RDG sequence was previously shown to have significantly less cellular adhesion in
respect to its functional RGD counterpart [37,38]. These microcapsules resembled in morphology and
size the (CHI/ELR-RGD)2 microcapsules (Figure 10.1D). With such similarity, it was expectable that
differences in the mechanism and efficacy of internalization of these two microcapsule types – if any –
would be solely caused by their peptide sequence bioactivity rather than by a morphological
discrepancy.
Mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) are hypoimmunogenic and pluripotent able to differentiate in in vitro,
ex vivo and in vivo, into multiple cells types such as osteocytes, adipocytes, chondrocytes, neurocytes,
hepatocytes, myocytes, and hematopoietic-supporting stroma. These characteristics have been
considered crucial factors when aiming to develop new candidates for clinical use, especially in tissue
engineering and regenerative medicine applications, such as transplantation, local implantation, gene
therapy, and drug delivery [39,40]. Cellular therapies in particular can be envisaged in order to
internalize molecules with the aim to control cellular behavior, such as the induced differentiation of
MSCs into osteoblasts [41]. Therefore, the option to use hMSCs in a model of internalization of
CHI/ELR microcapsules could open the direct applicability of the methodology described herein.
In order to demonstrate if this kind of hybrid nanostructured microcapsules are suitable for biological
applications, we analyzed the in vitro viability of hMSCs by means of their metabolic activity in the
presence of (CHI/ELR-RGD)2 and (CHI/ELR-RDG (-)
)2. We studied the dose-dependent response effect
for two experimental times: 3 h and 72 h. hMSCs were co-incubated with increasing microcapsule/cell
ratios within a range of 5 to 100 units per cell. In Figure 2, the cell viability is represented normalized in
respect to the positive control, that is, cells cultured without microcapsules. As observed in Figure
10.2A and Figure 10.2B, after 3 h and 72 h of incubation with (CHI/ELR-RGD)2, the metabolic activity
did not vary significantly for the studied ratio range in respect to the positive control.

In order to determine if this class of hybrid microcapsules could be internalized by cells, hMSCs were
co-incubated first with (CHI/ELR-RGD)2 for 72 h. To aid in this microscopy visualization, the
microcapsules were loaded with DQ-ovalbumin. This commercially available product is a conjugate of
ovalbumin heavily labeled with BODIPY dyes. Due to a characteristic self-quenching mechanism, it
exhibits a bright red fluorescence characterized by the close proximity of the fluorescent dyes, but it
shifts to a strong green upon proteolysis. This means that it would be possible to follow the
internalization of the microcapsules and the intracellular processing of the cargo by fluorescence assays.
Confocal microscopy (Figure 10.5) confirmed the presence of internalized RGD-functionalized
microcapsules after 72 h of incubation. A yellow color (resulting from the simultaneous fluorescence
emission of red and green) could be observed in different planes of the cells, evidencing that the
microcapsules containing DQ-ovalbumin were processed by the hMSCs. In Figure 10.5A, the arrows
point to bright green dots, indicating the presence of fully degraded microcapsules. To reflect upon the
electrostatic interactions between capsules and cellular membrane, the charges of ELR-RGD and
ELR-RDG (-)
in aqueous solution were determined by ?-potential measurements. They were shown to
have a charge of -5.7±1.2 mV and -6.3±1.2 mV, respectively, in PBS. One could argue that the negative
charge of the ELR outer layer could potentially hinder the internalization by conflicting with the
electrostatic nature of the cellular membrane [45]. However, electrostatic interactions alone were
previously unable to account for cellular adhesion to surfaces modified with polycations [46] and thus is
expected to have little influence in comparison to the bioactive properties of the used macromolecules.
Therefore, these results show that cellular uptake of CHI/ELR microcapsules can be achieved and that
their intracellular degradation can be followed by the used fluorophore.

Our results indicate that the internalization of LbL microcapsules is not affected significantly when
coupled with biofunctional components, contrary to what was demonstrated by other authors.[48,49]
For instance, Caruso and coworkers [48] showed that poly(styrene sulfonate)/poly(allylamine
hydrochloride) (PSS/PAH) capsules (around 500 nm in diameter) functionalized with humanized A33
monoclonal antibodies could be internalized specifically by LIM1215 colorectal cancer cells. However,
in another work, De Koker et al. [50] inhibited different endocytic pathways and actin polymerization in
bone-marrow-derived dendritic cells. Their results demonstrated that microcapsules with around 3 ?m
are internalized via macropinocytosis – a nonspecific endocytosis mechanism for foreign materials
roughly between 500–2000 nm [51]. Therefore it is likely that macropinocytosis was the major
endocytosis mechanism involved in the cellular uptake of carrier devices of this class and size (around
3–4 ?m in diameter), to which surface functionalization does not play a determinant role.
Upon internalization of a drug carrier, it is important to ensure that the agent is not only delivered but
also available for use by cells. Thanks to the use of DQ-ovalbumin, the consumption of this cargo by
cells could be conveniently assessed by fluorescence changes. After quantifying the cellular uptake, the
bioavailability of DQ-ovalbumin was evaluated by co-incubating cultured hMSCs with each kind of
microcapsules in parallel for 3 and 72 h. In Figure 10.7, representative bright-field and fluorescence
microscope images can be observed for (CHI/ELR-RGD)2 and (CHI/ELR-RDG (-)
)2 microcapsules loaded
with DQ-ovalbumin. The schematic representation in Figure 10.7A shows the various stages of cellular
uptake and intracellular processing of encapsulated protein. Until the cargo reaches a fully degraded
state, the intensity of green fluorescence increases and red decreases: their simultaneous emission
results in the orange and yellow intermediate colors observable under the fluorescence microscope.

After 72 h of incubation, a higher amount of microcapsules were detected interacting with the cells, in
comparison to the shorter time-point, with a predominant presence of yellow capsules found in the case
of hMSCs incubated with RGD-functionalized microcapsules and red capsules in the case of cells
incubated with the non-functional analogue ones. This observation indicates that, even after 72 h of
incubation, distinct stages of microcapsule/cell internalization and intracellular processing could be
found. However, judging by the intense yellow and occasional green dots in Figure 10.7C, the
bioavailability of DQ-ovalbumin encapsulated within (CHI/ELR-RGD)2 microcapsules seemed higher.
The microscopy comparison between both types of microcapsules (Figure 10.7) seems to indicate that
both (CHI/ELR-RGD)2 and (CHI/ELR-RDG (-)
)2 situations bear little difference in respect to the number of
apparent internalized carriers. Nonetheless, a dominant emission fluorescence towards the green
spectrum – that of cleaved DQ-ovalbumin – was dominant in the former. This result shows that the
cargo of RGD-functionalized microcapsules was processed faster, evidencing a higher bioavailability of
DQ-ovalbumin for this carrier type. In this sense, the bioavailability rate of the cargo does not follow the
results from the cellular uptake quantification shown in Figure 10.6: the internalization efficacy does not
seem much influenced by the surface functionalization, whereas the intracellular processing of their
cargo does. The study of the internalization mechanism and intracellular processing has not been much
researched. It is true that the role of macropinocytosis was previously demonstrated [50] but it is known
that functionalizing an interface can mediate specific integrin interactions [52]. Given that the surface
functionalization in this work had little influence in the internalization efficacy, one would expect that the
degradation of their cargo would be similar after the studied time of exposure. It could be suggested
that the distinct functionality of the adsorbed recombinamers triggers distinct proteolytic pathways, just
as RGD may active proliferation- and differentiation-related integrins. However, the study of such
mechanism was out of the scope of this work. Such mechanism should be studied in the future in order
to properly determine carrier and cargo fates upon cellular uptake, especially for carriers of the same
class internalized by similar endocytic mechanisms. With these results, we conclude that CHI/ELR
microcapsules can be internalized by hMSCs, regardless of their surface functionalization, and may act
as suitable carriers for the intracellular delivery of active agents.
10.4 Conclusion
We presented the fabrication of multilayer microcapsules made of natural and nature-inspired polymers
for intracellular delivery of active agents. Thanks to the nature of the constituents, the microcapsules
Chapter 10 – Cellular uptake of multilayered capsules produced with biomimetic and genetically
engineered macromolecules
357
were noncytotoxic as their degradation does not result in harmful products for the cells. Cellular uptake
was demonstrated, showing their potential as carriers for drug delivery directly to the cellular machinery.
In the future, this way of delivery may help minimizing drug losses and increasing their delivery control
and efficacy. The internalization efficacy demonstrated for hMSCs lets foresee their use in cell/tissue
engineering and regenerative medicine where it is important to control the differentiation of stem cells
into specific phenotypes. This work confirmed that CHI/ELR microcapsules could interact and be
internalized by cells, but experiments with microcapsules loaded with actual active agents are envisaged,
such as molecules that trigger the differentiation of cells into specific phenotypes. The mechanism of
internalization of the microcapsules at this scale did not depend on the surface functionalization. They
were internalized via macropinocytosis although the ELR functionalization suggested a minor role of
integrin-mediated mechanisms. In this context, the recombinant nature of ELRs will be of interest to
further study the microcapsules’ endocytosis mechanism. In particular, it is possible that the production
of smaller capsules by using nanotemplates may increase the influence of RGD and facilitate
internalization [53]. The inclusion of bioactive motifs other than this generic motif may constitute a
strong advantage of using such recombinant technologies, allowing exploring not only specific
recognition processes but also degradation pathways for targeted delivery and increased drug efficacy.
Therefore, multilayer microcapsules using biomimetic ingredients for intracellular delivery let foresee
new strategies to increase the availability of molecules of interest in cells and for targeted biomedical
applications.

Chapter 11. Multifunctional compartmentalized capsules with a
hierarchical organization from the nano- to the macro-scales 11
Abstract
Inspired by the cells’ structure, we present compartmentalized capsules with temperature and
magnetic-based responsiveness, and hierarchical organization ranging from the nano- to the visible
scales. Liquefied alginate macroscopic beads coated with a layer-by-layer (LbL) chitosan/alginate shell
served as containers both for model fluorophores and microcapsules, which in their turn encapsulated
either another fluorophore or magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs). The microcapsules were coated with a
temperature responsive chitosan/elastin-like recombinamer (ELR) nanostructured shell. By varying the
temperature from 25ºC to 37ºC, the two-hour release of rhodamine encapsulated within the
microcapsules and its diffusion through the external compartment decreased from 84% and 71%. The
devices could withstand handling and centrifugal stress, with 50% remaining intact at a rotation speed
of 2000g. MNPs attributed magnetic responsiveness towards external magnetic fields. Such
customizable system can be envisaged to transport bioactive agents and cells in tissue engineering
applications.

11.1 Introduction
Considerable research efforts have been focused on miniaturized compartmental engineering systems
with optimized properties over the past decade due to their wealth of potential applications in fields
such as catalysis, sensors, drug delivery, disease models, energy storage and microreactors [1-3],
which often require complex phenomena to occur simultaneously. Such a multifunctional device that is
capable of addressing several reactions at once would, however, be difficult to develop. Perhaps not
surprisingly, nature gives us an elegant example of a multifunctional entity in the form of biological cells.
Due to their unique hierarchical and compartmentalized organization, they allow numerous compounds
to be transported, proteins to be synthesized and enzymatic reactions to be regulated within their
cytoplasm. However, building artificial cells is still a technology in its infancy. In an attempt to mimic
cells, a great deal of research has focused on hierarchical nano- and microcompartments [4-6]. Multi-
shelled organic and inorganic capsules prepared by template-assisted strategies are usually
accompanied by harsh processing conditions [7-9]. In contrast, compartmentalized assemblies of
polymeric multilayer nano/microcapsules within larger partitions have been achieved by using non-
aggressive bottom-up strategies [10-14]. In any case, compartmentalization has allowed combining
properties and confine reactions that could not be achieved otherwise with single-component
assemblies [4].
The most attractive characteristic of compartmentalized devices does not necessarily involve their
potential ability to mimic intracellular reactions, such as confining drugs and enzymatic reactions into
partitions [15-17]. Compartmental systems should ideally be customizable by assembling
subcompartments which exhibit functions that are not coupled naturally. Moreover, following a proper
selection of the constituents, the range of such functions could be widened by exploiting the properties
of stimuli-responsive materials [18]. Some examples that would benefit from such approach are the
release control of several biomolecules delivered simultaneously for enhanced drug delivery [19], the
immobilization of such a device spatially for targeted therapies [20], and the control over a multitude of
cellular events that lead to stem cell differentiation [21].
In our goal to construct a hierarchical multifunctional device, we aimed to demonstrate that both
molecular compounds and inorganic iron oxide magnetic nanoparticles can be encapsulated in distinct
compartments. We report the construction of liquefied microcapsule-containing gel beads manufactured
using a hybrid “ionic gelation” strategy of alginate assisted by a layer-by-layer (LbL) approach. LbL is a
Chapter 11. Multifunctional compartmentalized capsules with a hierarchical organization from the nano-
to the macro-scales
366
simple and versatile technique which allows producing robust coatings, even in substrates with complex
geometries. Because it discards the need of organic and harmful solvents, it is an attractive technique
for tissue engineering applications [22-24]. In three-dimensional structures, namely spherical capsules,
the semi-permeable nature of multilayer coatings can be used to tune the permeability of molecules of
interest in or out, or to completely confine them [13,25-27]. Herein, liquefied alginate macrocapsules
delimited by multilayer shells of chitosan/alginate (CHI/ALG) were intended to containing
microcapsules made of CHI/”elastin-like recombinamer (ELR)” inside. The latter, on their side,
contained either magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) or model molecular compounds, such as the model
low molecular weight fluorophores fluorescein isothiocyanate and rhodamine.
CHI and ALG are two well-known polysaccharides of marine origin which show biocompatibility,
adhesiveness, non-toxicity, as well as bacteriostatic, fungistatic, anti-microbial and hemostatic
activities [28,29]. ELRs, a recombinant type of elastin-like polymer (ELP), are temperature-responsive
polypeptides that are soluble in aqueous media below a specific critical transition temperature (Tt) but
undergo a phase separation above it [30-32]. Lastly, MNPs are structures susceptible to magnetic fields.
They are often used to enhance medical imaging diagnosis of soft tissues (e.g., magnetic resonance
imaging, MRI) and temperature-triggered treatments such as hyperthermia and tissue ablation [33-35].
In light of the potential applications of compartmentalized structures, we have studied the properties of
each of the structures that can be found at the nano-, micro- and macro-scales, the permeability of the
multilayer shells at distinct temperatures (namely the coatings containing the temperature-responsive
ELR) and the response to external magnetic fields. We hypothesized that such systems could be
fabricated and customized to display smart tunable permeability and spatial
mobilization/immobilization.
11.2 Experimental section
11.2.1 Materials
Medium molecular weight chitosan was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (ref 448877) and purified by a
series of filtration and precipitation in water and ethanol steps, adapted from the method described by
Signini and Filho [36], followed by freeze-drying. The degree of deacetylation was determined to be 82%
(Supplemental Figure 11.1). Alginic acid sodium salt from brown algae was purchased from Sigma-
Aldrich (ref 71238) and used as received.
Chapter 11 – Multifunctional compartmentalized capsules with a hierarchical organization from the
nano- to the macro-scales
367
11.2.2 Bioproduction of the elastin-like recombinamers
An ELR containing a L-arginine-glycine-L-aspartic acid (RGD) motif was bioproduced using a
fermentation process from an Escherichia coli strain BLR(DE3) containing an appropriate expression
gene, obtained using an appropriate protocol for gene design [37]. After fermentation, the culture was
harvested and lysed by ultrasonic disruption. Insoluble debris was removed by centrifugation and the
cleared lysate was subjected to several cycles of cold (4ºC) and warm (40ºC) centrifugations, at
10000 rpm for 10 minutes each. Finally, the polymer was dialyzed against ultra-pure Milli-Q water at
4°C in dialysis membranes with a 12 kDa molecular weight cut-off for a minimum of 6 hours, after
which the water was changed. After 4 changes of water, the biopolymer was frozen and freeze-dried.
Characterization of the bioproduct was done previously [22,38].
11.2.3 Synthesis of magnetic nanoparticles
In a typical synthesis to synthesize spherical iron oxide MNPs, 10 mL of a solution containing 1.2 g of
iron(III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3?6H2O, Sigma-Aldrich ref. 236489) and 0.6 g of iron(II) chloride
tetrahydrate (FeCl2?4H2O, Sigma-Aldrich ref 220299) was added drop-wise to 25 mL of ammonium
hydroxide solution (NH4OH, made of 33% ammonia, NH3, in H2O) over 4 h under an inert nitrogen
atmosphere. The products of the reaction were collected by magnetic separation and washed three
times with ethanol and water. The last washing step was made with ethanol, after which the products
were left to dry at room temperature.
11.2.4 Characterization of the MNPs
The shape and morphology of the magnetite nanoparticles were determined using high resolution
transmission electronic microscope (TEM, JEOL JEM-1011, operating at 200 kV). Samples were
prepared by dropping a dilute aqueous solution (concentration = 1 mg?mL -1
) of the nanoparticles onto a
200-mesh copper grid and allowing the solvent to evaporate. The magnetization of the MNPs was
measured as a function of the applied external magnetic field (maximum value 10 kOe) using a
vibrating sample magnetometer (PPMS, Quantum Design) at 300 K.
Chapter 11. Multifunctional compartmentalized capsules with a hierarchical organization from the nano-
to the macro-scales
368
11.2.5 Temperature-induced aggregate measurements
The aggregate sizes of chitosan, alginate and ELR in solution were measured using the dynamic light
scattering (DLS) from a Nano-ZS from Malvern (United Kingdom) for temperatures 25ºC/37°C after
stabilization for 5 min. The samples of alginate and ELR were prepared at 300 µg?mL -1
in
phosphate-buffered solution (PBS), pH 7.4. In the case of chitosan, the solvent was acetic acid at
1% (w/v) and sodium chloride (NaCl) concentration of 0.15 M, pH 5.5. Measurements were performed
first at 25ºC, then 37ºC and finally back at 25ºC. A total of 20 runs were performed for each sample to
obtain an average value at stabilized temperature.
11.2.6 Synthesis of the calcium carbonate sacrificial particles, either empty or
entrapping fluorophores/MNPs
Aqueous solutions of anhydrous sodium carbonate (Na2CO3, Sigma-Aldrich ref 222321) and calcium
chloride (CaCl2, VWR ref 1.02378.0500) were prepared at 1 M. In a typical co-precipitation reaction,
100 ?g of a desired material was entrapped in a medium of 200 µL of H2O by adding 100 µL of
Na2CO3 followed by 100 µL of CaCl2 with rapid stirring for 30 seconds. The H2O precipitation medium
contained the material to be entrapped at a concentration of 500 ?g?mL -1
. Three distinct ingredients
were added to the H2O precipitation medium: fluorescein-5(6)-isothiocyanate (FITC, 389 Da, Sigma-
Aldrich ref F3651), rhodamine-B isothiocyanate (Rhod, 536 Da, Sigma-Aldrich ref R1755) and MNPs.
As a control, empty microcapsules were also fabricated by using solely ultrapure H2O. Stirring was
stopped after 30 s and the suspension of newly synthesized calcium carbonate (CaCO3) microparticles
left to react and precipitate for 15 min. The supernatant was then removed and the particles washed
twice with ultrapure water to remove residual salts and non-entrapped materials. Unless stated
otherwise, all supernatants were retained for fluorescence measurements and quantification of losses
until the construction of compartmental capsules was completed.
11.2.7 Construction of the microparticle multilayer coating
The CaCO3 sacrificial templates (empty or entrapping either a fluorophore or MNP) were immersed
alternately in CHI and ELR solutions (300 µg?mL -1
, pH 5.5, 0.15 M of NaCl) for 10 min each, then
washed with 0.15 M NaCl (pH 5.5 at 0.15 M). Centrifugation was avoided to prevent damage and
aggregation of the particles each time the samples were to be retrieved from solution; simple
Chapter 11 – Multifunctional compartmentalized capsules with a hierarchical organization from the
nano- to the macro-scales
369
precipitation of the suspension was used instead (3 to 5 min). This process was repeated until three
bilayers had been assembled, (CHI/ELR)3. For the sole purpose of confocal microscopy
characterization described below, the CaCO3 cores were chelated at this point by immersion in
ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA, Sigma-Aldrich ref E9884; 0.2 M, pH 5.5) for 30 min.
11.2.8 Construction of multilayer coated external subcompartment-containing
beads
A 1% (w/v) solution of alginic acid sodium salt was prepared. In a typical experiment, the
(CHI/ELR)3-coated microparticles were suspended in 1 mL of alginate solution and the resulting
suspension extruded through a 25G needle, at a rate of 0.33 mL?min -1
, into a 0.75% (w/v) solution of
CaCl2 under mild stirring. Alginate beads containing coated microparticles were formed by calcium-
mediated ionic gelation. The beads were immersed alternately in CHI and ALG solutions (300 µg?mL -1
,
pH 5.5, 0.15 M NaCl) for 10 minutes each, then washed with 0.15 M NaCl (pH 5.5 at 0.15 M). This
process was repeated until three bilayers had been assembled, (CHI/ALG)3. After the coating had been
assembled, the beads were immersed in EDTA. At this point, the CaCO3 sacrificial templates are
chelated simultaneously with the liquefied alginate bead.
Liquefied alginate beads coated with (CHI/ALG)3 multilayers loaded with not only empty microcapsules
and Rhod in the ALG medium were also constructed. Rhod was suspended alongside the empty
microcapsules and encapsulated in the ALG bead compartment instead of in the inner microcapsules.
In a typical experiment, Rhod was suspended in ALG at 15 ?g?mL -1
. This value was determined by first
calculating the construction losses resulting from the Rhod-loaded microcapsules within the external
alginate macrocapsule in order to minimize concentration-dependent artifacts (see Supplemental Figure
11.3 for details).
11.2.9 Characterization of the compartmental units
The morphology of the FITC-loaded (CHI/ELR)3 microcapsules was determined using an Olympus
FV1000 confocal microscope (Germany). TEM images of both empty and MNP-loaded microcapsules
were obtained using a JEOL JEM-1011 HR instrument operating at 80 kV. Prior to the observation, a
volume of 60 ?L of microcapsule suspension was pipetted onto a transmission electron microscopy
(TEM) grid and left to evaporate overnight. An Axioimager Z1M Zeiss microscope (Germany) was used to
Chapter 11. Multifunctional compartmentalized capsules with a hierarchical organization from the nano-
to the macro-scales
370
observe (CHI/ALG)3-coated liquefied beads using transmitted light and fluorescence microscopy for
Rhod-loaded external compartments. The latter also containing FITC-loaded microcapsules were
observed to assess the distribution of the subcompartments within the macrocapsules.
11.2.10 Mechanical resistance of the external compartments
A centrifugal rotation test was performed with the samples suspended in PBS to measure the
mechanical resistance of the (CHI/ALG)3 macrocapsules. 100 samples were placed in centrifuge tubes
and rotated at a starting centrifugal load of 500g. After 5 min, the number of intact beads was counted.
Those that remained intact were submitted to incremental centrifugal loads (500g incremental steps)
up to a maximum of 5000g. This experiment was performed three times.
11.2.11 Rhodamine release studies
The compartmentalized systems were suspended in PBS at either 25 or 37ºC. Prior to this study, Rhod
was encapsulated in one of two hierarchical locations: the internal (CHI/ELR)3 microcapsules (with
Rhod added during the co-precipitation stage) or the external liquefied alginate (CHI/ALG)3-coated
macrocapsules (with Rhod added to the initial alginate solution). The study was conducted for 2 h to
assess the early release profile in 3 mL of PBS, with 600 ?L of surrounding PBS being removed every
10 min and the container being refilled with the same volume of PBS pre-stabilized at the
corresponding temperature. 100% of Rhod was considered to be the total mass remaining in the
compartmental systems after taking construction losses into account. The studies were performed three
times (n=3).
11.2.12 Magnetic-based responsiveness
Macrocapsules containing MNP-loaded microcapsules were suspended in a PBS-filled square
polystyrene Petri dish placed upon a 1×1 cm 2 grid. A 1.3 T permanent neodymium (NdFeB) bar
magnet (diameter: 4 mm; length: 2.5 cm) was used to apply the external magnetic field. Ten samples
were placed 3 cm away from the magnet, with the latter placed at a height of 1.4 cm from the PBS
surface. The movement was recorded on video and the mean normalized distance traversed by the
samples plotted as a function of time.

11.3 Results and discussion
The conception of a multifunctional compartmentalized device may involve using several ingredients
from distinct classes of materials, depending on the functionalities desired from a system of this kind,
and require a huge number of fabrication operations. An illustration of the proposed system is
illustrated in Figure 11.1.
Figure 11.1. Hierarchical organization of the multicompartmental capsules. Liquefied alginate beads,
delimited by a (CHI/ALG)3 coating, are visible to the naked eye. Multilayer microcapsules of (CHI/ELR)3
and molecular compounds can be suspended within the aqueous polymer phase. The former can
further contain other types of molecular compounds and MNPs.
The borders between compartments consist of multilayer shells with three bilayers for the purpose of
proof of concept. Our proposition comprises the fabrication of alginate beads by calcium-promoted ionic
gelation separated from the environment by a multilayer coating of three CHI and ALG layers,
(CHI/ALG)3, with thickness around 40 nm [39]. Prior to ionic gelation, the microscopic
subcompartments are suspended in an ALG solution to form beads containing small spherical
structures. These microcapsules are templated in CaCO3 microspheres and delimited by a coating of
three CHI and ELR layers, (CHI/ELR)3, with thickness around 25 nm [22]. In the subcompartments we
encapsulated further components of smaller scales – fluorophores and MNPs. Since the synthesis of
the CaCO3 templates results from the co-precipitation of equimolar solutions of Na2CO3 and CaCl2,
various substances can be added to the co-precipitation medium and entrapped within it. After the
Chapter 11. Multifunctional compartmentalized capsules with a hierarchical organization from the nano-
to the macro-scales
372
assembly of all compartments, the inorganic template is removed by treatment with EDTA, which also
liquefies the alginate bead to a highly viscous medium. The final product is an external macrocapsule
containing internal microcapsules – henceforth referred to as external (EC) and internal compartments
(IC), respectively – with each partition being delimited by multilayer membranes.
To ensure that we could assemble structures from different size scales, the hierarchical organization of
the proposed system was characterized initially. MNPs, ICs and ECs were observed resorting to distinct
microscopy techniques and are shown in Figure 11.2. Note that for every experiment performed, ECs
are always loaded with empty ICs, i.e., without any fluorophore encapsulated, unless otherwise
specified. Using TEM, the MNPs (Figure 11.2a) were found to have a diameter of about 10 nm which,
along with the model molecular compounds, represents the smallest scale present in this system. FITC
was encapsulated within (CHI/ELR)3 microcapsules and could be observed by confocal laser scanning
microscopy (CLSM) upon removal of the CaCO3 template (Figure 11.2b). We have previously
constructed multilayer films made of chitosan and ELRs. Characterization of this ELR – amino acid
sequence, matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization-time of flight (MALDI-TOF), and differential
scanning calorimetry (DSC) – which contains a RGD motif, can be found elsewhere.[22,38]
Although used previously to enhance cell adhesion, the primary reason for using this specific ELR
herein was to enable LbL construction due to the negative charge provided by the aspartic acids (D),
with a pKa ranging from 3.0–4.7 [40], thus exploiting the biological function of this sequence was not in
the scope of this work. The average size of the ICs was 3 ?m, what places them at a microscale level.
The external compartments act as containers where both ICs and molecular compounds can be
entrapped. Encapsulation of the fluorescent molecule Rhod showed that the (CHI/ALG)3 macrocapsules
have a diameter of 2 mm (Figure 11.2c) and are therefore representative of the visible scale.

Figure 11.2. Scales of hierarchical components. (a) TEM image of MNPs; (b) CLSM image of FITC-
containing (CHI/ELR)3 microcapsules; (c) fluorescence microscopy image of the Rhod-containing
liquefied ALG bead coated with (CHI/ALG)3.
The proposed formulation contains ingredients that respond to external stimuli. Namely, the polymeric
constituent ELR is known to respond to temperature, while MNPs to magnetic fields. These properties
were studied and the results are presented in Figure 11.3. The response to temperature of the
polymers used herein – CHI, ALG and ELR – was assessed by means of aggregate size measurements
at 25ºC and 37ºC. In Figure 11.3a, it is shown that the size of ELR aggregates at 25ºC is about
200 nm. In contrast to this situation, at 37ºC aggregates of around 2000 nm were formed due to the
temperature transition of ELRs above their Tt (in Supplemental Figure 11.2, the Tt was determined to
be 29ºC).
Chapter 11. Multifunctional compartmentalized capsules with a hierarchical organization from the nano-
to the macro-scales
374
Figure 11.3. Stimuli-responsiveness of the multicompartmental device constituents. (a) aggregate size
measurements by DLS of CHI (pH 5.5), ALG and ELR (pH 7.4) at 300 µg?mL -1
for a temperature cycle
of 25–37–25ºC; (b) magnetization assay of MNPs.
Upon decreasing the temperature to 25ºC once again, it was observed that the aggregate size
decreases to around 300 nm, confirming that the polypeptide used herein exhibits a reversible
response towards temperature. Thus, the use of ELRs in such multilayer coatings may mean that the
permeability of the subcompartments can be tuned simply by switching between room and
physiological temperatures. As expected, CHI and ALG were not significantly influenced, since they are
not temperature-responsive. For CHI, the working pH was of 5.5, as the pKa of this polysaccharide is
around 6. Nonetheless, CHI is not a temperature responsive biomaterial, therefore pH is not expected
to alter its response to this variable. The use of temperature responsive macromolecules could help in
controlling the permeability of a carrier coating based on temperature variations, when the release of a
specific molecular compound needs to be more sustained or pronounced. At the same time, the use of
CHI and ALG allows herein the assembly of a static coating, i.e. that is not stimuli-responsive under the
temperature-dependent experimental conditions used further on, used solely for the purpose of
encapsulating the rest of the components in its interior.
The other constituent of this system are MNPs. Magnetization measurements with the MNPs are shown
in Figure 11.3b. Magnetic particles can be classified as ferromagnetic and
paramagnetic/superparamagnetic. Whereas the former exhibit a permanent magnetic dipole moment,
with a paramagnetic particle a magnetic dipole moment is induced only when an external magnetic field
is applied [41-44]. The MNPs showed a saturation magnetization of 40 emu?g -1
and the typical
sigmoidal curve of superparamagnetic nanoparticles, thereby confirming their response to magnetic
fields and potential use for spatial mobilization/immobilization of a host device. In particular, it is known
Chapter 11 – Multifunctional compartmentalized capsules with a hierarchical organization from the
nano- to the macro-scales
375
that the success in therapeutic applications of growth factors often requires a release system for
delivery with spatiotemporal control [45]. Thus the magnetic component may help achieving a better
efficacy of the encapsulated agent and reduce losses to surrounding fluids.
Another important characteristic of these systems is their mechanical resistance. The ECs are visible to
the naked eye and can therefore easily be handled. However, it is important to determine whether the
external LbL coating can withstand handling whilst retaining the liquefied ALG. The integrity of the
(CHI/ALG)3 coating was assessed by submitting the macrocapsules to incremental centrifugal stress.
Figure 11.4 shows that these macrocapsules can withstand centrifugal stress, with 50% of them
remaining intact at a rotation speed of 2000g.

The separate fluorescent channels are shown (Figure 11.5b and Figure 11.5c). It is clear that the ICs
are homogeneously distributed in the ALG liquefied medium, showing that a compartmentalized
structure is definitely conceived.
To further explore the permeability of the compartments, early release studies were performed by
loading either the ICs or the ECs with Rhod and plotting the cumulative release of this compound from
the (CHI/ELR)3 and (CHI/ALG)3 compartments at 25ºC (Figure 11.6a) and 37ºC (Figure 11.6b) as a
function of time. One important finding from this study was that the release of Rhod encapsulated in the
ICs was more sustained at 37ºC than at 25ºC (84% and 71%, respectively, after 2 h). This phenomenon
results from the temperature response of the ELR: at the temperature of 37ºC – above Tt – its transition
to a more ordered state is triggered and is manifested by the decrease in the shell permeability, an
effect previously demonstrated for CHI- and ELR-based microcapsules entrapping bovine serum
albumin (BSA) [46]. Such decreased permeability of the microcapsules can therefore be used as a
mechanism to control the release of molecular compounds. As such, it could be useful in the field of
sustained drug-delivery devices for targeting a therapeutic window, micro-reactors confining chemical
reactions, and sensors for the simultaneous detection of macromolecules or gases by diffusion (in or
out). It should also be noted that the release of Rhod from the ECs did not change significantly since
CHI and ALG are not temperature responsive (90% at 25ºC and 92% at 37ºC)

Another important finding was that the release of Rhod from the ICs decreased after an initial burst
detected at the first time-point. Namely, the Rhod release rate decreased between 10-20 minutes
(25ºC) and 10–30 minutes (37ºC), with this decrease being more pronounced in the latter case. This
could be due to the fact that molecules encapsulated within the microcompartmental system have to
diffuse through the IC coating to the alginate medium and then through the external coating to the
external environment. This would explain the existence of a time-gap that is not present when Rhod is
encapsulated within the ECs. Figure 11.7 depicts the proposed mechanism for the initial burst release
detected in the IC case.
We hypothesize that this phenomenon results from the release of Rhod by diffusion into the alginate
medium during construction of the ECs containing Rhod-loaded ICs, mainly at the chelation stage. At
the start of the release studies, this fraction would behave similarly to the EC case at the first time point,
with an initial burst similar in magnitude to that of the ECs. The remaining Rhod is released from the
ICs at a slower rate. In this regard, in Figure 11.5 we had separated the fluorescence channels of FITC
and Rhod. Indeed, immediately after construction of the multicompartmental device, there is a diffusion
of FITC throughout the alginate medium, as evidenced by diffuse green zones Figure 11.5b.

The existence of two release rate constants is consistent with the "double barrier" effect recently
evidenced by Lecommandoux and co-workers for polymersome-in-polymersome systems [47]. In their
work, doxorubicin was encapsulated in inner or outer compartments. The fabrication method differed
from our LbL mechanism: they were fabricated by nanoprecipitation and an emulsion/centrifugation
process, respectively. They observed lower release kinetics when doxorubicin was encapsulated within
the internal nanovesicles in comparison to the latter case.
Theoretically, if such initial burst did not occur, a more prolonged time-gap would be visible from the
beginning before Rhod from the ICs could be detected. This burst-type release is not necessarily a
drawback as some applications may benefit from it. For instance, a higher fraction of antibiotics/anti-
inflammatories can be released in the first few minutes after administration when they are most needed,
with the rest of the load being released subsequently within a therapeutic window. The release of more
than one molecule from a reservoir with independent and tunable rates may be important in drug
delivery systems, when the delayed delivery of one active substance with respect to another is desired,
or to circumvent premature drug leakage [48]. Moreover, tuning the release rate of a molecular species
could be accomplished further by varying the number of layers of the coating: a substance could diffuse
through the multilayers with higher release kinetics for thicker coatings, in comparison to a thinner

the delivery of therapeutic molecules, other applications have been proposed in fields ranging from

Empty microcapsules were used as a control for MNP-loaded ones. In comparison, Figure 11.8b shows
empty ICs, where no spherical structure could be detected. As they are empty and the electronic
density is lower than MNP-containing ICs, the multilayer shell can be discerned, with creases and folds
which are characteristic of collapsed ultrathin walls due to the drying process.
In light of our initial findings, we conducted an experiment where MNP-containing ICs were loaded into
ECs and attracted by a magnet placed at a distance of 3 cm (Figure 11.8c). This strategy adds further
value to the proposed device in terms of biomimetism. Besides its multicompartmental nature inspired
by natural cells and self-assembly mechanism of constituents in which the LbL strategy is based upon,
the use of MNPs can be considered to be a biomimetic approach inspired by unique structures with
magnetic properties, such as magnetotactic bacteria [49-51]. Magnetic alginate beads have been used
previously for applications such as water pollution remediation [52] and magnetic hyperthermia-
enhanced doxorubicin release [53], although the magnetic character was not exploited primarily for

to the macro-scales
380
spatial mobilization. It took 42 s for all the beads to travel this distance and be completely immobilized.
As soon as the magnetic compartmental units were exposed to the external magnetic field, they
became attracted to the position at which the maximum magnetic field value was available to them at
the surface of the PBS medium. As they got closer to the magnet they were exposed to a stronger
magnetic field and the attraction increased. Movement stopped abruptly once they reached the position
below where the magnet was placed. The normalized mean distance traveled by MNP-loaded ICs within
ECs is represented in Supplemental Figure 11.4. This observation shows how the internal
subcompartments can be customized to possess distinct functions, including distinct types of smart
responsiveness. Specifically, the entrapment of superparamagnetic nanoparticles within microcapsules
could be envisaged for applications that require immobilization, such as localized therapies, and
magnetic resonance imaging. The developed devices should also permit the incorporation of living
microorganisms and cells inside the EC, as its processing is performed in mild conditions [39].
11.4 Conclusion
In conclusion, we presented a multifunctional system characterized by hierarchical organized spherical
compartments. We showed that compartmentalized structures delimited by multilayer coatings can be
customized to exhibit properties that are not found coupled in nature. Although the present work was
limited to the proof of concept, we envisage that it can be improved in the future. Namely, the
multilayer organization makes it possible to tune the permeability of the coatings just by changing the
number of layers. Other stimuli could be coupled together: for instance, temperature, pH or light (e.g.,
from the incorporation of azobenzenes or spiropyrans) could be combined for multifunctional
biosensors confining reactions. The genetic nature of ELRs further allows synthesizing biofunctional
polypeptides for advanced applications, such as increased cell adhesion or enhanced biomineralization.
Cells have been previously encapsulated within alginate beads, but we envision that coupling biological
material with functionality such as controlled release of growth factors and provision of adhesion sites
may improve cellular sustained survivability over time. Moreover, the addition of magnetic components
provides such compartmentalized system potential for biotechnological and biomedical applications
where spatial immobilization, high local availability of an active agent or monitoring by magnetic
imaging is required.

collected during entrapment, construction and chelation stages were measured and quantified. The
percentage Rhod loss was plotted for both each stage and cumulatively.
All the supernatants collected during the construction of Rhod-loaded compartments (either internal or
external ones) were used to calculate the losses occurred prior to the commencement of the actual
release studies. The graphic in Supplemental Figure 11.3 shows the stage and cumulative Rhod losses

following liquefaction of the bead. Furthermore, empty CaCO3-coated particles were loaded at the same
time to keep the same subcompartmental structure.

Chapter 12. Major conclusions and future perspectives
The surface modification technique known as layer-by-layer (LbL) was employed successfully in
accordance to the hypothesis of this thesis. Various substrates – both planar and three-dimensional –
were coated with natural or biomimetic polymeric constituents distinct in functionality but sharing
natural roots. It was then possible to develop multilayer devices intended for a wide range of biomedical
applications, namely adhesive films, coatings for biomaterials, drug delivery carriers – for delivery either
by drug diffusion or by cellular uptake – and microreactors with customizable properties.
First, it was demonstrated that multilayer films can retain and exhibit the properties of their natural
constituents. A phosphonate derivative of levan, a fructose polymer obtained from extremophilic
microorganisms, allowed fabricating multilayer films with chitosan (CHI) that exhibited superior
adhesive properties in comparison to a multilayer formulation of CHI and alginate (ALG) – two
polysaccharides of marine origin widely regarded as good adhesive ingredients. The advantage of using
levan was also evident by the superior cell adhesion to films containing this polymer, in comparison to
CHI/ALG films. Future developments of levan-functionalized multilayer films may include tests using
actual animal tissues to further evaluate their potential as wound healing coatings and tissue sealants
for post-surgical procedures.
Elastin-like recombinamers (ELRs) were used as a polypeptide constituent of most multilayer
formulations presented herein. Its genetic origin, rooted in natural elastin, allowed using constituents
exhibiting a precise amino acid content, sequence, length, and, most importantly, bioactivity. By using
an ELR containing the bioactive sequence arginine-glycine-aspartic acid (RGD), substrates with
enhanced cell adhesion were made. Given the multiple stimuli-responsive nature of ELRs, it was
demonstrated that, like in the case of levan, films containing these polypeptides also retained such
responsiveness, namely toward temperature, pH and ionic strength. Raising any of these parameters
above an upper threshold triggered the transition of the ELR adsorbed at the surface, leading it to
exhibit charged amino acids toward the interface. This phenomenon was translated by an increase of
hydrophilicity and surface roughness.
The buildup feasibility of this ELR-RGD with CHI in a multilayer structure was monitored in situ using a
quartz-crystal microbalance (QCM). Although a construction based on strong electrostatic interactions
was first anticipated, there was evidence that weaker hydrophobic interactions could play an important
role in this process between polysaccharides and polypeptide-based polymers. Resorting to the QCM
Chapter 12 – Major conclusion and future perspectives
394
and the mathematical Voigt-based model for viscoelastic films, several distinct ELRs were combined
with either CHI or ALG for the construction of hybrid films at distinct values of pH. The estimation of
each of the films’ thicknesses led to the conclusion that not only electrostatic but also hydrophobic
interactions drive the self-assembly of this type of multilayer films, judging by how thicker films could be
obtained when using partially neutralized polysaccharides. This result provides a consistent basis to the
development of future devices based on this class of coatings by ensuring that the best construction
parameters are used in order to achieve thick films across various scales – nano to micro – and
stability.
LbL extrapolation to 3D was successful in the form of spherical microcapsules of CHI and ELR for the
purpose of drug delivery, envisaging two forms of administration. The first consisted in the
pre-encapsulation of a high molecular weight protein, bovine serum albumin (BSA), within the
microcapsules and its release by diffusion under distinct temperatures. It was demonstrated that the
permeability of the multilayer shell was dependent on the temperature and on the number of layers.
Thanks to the incorporation of ELRs in the multilayer formulation, its temperature-triggered phase
transition led the microcapsules to be more retentive at physiological than at room temperature, a
phenomenon also accompanied by a significant shrinkage of the capsular structures. As expected, a
higher number of coating layers also provided a more effective barrier to the diffusion of the
encapsulated agent. The reduced release rate verified at physiological temperature may help in the
delivery of active agents (e.g., chemotherapeutics) that are necessary locally in small but controlled
doses, i.e., within a therapeutic window. Varying the number of layers provided an additional means of
control over the release kinetics, what helps further to achieve an appropriate drug release and
bioactivity. Future developments may investigate the potential use of these carriers for the delivery of
active agents instead of model proteins for a wide spectrum of molecular weights. Ideally, these should
be studied under sink conditions, which ensure that the release medium is not saturated by drug so
that its release is controlled solely by the delivery system and is not affected by its solubility.
The second mechanism consisted in the delivery of microcapsules directly to the interior of the cells,
where the whole cellular machinery is located. Using RGD- and RDG-functionalized microcapsules (with
the latter being a nonfunctional analogue of the former) it was possible to determine that the
mechanism of internalization of these capsules by human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs) was due
majorly to a mechanism of macropinocytosis and not due to the surface functionalization. This is an
important mechanism of drug delivery since the delivery of drug carriers directly to the cells diminishes
potential active agent losses to the extracellular environment by diffusion. Furthermore, drugs may be
Chapter 12 – Major conclusion and future perspectives
395
delivered to where they are most needed, ensuring a high drug availability and efficacy. However, the
intracellular degradation – hence potential drug availability – was faster for RGD-functionalized
microcapsules. Future experiments may focus on determining the mechanism behind the distinct
intracellular processing rates, which seemed dependent on the surface functionalization of the
microcapsules. Furthermore, growth factors and other differentiation agents may be encapsulated to
exploit stem cell differentiation mechanisms dependent on controllable dosages and carrier size.
Finally, it was shown that LbL allows achieving higher levels of functionalization, difficult to achieve
using the most conventional surface modification strategies. Macrocapsules observable with a naked
eye were delimited by CHI/ALG multilayers. This macrodevice exhibited compartmentalization and
hierarchical organization from the nano- to the macro-scales. ELR-functionalized microcapsules served
as microcompartments suspended within a confined ALG liquefied environment. The microcapsules
could be loaded with magnetic nanoparticles, which provided the possibility to guide spatially the whole
compartmentalized structure by applying an external magnetic field, which could be useful in
applications that require mobilization to and immobilization at a site (e.g., guided therapies).
Compartmentalization was exploited to encapsulate rhodamine as a model low molecular weight
molecule either in the interior of the microcapsules or in the ALG medium. Release studies at distinct
temperatures showed that rhodamine when encapsulated in the microcapsules was released at a lower
rate at physiological temperature, thanks to the use of ELRs. When encapsulated in the ALG
compartment, the release kinetics was not significantly affected. Incorporating distinct functions in a
same system by carefully selecting its constituents lets foresee the construction of customizable
microreactors that may exhibit other types of response, for instance, toward temperature, pH or light.
Such a device could also be used as a platform for the development of microenvironments that
simulate the formation of microtissues or the treatment of diseases at a laboratorial level.
The work developed herein shows how LbL-based strategies have surpassed the simple purpose of
modifying a surface. From the results obtained in each of the chapters of this thesis, it is clear that LbL
permits to achieve high degrees of functionalization and complexity, both in bioactivity and geometry,
for various distinct biomedical applications. Despite the potential of LbL, this technology has been
limited to the fabrication of bidimensional devices – some already in medical use. Thus, it is expected
that the superior functionalization may result in the development of strategies useful not only for
conventional medical applications but also more cutting-edge ones in biomedical engineering, such as
tissue engineering.
